story:
Our Story

Innervation Dance Cooperative (IDC) has been busy formatting two original contemporary ballets, Everyman and Gods, Monsters, and Heroes, based on classic literature, to tour to Chicago-area schools in 2012.


We based Everyman on the medieval morality play by the same name, a story of redemption, performing good deeds and living a life that matters. We set the tale to timeless, stirring music by Led Zeppelin. Gods, Monsters, and Heroes, set to contemporary music, tells various stories from Greek mythology, and educators can choose the myths they would like to see presented, customizing the performance for their students’ ages and studies. A study guide has been created for each show in an effort to enhance the students' and teachers' experience, presenting lessons about dance in general, about the literary works, the ballets themselves, and about how all of these elements relate to other subject areas. We had some wonderful experiences and feedback after taking Gods, Monsters, and Heroes on a few pilot tour performances earlier this year. Now the touring company is gearing up and eager to reach more young audiences, but we need your help!


The Impact

Today arts funding is at an all-time low and evidence suggests that arts engagement for kids and teens is more important and beneficial than ever. We remember being inspired as kids by visiting performers and we hope this tour will pay that inspiration forward by expanding young minds through exposure to meaningful movement, increasing students’ connection with literature by presenting literary classics in a visual and visceral medium, and creating life-long appreciators of dance and fine arts.


What We Need & What You Get

Your donations will help support costume creation, props/set design and creation, PR, booking, study guide creation, transportation, dancer stipends, etc. By supporting this project you not only help us cover costs, you also get one of our great perks. On top of that, you can sleep like a baby knowing you helped make possible the smiling face of a student being delighted and fascinated by a meaningful, educational dance performance.


Other Ways You Can Help

Please help us spread the word!  Use the share box to tell your friends about the project page or share the link manually. Thanks!

story:
With our second show coming up in just a little over a month we need to gather some more funds. Please help us get to $3,000! All of that money will go DIRECTLY to paying the artists involved a small stipend for the dozens and sometimes hundreds of hours of work that go into the magic of music and theater. 

--

This June, Brooklyn-based music and sound design collective Scouts remounts its first-ever concert-play at Ars Nova's ANTfest after a sold-out show at Dixon Place. As a band, they've played the McKittrick Hotel, Rockwood Music Hall, the Bowery Electric, and Littlefield. As a sound design and composition team for the theatre, they've worked at Galapagos Art Space, Ars Nova, the Brick, and Theatre for the New City.

"what's this called, this spirit?", written by Scouts frontwoman Jeanna Phillips and directed by Kate Hopkins, collides the narratives of Steinbeck's "The Grapes of Wrath" with the world of Rogers & Hammerstein's "Oklahoma!" and centers around a young girl who has grown up in the dust bowl - a generation removed from the cause of the catastrophe. Alternately heartbreaking and silly, "spirit" is a play about failure, growing pains, and the supreme discomfort of flour sack underwear.

The date is set, the script is written, and rehearsals are underway, but we still need your help! Here's where your money will go, should you choose to support us:

  • To rent rehearsal space in Manhattan and Brooklyn at places like Triskelion Arts, Leimay's CAVE, and Dixon Place.
  • To allocate a budget to our brilliant set designer, Rachel Schneider.
  • To provide small stipends for our performers and production team in exchange for the hours and hours of work they are pouring into our show.
From everyone on the team behind "what's this called, this spirit?", thank you for your donation!
--

created and written by Jeanna Phillips . directed by Kate Hopkins . featuring the talents of Molly McAdoo . Hannah Whitney . Kelsey Larsen . Alex Thrailkill . Daniel Johnson . Lannon Killea .  Rebecca Kushner . & Jeanna Phillips . with design by Ben Gullard . Rachel Schneider . Alejandro Fajardo . Alex Thrailkill .  & Molly McAdoo . produced by Dylan Moore . stage-managed by Gili Nir .

story:
Short Summary

Help us raise vital funds for the world premiere of Palestinian-Irish playwright Hannah Khalil’s Scenes from 68* Years at the Arcola Theatre in Dalston, East London from 5 April to 3 May 2016. 

Scenes from 68* Years is a selection of intertwined vignettes telling the story of ordinary Palestinians at a very human level with mischievous humour. It takes snapshots of the mundaneness of life in the shadow of occupation: we look into an Israeli household with a rebellious pro-Palestinian teenager, join a tediously long queue at an Israeli check point, and get swept into an absurd act of civil disobedience by Palestinian civilians in a desperate attempt to get worldwide media attention. 

Hannah is an award-winning writer who has had her plays broadcast on BBC Radio 4, and is working on ideas for the small and big screen. Hers is definitely a voice worth hearing!

What We Need & What You Get

The Arcola selected Scenes from 68* Years  from over 100 scripts to be part of the Arcola’s Playwrought #2  and have committed to support the production in kind with four weeks of rehearsal space and marketing support, but our most immediate need is to secure the venue with a deposit of £2,500. We need your help to secure this vital funding, which will ensure the project overcomes its first hurdle and gets off to a good start.

Our perks include shout outs on social media so you can flaunt your social conscience in public. We'll also print your name in the programme, and even offer you a free ticket once you've booked yours. You could also bag a copy of the first ever anthology of plays by Palestinian Writers which is only published in the USA and features Hannah's play Plan D. You could even have dinner with Hannah and the Director, Chris White and get personal insights in to her writing and the process of bringing the play to the stage. What more could you ask for?


The Impact

Sandpit Arts has had loads of success promoting Arab arts. We are a non-profit arts organisation, which creates inspiring, high participatory events for local communities. By providing platforms for presenting and discussing the diverse creative cultures of the Middle East, North Africa and their diasporas, our aim is to educate and create cross-cultural understanding. 

We have a track record of receiving public funding, so we feel confident that once we overcome this first hurdle, we will be able to raise the remaining funds to stage Scenes from 68* Years.


Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help:

  • Get the word out within your own circles, and pass on to your email list, and make some noise about our campaign.
  • Remember to use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that's all there is to it.


Pictures taken by Liz Hyder.

Film by Zeina Frangie-Eyres

story:
Short Summary

Hello! 

We are the Tempest Ladies, an all-female Shakespeare ensemble embarking on our fourth production, A Midsummer Night's Dream.  The show will open Off-Broadway in NYC this spring and tour to Istanbul later this year.

Our company was founded in 2008 at Shakespeare's Globe in London.  Our first production was The Tempest, which we produced, directed and performed. Quickly dubbed, The Tempest Ladies, we've carried our company and our productions (The Tempest, Macbeth, Taming of the Shrew) internationally (Edinburgh Fringe Festival, Istanbul Sevgi Gonul Festival, Istanbul SAHNE Besiktas) and nationally (NYC Off-Broadway, Off-Off-Broadway) for the past six years. 

We are thrilled to be in pre-production for our fourth Tempest Ladies Production, A Midsummer Night's Dream. It is truly a dream come true to not only still be together, but to be growing at such a rapid pace. Our productions are now being staged Off-Broadway, and beginning with Midsummer and going forward, our shows will be equity showcases.

Your support is invaluable because you help us grow and bring our unique takes on these classic works to bigger and broader audiences. With modesty, we do not know any other all-female Shakespeare ensemble that approaches his works the way we do with our part switches, our percussion music playing, and ensemble/tribal based story-telling.  Our productions are unrivaled in how we tell the most beautiful tales ever written. 

What We Need & What You Get

We are looking to raise $10,000 for a two week run for A Midsummer Night's Dream at a well-respected Off-Broadway theater.  Your donations will primarily go towards theater rental, costumes, set dressing.  The more we raise, the more amazing we can make the show!

Our perks for contributing are very special.  We are offering original, beautiful artwork and pottery, free tickets, a fun outing with the group and more!  We know that without our contributors our shows would not happen, and it is important to us to make sure that our donators know how much we appreciate them.  Anything contributed assists in keeping the arts alive and thriving!

If we don't reach our goal, the show will go on, but it will either be for a shorter run, or we will have to work with a very minimalistic set design, which is not ideal for this particular play.  We would really like to present an elaborate show for our audience and to be able to give people a special night at the theatre.  No matter what happens, we will give it everything we've got.  

The Impact

The Tempest Ladies has been together producing and performing Shakespeare since 2008, and we hope to continue to do so for a long time to come!  In addition to performing in NYC, we also take our shows over to Istanbul where we tour schools and teach kids about Shakespeare.  We value education through performance and creativity, and by donating to us, you will help us to further maintain our ability to educate overseas.  

Risks & Challenges

This is basically a risk-free donation.  No matter what, the show will go on, and any money that you contribute will be put towards it.  The only challenges that could potentially arise are on our end in the event that we do not reach our goal.  In that case, we will simply get creative and give you the best show we possibly can with what we have been given.  

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to contribute, there are many other ways that you can help!  If you feel inclined, you can help by spreading the word about our campaign to others, following us on Facebook, or by being an audience member!  We would love to have you be a part of our community.

I am raising money to help fund a demo recording of this new musical                         to promote with the ultimate goal of premiering on Broadway.

10% of all money raised will be given to one or more private sector                  Veteran's Support Programs to use in funding their initiatives.

story:
What

The new play Who's Afraid of Me, Myself & Edward Albee? by Matt Thompson is heading to the NY Fringe Festival August 10-16 2013 for a one week run.

Where

CSV Kabayitos
107 Suffolk St.
New York, NY, 10002

The Clemente Soto Vélez Cultural Center

When

August 10-16, 2013


NEW YORK FRINGE FESTIVAL SCHEDULE

August 10-16, 2013


Saturday, August 10 @ 2:15pm
Sunday, August 11 @ 7pm
Tuesday, August 13 @ 5:30pm
Wednesday, August 14 @ 2:30pm
Thursday August 15 @ 7pm
Friday, August 16 @ 9:15pm


Who

San Diego Playwrights Collective Production

 

Julianne Eggold - Musical Score & Songs

Valerie Henderson - Costume Design

Jeff Hillman - Cast Member

Libbey Lazarus - Producer / Hair & Make-up

Anya Tuerk - Assistant Director / SM

Matt Thompson - Playwright / Director

Matt Warburton - Sound Desgin

Jarrod Weintraub - Cast Memeber

 

Play Synopsis

While Larry is waiting for the bus to take him on his daily loop of chores he is visited by a irascible stranger named Herman.  As the two men wait endlessly for the bus to arrive they develop a visceral dialogue engaging in discussions about family, adoption, abandonment, and sexual orientation.  Herman inundates the mild mannered man with several cerebral attacks until Larry is left with questions, decisions, and a major choice at play's end.

Themes

Borrowing various themes and structures of Edward Albee's writing as well as his personal life, the story centers upon the plight of the human condition and the idea of self identity.

History of the play

1996 - The 15 minute short entitled Apemantus premieres at the San Diego Actor's Alliance Festival.

1997 - The 15 minute short is produced by The Plutonium Theatre in Oceanside, California.

1998 - The play is expanded to 50 minutes and produced at The Road Theatre in Los Angeles, California.

2000 - The 50 minute play is produced for a four week run at The Sweet Lies Theatre in Los Angeles, California.

2003 - A film version of Apemantus is produced.  LINK: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ow1GwnwvNSw

2008 - Numerous re-writes change the short play into a full 85 minute play entitled Who's Afraid of Me, Myself & Edward Albee?

2009 - Professional Staged Reading at North Coast Repertory Theatre in Solana Beach, California.

2009 - During the 2009 San Diego State Juries, Matt Thompson meets Edward Albee and discusses the author's canon and Matt's new play.  A monologue in Who's Afraid of Me, Myself & Edward Albee? is based on a thirty minute conversation between the two as Matt attempts to find Edward Albee a restroom after most of SDSU has shut down for Spring Break.

2010- Letters are exchanged between Matt Thompson and Edward Albee regarding the development of Who's Afraid of Me, Myself & Edward Albee?

2012 - Professional Staged Reading at Encinitas Theatre Consortium.

2013- Accepted into the Fresh Fruit Festival in New York

2013- Accepted into the FringeNY Festival in New York

2013 - July 29 - Professional Staged Reading at ion Theatre in San Diego, California.

Budget Breakdown:

APPLICATION FEE

$650 - Fee

 

SCENIC

$25- Props

$75 - Set

 

COSTUMES

$50 - Costume for Actor #1 - Jeff Hillman

$50 - Costume for Actor #2 - Jarrod Weintraub

 

MARKETING

$75 - Marketing logo

$595 - FringeNY program ad

$200 - Other marketing

$100 -Programs

 

TRANSPORTATION

$600 - Airfare for Producer - Cristina Surplus

$0   - Airfare for Playwright / Director - Matt Thompson

$600 - Airfare for Stage Manager/ Assistant Director - Anya Tuerk

$600 - Airfare for Actor #1 - Jeff Hillman

$600 - Airfare for Actor #2 - Jarrod Weintraub

$100 - General travel funds

 

LODGING

$500 - Lodging for Producer - Cristina Surplus

$500 - Lodging for Playwright / Director - Matt Thompson

$500 - Lodging for Stage Manager/ Assistant Director - Anya Tuerk

$500 - Lodging for Actor #1 - Jeff Hillman

$500 - Lodging for Actor #2 - Jarrod Weintraub

 

VENUE PAYMENTS

$100

 

INSURANCE

$250 - Insurance Bond

 

MISC.

$100


_____________________________________________________


$7270 - Budget TOTAL

$100 - General travel funds

$500 - Lodging for Playwright / Director - Matt Thompson
$500 - Lodging for Stage Manager/ Assistant Director - Anya Tuerk
$500 - Lodging for Actor #1 - Jeff Hillman
$500 - Lodging for Actor #2 - Jarrod Weintraub

story:
It's time we move master dramatist, John Howard Lawson, from the blacklisted Hollywood 10 and restore him to his rightful place, in the Top 10 American Playwrights.
 
Having produced the "lost" works of the Group Theatre for 4 years now to much acclaim, one of our most widely received pieces was our very first endeavor, a one-night production of John Howard Lawson's SUCCESS STORY in 2010.   To celebrate Mr. Lawson's amazing work, we are doing a 3 week festival of two of his plays.  In conjunction with SUCCESS STORY, his classic Group Theatre drama about the NY Advertising men of Madison Ave, we're presenting "Loud Speaker," his full-on vaudeville farce about politics, reporters, and voluptuous skeletons-in-the-closet, which was last staged 85 years ago.  
 
We've raised over $15,000 to bring these shows to fruition. We're so close to our goal, but we really need another $1500 to go towards production costs.  Please consider making a donation. Help bring great theatre to the NY stage and help vindicate this important voice in American Theatre.
 
We thank you for taking the time to read this campaign.  We appreciate your support in helping us bring these two amazing plays back to the stage for the first time in decades.
 
Please check out our website www.regrouptheatre.org for more information on our company and to buy tickets for "Success Story" and "Loud Speaker."  We hope to see you all there!
story_txt:
It's time we move master dramatist, John Howard Lawson, from the blacklisted Hollywood 10 and restore him to his rightful place, in the Top 10 American Playwrights.
 
Having produced the "lost" works of the Group Theatre for 4 years now to much acclaim, one of our most widely received pieces was our very first endeavor, a one-night production of John Howard Lawson's SUCCESS STORY in 2010.   To celebrate Mr. Lawson's amazing work, we are doing a 3 week festival of two of his plays.  In conjunction with SUCCESS STORY, his classic Group Theatre drama about the NY Advertising men of Madison Ave, we're presenting "Loud Speaker," his full-on vaudeville farce about politics, reporters, and voluptuous skeletons-in-the-closet, which was last staged 85 years ago.  
 
We've raised over $15,000 to bring these shows to fruition. We're so close to our goal, but we really need another $1500 to go towards production costs.  Please consider making a donation. Help bring great theatre to the NY stage and help vindicate this important voice in American Theatre.
 
We thank you for taking the time to read this campaign.  We appreciate your support in helping us bring these two amazing plays back to the stage for the first time in decades.
 
Please check out our website www.regrouptheatre.org for more information on our company and to buy tickets for "Success Story" and "Loud Speaker."  We hope to see you all there!

story:
Exhale Dance Tribe

Exhale Dance Tribe is a registered non-profit organization that relies soley on donations, grants, and gifts from our amazing supporters and community. As we begin our 2012-2013 season we are looking ahead to our Spring Dance Concert, "Love Letters" February 16th & 17th at the Aronoff Center for the Arts. 

What We Need 

As a resident dance company of the Aronoff, Exhale strives to put forth our very best every time we take the stage. To do so we need your help! Below you can see the direct affect your donation will have on our Spring Show. 

-Rental of the Aronoff Center for the Arts for two nights

-Costuming for the tribe

-The opportunity to bring in guest choreographers to set work on the Tribe

     -Past guest choreographers include Dee Caspary (So You Think You Can Dance)    Kristin Denehy (Taylor Swift's 2011 national tour, The Sing Off), Andrew Turteltaub (Member of Mia Michael's company RAW, Wicked, Fame) among others!

-Shane Weber hair/make up design

-Lighting desiger

-Photographer/Videographer

-Program/Poster printing and promotions

-Compensation for dancers and choreographers involved in "Love Letters"

Your Impact

We are so grateful for your donations and your generosity. Your gift, big or small will make an impact on our company and help us inspire those around us with the love of movement.

Exhale provides an outlet and education for young artists in our area that otherwise would not exist. Giving these artists a chance to perform and live their dreams out on stage is a lifelong gift. As a tribe we focus on diversity, healthy body images and outreach education to the youth in our area. With your help we can continue serving our community and the arts with dance. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word about Exhale Dance Tribe and our upcoming shows! Like us on facebook, give us a shout out to your friends and helps us spread the importance of dance and art in the Cincinnati area! Suggest this donation page to your friends and help us reach 100%!!!

 

Thank You from each and every one of us and know that without you Exhale would not be able to do what we do. Thank you thank you thank you!!!

story:
Hello There friends!
My name is Alena Adler and I am a senior majoring in Theater and Performance  minoring in Arts Management at SUNY Purchase.  For my senior project, I will be directed by Jesse Penber in A Woman Alone, a one woman show written by Dario Fo and Franca Rame.
Last year, I started studying Vaudeville and found myself interested in Solo performances. I had made it a bucketlist goal to do a One Woman show, when a teacher suggested I do one for a senior project. After reading a variety of different One Woman Shows, i found Dario Fo, and after reading another one of his plays, Waking up, and appreciateing his humor, I knew I had found something I was interested in. A Woman Alone was the second play I read and after laughing aloud at the humor and irony in the piece, I remember thinking 'I could see myself playing this character.' I kept it in the back of my mind and read a few more Dario Fo and Franca Rame One woman shows and decided AWA was the best choice.It is an intricate piece with more layers than an onion. It is a tragicomedy, meaning it is filled with both tragic and humourous elements. It was written in Italian in 1977, being performed that year in Italy. The english translation was written in 1981 and performed in 1982.
It is about Maria, a prisoner in her own home, using farce to push her forward. She tries to continue living life as normally as possible while juggling an abusive husband, a younger lover, a sexually deprived caller, a peeping tom and a perverted brother-in-law.
 
 This is the most important show I've ever done, so along with putting as much possible time into it, I'd also like the the set to be perfect. If I had more time (aka if I wan't a college student) I would spend my own money on props and the set, but I'm currently without a job and thus, money. I want to show how much everyone has put into this show. On that note, It would mean the world to me for any kind of support. Even $5 could help us get one of our 5 doors or a window.
 
 
So pretty please help us!
Thank you so much!
All the best,
Alena

story:
Who We Are

Conception

In 2010, an adventurous band of merry thespians, social entrepreneurs, fiscally prudent sorts and other adventurers, set out to create a new theater that would eventually become Serendipity Playhouse. This brainchild was born to change the World! (Or at least a 10 square mile segment of it in SW Washington.) Serendipity Players is committed to opening ourselves, our stage, our technical shop, and our classrooms to all people who want to participate, and who bring diverse backgrounds to enrich the process. In doing so, we have created a playhouse which illuminates all members in our community. We foster great plays, community interaction, and good fun while encouraging individuals with different agendas to tell their stories in new and healing ways.

                             ~ Serendipity Playhouse ~

                 Where Great Theater Includes Everybody!

Serendipity Players started this journey by producing “Sylvia” by A. R. Gurney in the Minnehaha Grange, during the hottest week of August in 2011. Encouraged by the success of our unknown theater company’s first work, we set out to find a home with air conditioning! We finally found Serendipity Playhouse in January of this year.

Birth – 2 Years

Since opening the Playhouse, we’ve produced two local playwrights and two internationally acclaimed playwrights to great reviews. We have learned a lot about the “behind the scenes” work that goes into producing great theater. Our audiences are growing, and we are bringing new people to the wonder of theater.

Now, at the dawn of our second year, we have learned our efforts to configure our barrier-free stage, facilities, and seating have come up short. Whenever you’re facing unforeseen stumbling blocks, the first thing to do is to gather all the information you can about the trouble. Here’s what has surprised our playhouse: in qualifying for a grant to complete the final cosmetic restoration on the exterior of our historical downtown space, a building inspection determined we must fine-tune some of the modifications we had already made to the interior of our theater.

To comply with these requests – regardless of continued eligibility for the grant – we must tweak changes to stage lighting, re-configure some of the seating, and meet other code alterations that seem minor, but are necessary to do.

The Future

Resilience will get us through this, but we’re going to need help.  We are wondering if you would pledge or donate any small amount you feel is appropriate to help the theater meet the improvement deadlines and continue with our important mission.  This money will translate into ensuring that barrier-free theater in the arts and culture of our town becomes part of the fabric to a vibrant and flourishing Vancouver. 

We are deeply appreciative for your past participation and support in helping launch our unique addition to quality performing arts in the region.  Putting this unexpected hurdle behind us will mark an important turning point for the continued excellence that is Serendipity Players.

The Impact

This is it. The big chance. The step up. How often do you get the chance to be a part of a new adventure from the beginning (or close to the beginning.) You'll be able to look at Serendipity Playhouse as not just a place where you come and see great theater, you'll be able to say, “I'm part of the reason this is here.” We're currently rehearsing our next show, we have the 2013 season laid out, and we've started making plans for 2014. If you help us, we'll be here for years to come. We've only started to scratch the surface of what we can do at Serendipity Playhouse. With your help, things will only get better.

We're trying to set a new standard for theater in SW Washington. We're hoping that future includes you as an active member of the Serendipity family.

It’s amazing, thrilling, terrifying – and the board of Serendipity is ready for our baby to grow up and take the leap. But we need your help.

Every donation made to this campaign will help us all realize our goal of maintaining a permanent venue.  It will help to continue to have great theater right here, in our community, without having to cross the bridge to the “big city.” 

What We Need

Only 40 to 60 percent of a non-profit theater's budget comes from the box office.  Our founders, Board of Trustees, Donors from the community and theater lovers like you provide the additional necessary funding to keep the keep the productions excellent and informed by diverse perspectives. Because of this, we need your help to raise the following funds:

$2,500 for air flow adjustments
$1,500 for permits
$1,500 for lighting upgrades
$1,500 for access by wheelchairs
$1,000 to adjust stadium seating arrangement to meet code

We have secured a promise of matching funds from one of our regular donors for all contributions received through this campaign - your gift will be doubled! Serendipity Players is a 501(c)(3) non-profit organization, so the portion of your donation that doesn't pay for a perk is tax deductible.

Other Ways You Can Help

Every little bit helps, but if you can't spare the cash, there are other things you can do:

  • Donate professional skills that would allow us to complete the work free of labor costs.
  • Help get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.
  • Indiegogo has share tools that you can use on Facebook, Twitter and your other favorite social media outlets!

             Spread the word, spread the word, spread the word!

“Thank you!” from all of us at Serendipity Players – Sandra Geary, President; Tony Broom, Artistic Director; the acting Board of Trustees: John Chiappetta, Vice President; Cecelia Harper, Secretary; David Crain, Development Director; Bob Pitman, Historian.

story:
Short Summary

We are drama students at Syracuse University, putting on an independent production of Jane Martin's, Keely and Du. This show is a volatile drama about abortion. Du, a right to life activist, and Keely, a pregnant rape victim she is confining, transcend their circumstances and the ideological issues that separate them. Keely and Du is a mind probing issue play with a gripping human face. Who is accountable? What is the extent of individual freedom? What are a rape victim's rights? What is a Christian's realities of procreation? Their passionate stories exist on the extreme edge of everyday reality.

Our AMAZING production team: 

  • Director and Set Designer - Amy Woschnik
  • Producer - Rachel Slotky
  • Stage Manager - Stephanie Lane
  • Lighting and Sound Designer - Susannah Baron 
  • Costumes - Juan Velez-Sanchez 
  • Props - Connor Norton and Cynthia Moore
  • Assitants - Lila Coogan, Hyrum Judkins and Lindsay Ortemeyer 

Our PHENOMENAL cast:

  • Keely - Rachel Slotky
  • Du - Bailey Lauren Thompson
  • Walter - Brooks Moyer
  • Cole - Will Serri
  • Prison Guard - Lila Coogan

What We Need & What You Get

Our goal is to raise $1,500 to cover our extensive props list, script distribution, advertising costs, materials for the set, and intricate costume pieces (including an extremely realistic baby bump!). Not to mention, ingredients to concoct a whole lot of fake blood!

The drama department has been extremely gracious in helping pay for as much as they have in their budget, but unfortunately it won't cover it all. Because it is an independent project, it is our duty to fundraise in order to make this production as professional and fully produced as possible, and create a realistic atmosphere for the audience. This play challenges the audience to think about their personal perspective on delicate issues, and consequently evaluate the opposing argument. We would hate for a lack of funds to interfere with our artistic goals. That is why we need YOUR help!

We understand the economy is rough at the moment, but trust us when we say that any little bit helps. We appreciate even the smallest donation! Every dollar we raise brings us one step closer to our ultimate goal. Even if you can't donate your money, we ask you to donate your time! If you aren't in the position to contribute, we would appreciate you sharing this page with your friends and family! If we can get the word out, we can reach our goal, and create a piece of art that we guarantee will take our audience on a thrilling and emotional ride.

story:
When a dancer comes onstage...behind him, [he] has all the decisions he has made in life... Each time he has chosen, and in what he is on stage, you see the result of those choices. You are looking at the person he is, the person who, at this point, he cannot help but be.
    - Mikhail Baryshnikov

   ___________________________________________

   Miscellum Dance Collective is a select group of eight professional, Toronto-based dancers, coming together under the leadership of Ming-Bo Lam. Each dancer has a unique story and background which allows them to bring an exceptional quality to the collective as a whole. Some have trained extensively in classical ballet and modern, while others specialize in urban dance styles. All are dedicated, passionate, and driven individuals committed to mastering their craft. By bringing both their depth of knowledge and beautiful artistic diversity to a common place, the potential for creating innovative work is endless.

     'Miscellum' is Latin for hybrid, or mixed type. Our mission is to open the doors of Toronto’s independent, often underground, dance scene and encourage audiences to discover the awesome talent this city has to offer. To learn more about who we are, and our goals as a collective, please visit our website: www.miscellumdance.com
 
    Why did we create this Indiegogo campaign? We are currently producing our first full-length work as a collective this November, and need your help to ensure it comes together to the best of our ability. Reaching our fundraising goal will provide us with the means to cover production costs and pay our dancers. In return, we will give you a refreshing, inspiring evening of dance -- in addition to our love and gratitude!

   ___________________________________________

Fundraising Goal: $6000

-Lighting Designer $300
-Theatre Rental $900
-Dancers ($500/dancer) $4000
-Indigogo Fee (appx.) $500
-Emergency Funds $300

*If we reach our goal, 4% will go to Indiegogo, for allowing us to use this platform. If we fail to reach our goal, that percentage will rise to 9%.

*Best case scenario: we hit $7000, or beyond! Surpassing our goal will provide us with additional funding for documentation and filming, in addition to marketing, which is currently coming out of my own pocket.

*What about box office profits? Partial box office profits will go towards the dancers, the goal to bring their pay up to $1000, as well as additional pay to our lighting designer, and others involved in the process.

*What if we don't make our goal? Hopefully we are able to at least clear the $2000 mark, so we can cover production costs. If this is the case, we will split 100% of the box office profits amongst the dancers. If we fail to raise $2000, production costs will be covered by personal means, with profits going to the dancers.

___________________________________________

The Timeline

    We have been rehearsing on and off for the past year, but this will pick up drastically come September. A deposit has been put down on theatre space, the performance dates are November 7 & 8th, 2013.

    Full details will be released come September.

___________________________________________

The Performance

    Recently I have been witness to a couple of incidents that caused me to question the value and importance of T i m e.  
    
    The conclusion I came to was that no matter how many hours are spent with someone, how many stories are told, laughs, kisses, and moments are shared, it will never be enough. Perhaps this is an obvious statement, but for some reason the realization that I will never have enough time has sat heavily with me, and has since been present in the back of my mind.      

    My goal is to create a piece that explores, through various relationships, separate stories, all related to the concept of time: beginnings, middles, and ends.     And, most importantly, when time is up...what remains?

    This work will feature the talents of: Alexandra Crenian; Emily Einsmann; Mayumi Lashbrook; Dane 'Tall-Up' Gulston and Dwayne 'Boneless' Gulston, of Mayhem's Finest; Derick Xclusiv Robinson and Raffaele Brereton, of the O.G. Crew.

___________________________________________


The Impact

    I have re-written this section a thousand times, trying to find a reason for you to care about this project of mine. I started brainstorming until I got to the heart of it all; the following is what stood out.    

    This performance will give us, the dancers of MDC, the rare opportunity to showcase a different side of our artistry. The majority of paid work we have done, as individuals, has been where the focus is on commercial entertainment. This is awesome! We love it and are thankful for everything these opportunities have provided us! However, I also believe that it is important to participate in work that addresses bigger questions and concepts, and allows us to be a part of a creative process that pushes us outside both our emotional and physical comfort zones. Our goal is to come away from this experience with a deeper understanding of our capabilities as both performing artists and human beings, and encourage our audience to push their own boundaries in their lives as well.    
   
    Through exploring the “value and importance of time”, what we are really seeking to answer is: what will our legacy be? What will the consequences of our actions be? What do we aim to leave behind? How can we positively affect the world in which we live? By helping us achieve our goal of creating this work, you are helping us answer these questions, and (we hope!) inspired to answer them for yourself.     
  
    Each dancer involved with Miscellum Dance Collective is an individual who is generous with their time, talent, and knowledge. We teach and volunteer in community, school, and studio based programs. We educate youth in dance and all it entails: self-discipline, fitness, health, spatial awareness, musicality, emotional intelligence, creativity, problem solving, teamwork, self-confidence, goal setting...the list is endless. Through supporting this project, you are helping us grow and build our knowledge, which we can then pass on to those with whom we work.

    Thank you - truly - from the bottom of my heart, if you actually read all the way down to this last paragraph, it means the world that you took the time to do so.

    I know how it feels to have someone ask for the money you work so hard for, so if you have already reached your donation budget, I completely understand. Please know that even passing this campaign on to anyone you know, who may be interested, could potentially make a difference and get us one step closer to our goal.

   With love,
        xo Ming-Bo & the Artists of Miscellum Dance Collective

 

*Photo credit: Katie Nicole Photography

   ___________________________________________   Miscellum Dance Collective is a select group of eight professional, Toronto-based dancers, coming together under the leadership of Ming-Bo Lam. Each dancer has a unique story and background which allows them to bring an exceptional quality to the collective as a whole. Some have trained extensively in classical ballet and modern, while others specialize in urban dance styles. All are dedicated, passionate, and driven individuals committed to mastering their craft. By bringing both their depth of knowledge and beautiful artistic diversity to a common place, the potential for creating innovative work is endless.     'Miscellum' is Latin for hybrid, or mixed type. Our mission is to open the doors of Toronto’s independent, often underground, dance scene and encourage audiences to discover the awesome talent this city has to offer. To learn more about who we are, and our goals as a collective, please visit our website: www.miscellumdance.com     Why did we create this Indiegogo campaign? We are currently producing our first full-length work as a collective this November, and need your help to ensure it comes together to the best of our ability. Reaching our fundraising goal will provide us with the means to cover production costs and pay our dancers. In return, we will give you a refreshing, inspiring evening of dance -- in addition to our love and gratitude!
   ___________________________________________Fundraising Goal: $6000-Lighting Designer $300-Theatre Rental $900-Dancers ($500/dancer) $4000-Indigogo Fee (appx.) $500-Emergency Funds $300*If we reach our goal, 4% will go to Indiegogo, for allowing us to use this platform. If we fail to reach our goal, that percentage will rise to 9%.*Best case scenario: we hit $7000, or beyond! Surpassing our goal will provide us with additional funding for documentation and filming, in addition to marketing, which is currently coming out of my own pocket.
*What about box office profits? Partial box office profits will go towards the dancers, the goal to bring their pay up to $1000, as well as additional pay to our lighting designer, and others involved in the process.
*What if we don't make our goal? Hopefully we are able to at least clear the $2000 mark, so we can cover production costs. If this is the case, we will split 100% of the box office profits amongst the dancers. If we fail to raise $2000, production costs will be covered by personal means, with profits going to the dancers.___________________________________________The Timeline    We have been rehearsing on and off for the past year, but this will pick up drastically come September. A deposit has been put down on theatre space, the performance dates are November 7 & 8th, 2013.     Full details will be released come September.___________________________________________The Performance    Recently I have been witness to a couple of incidents that caused me to question the value and importance of T i m e.          The conclusion I came to was that no matter how many hours are spent with someone, how many stories are told, laughs, kisses, and moments are shared, it will never be enough. Perhaps this is an obvious statement, but for some reason the realization that I will never have enough time has sat heavily with me, and has since been present in the back of my mind.          My goal is to create a piece that explores, through various relationships, separate stories, all related to the concept of time: beginnings, middles, and ends.     And, most importantly, when time is up...what remains?     This work will feature the talents of: Alexandra Crenian; Emily Einsmann; Mayumi Lashbrook; Dane 'Tall-Up' Gulston and Dwayne 'Boneless' Gulston, of Mayhem's Finest; Derick Xclusiv Robinson and Raffaele Brereton, of the O.G. Crew.
___________________________________________
The Impact    I have re-written this section a thousand times, trying to find a reason for you to care about this project of mine. I started brainstorming until I got to the heart of it all; the following is what stood out.        This performance will give us, the dancers of MDC, the rare opportunity to showcase a different side of our artistry. The majority of paid work we have done, as individuals, has been where the focus is on commercial entertainment. This is awesome! We love it and are thankful for everything these opportunities have provided us! However, I also believe that it is important to participate in work that addresses bigger questions and concepts, and allows us to be a part of a creative process that pushes us outside both our emotional and physical comfort zones. Our goal is to come away from this experience with a deeper understanding of our capabilities as both performing artists and human beings, and encourage our audience to push their own boundaries in their lives as well.             Through exploring the “value and importance of time”, what we are really seeking to answer is: what will our legacy be? What will the consequences of our actions be? What do we aim to leave behind? How can we positively affect the world in which we live? By helping us achieve our goal of creating this work, you are helping us answer these questions, and (we hope!) inspired to answer them for yourself.             Each dancer involved with Miscellum Dance Collective is an individual who is generous with their time, talent, and knowledge. We teach and volunteer in community, school, and studio based programs. We educate youth in dance and all it entails: self-discipline, fitness, health, spatial awareness, musicality, emotional intelligence, creativity, problem solving, teamwork, self-confidence, goal setting...the list is endless. Through supporting this project, you are helping us grow and build our knowledge, which we can then pass on to those with whom we work.
    Thank you - truly - from the bottom of my heart, if you actually read all the way down to this last paragraph, it means the world that you took the time to do so.    I know how it feels to have someone ask for the money you work so hard for, so if you have already reached your donation budget, I completely understand. Please know that even passing this campaign on to anyone you know, who may be interested, could potentially make a difference and get us one step closer to our goal.   With love,        xo Ming-Bo & the Artists of Miscellum Dance Collective
 
*Photo credit: Katie Nicole Photography

story:
The above picture shows me on stage playing the character of Magrat Garlick in Terry Pratchett's play, Wyrd Sisters.

Hello,

My name is Hannah. I am 19 yeas old and an aspiring actress. More than that, I am an aspiring performer. I hope to one day be able to inspire and capture the hearts of an audience the way that I have been inspired and made to fall in love with the art of acting. As you may well know, the competition for aspiring actors to get into prestigious drama schools is very high with thousands of people desperately wanting to get in every year and going to audition after audition. Through my hard work and determination I have been privileged enough to be accepted into one of the best and highly respected drama schools in the country, The Oxford School of Drama. I have been accepted to do a Foundation Degree in Acting. 

The tuition fees for this course costs over £7,000 and with no government funding available I am left to raise this myself. £7,000 is an unthinkably large amount of money however, with help from my supportive family, out of this I now just need to raise the last £500 to keep my honorable place at The Oxford School of Drama. The course covers the acting methods and techniques of Stanislavski, Chekhov and Hagen, as well as classes in movement, voice, singing, stage fighting, film and television work and professional development. I can compare the opportunities I will get from this to nothing I have ever experienced in my life. 

I have a strong passion for performance. I relish the versatility it demands of the performer and the challenge of engaging and connecting with the viewer. I began my journey with the Stagecoach Theatre Arts Company, being introduced to singing, dancing and acting and I have recently completed a B-TEC Extended Diploma in Performing Arts. In this, I have had the opportunity to further develop my skills in these disciplines and I completed the course proudly achieving final grades of DMM. During this time, I have had amazing opportunities in the industry such as being a background artist in a feature film, How I Live Now, and also popular ITV programmes Lewis and Endeavour. I've had chance to meet and discuss with known professionals within the industry on a live set. I have also performed in venues such as Oxford New Theatre, Pegasus Theatre, Chipping Norton Theatre and the Wycombe Swan. I spend my spare time seeking supporting artist opportunities, gaining modelling experience, maintaining my fitness and holding down a part time job to finance my ambitions. I can not express enough the life changing opportunities I will gain from the training I will receive at The Oxford School of Drama.

I appreciate that £500 is still a very large amount of money and not many people have money to spare but even the smallest amount will be a blessing to me! The funds will go only towards my drama school education and nothing else. If you are able to support me and contribute whatever way you can towards my future, I, in return, will keep you in it! I will write you a personal thank you letter to help show my appreciation of your kindness and invite you to any shows/showcases I may have. I will let you know of my progress (and success!) of being a drama student and let you know of my journey afterwards, which will hopefully continue to grow as I pursue it.

Even if you are unable to contribute I would still appreciate a simple share of this page to let others know and I will be just as thankful! Above this text is a simple link to share my page!

Thank you so much for taking the time to read this. I am not usually one to ask for money, however I will do anything I can to help further myself in the industry and in my own personal training. Every little helps, however small or large! I am extremely greatful to all.

Thank you, Hannah Barron

story:
Short Summary

Hello! My name is Chris Lovell, and I am a sophomore at the College of Saint Rose. I've had a passion for theatre since 6th Grade. Last year I was able to start a project that was a dream of mine for a couple of years. The drama department at Saint Rose helped produce the first run of the Saint Rose Theatre Festival. It was very successful, filling every seat in the house in its one-night-only run. 

As soon as the house emptied after the performance, I knew that I wanted to see the festival into a second year. This year the festival will run for an entire weekend, and for that to happen successfully, we need your help.

What we need your help for...

To make theatre accessible to everyone, the festival is free to all attendees. Having a multi-performance festival with free admission makes things difficult financially. So, to successfully produce the festival this year, we will need to expand our budget. Some of the things we need funding for include:


- New walkie-talkie system for communication between backstage, house management, and lights/sound
- Advertisement and publicity materials (including print and online media advertisements)
- Printing and binding of scripts and programs
- Lighting and sound effects equipment
- Paint to revamp the theatre

The Impact

College is the prime time for everyone to enjoy new things and make some self discoveries. Not many students have the chance to see their writings come to life on stage. This festival does exactly that, It also gives theatre goers a view into new and interesting ideas in theatre. 

Other Ways You Can Help

I understand if you aren't able to contribute financially to the theatre festival. But you can still help make the festival even more successful than it was last year. You can help spread the news about the festival and this campaign, and follow the festival on multiple social media platforms. 

"Like" the festival on facebook! www.facebook.com/CSRTheatreFestival

Follow us on Twitter! www.twitter.com/CSRTheatre_Fest 

Stay updated throughout the whole process, even after this funding campaign is over! Join the Festival Mailing List:http://www.theatrefestival.info/mailing-list.html

story:
What is The Three Leaches? The Three Leaches is a small local theatre company, dedicated to bringing quality, exciting and edgy theatre to the masses for an affordable price.

We wholeheartedly believe great theatre should focus first and foremost on the quality and depth of the story and acting, which is why a budget of $1000 is set for every show we produce. 

We forgo ornate sets, complicated costumes, and glamorous divas to give you the best experience we can. 
This is theatre - raw. 

  • So why do we need your generous donations? The Three Leaches wants to do something new- we are always looking for ways to expand and challenge ourselves! We want to take two fantastic shows- one classic and one modern take on that classic- and produce them side by side as one show/ project instead of two.  This takes twice the resources to accomplish, which is why we need your help!

The shows: 

The Seagull by Anton Chekhov- This classic dramatises the romantic and artistic conflicts between four characters: the ingenue Nina, the fading actress Irina Arkadina, her son the playwrite Konstantin Tréplev, and the famous middlebrow story writer Trigorin.  This classic will be directed by the incredibly talented Bryce Alexander. 

The Nina Variations by Steven Dietz, A Denver Playwright- Dietz imagines 42 different scenarios between Chekhov’s Nina and Treplev, the young actress and playwright from The Seagull. What happens when these two classic characters are trapped in a room together with no way out? This will be directed by The Three Leaches Artistic Director, Melissa Leach. 

Where does our money go? Even if we don't meet our total goal, every little bit helps.  All of the money from this fundraiser will go towards the rights, the rental price, the costumes, the set, and the props for these two shows. It is money well spent! Denver's theatre scene is growing and you can help the arts thrive!

  • What's in it for you? Good question.  First of all, you get to help fund two fantastic shows. We also want to thank you all for donating, so depending on how much you donate, we will show our love for you with: Shout outs in our programs, free tickets to see the shows, a free drink at the show, a sneak peek at the rehearsal process, and finally, a dinner with the owners of The Three Leaches before a performance.

story:
Melissa Attebery, Vanessa Shealy and Nichole Donje’ are actors, writers, directors and producers; three artists who consistently face the wonders and challenges of being women in the entertainment industry and yet continue to pursue these fields with passion and integrity. They have come together to answer the challenge put forth by MISS REPRESENTATION to host a screening of its award winning documentary film.

They are doing that, and then some! This is an action packed night bringing art, theatre, film and audience together to explore and connect as an ensemble.

MISS REPRESENTATION is a powerful, educational and emotional film. It’s important for us to come together to experience this film as a community. Then our discussion of women's “roles”  in this industry will invoke your passion to move toward positive change. It will make you ask the difficult question, “Is it what I believe or what I have been shown I should believe?”

Let us entertain you.

Ignite your passion.

Share your voice.

And keep this dialogue moving ever forward.

Let’s make this happen together!!!

 

Here is what we need:

MONEY!

Money for the Event & Rehearsal Space, the Bar, Photographer/Exhibit, Musicians, Actors, Panelists, Marketing, Supplies, etc. 

All money goes directly to making this event AMAZING!

 

AND YOU GET GREAT PERKS!!!!

$1+ - LOVE!

We will give you a big shout out on Facebook, Twitter, in emails and on our many websites!

$25+ - THANKS!

We will send you ONE THANK YOU NOTE signed by all of us.
(Wow!!! - Priceless!)
  (plus the LOVE above, of course)
 
$50+ - POETRY

We will write TWO HAIKUS personalized for you!
  (plus LOVE and THANKS)

$100+ - BEAUTY!

We will give you THREE PHOTO CARDS from donje' photography!
  (plus LOVE, THANKS and POETRY)

$250+ - JOY!

We will give you FOUR GLASSES OF WINE . . . conveniently packed in one wine bottle!
  (plus LOVE, THANKS, POETRY and BEAUTY)

$500+ - GOLD!

We will send you FIVE GOLDEN TICKETS (yes, Golden!) to our May 6th event!
  (plus LOVE, THANKS, POETRY, BEAUTY, and JOY!)

How awesome is that?!!!!!

 

No Money?

If you can’t contribute monetarily, we TOTALLY understand. But here’s how you can help for free....

TELL 4 FRIENDS!  Share this link in email and on Facebook and Twitter! If everyone who reads this tells 4 friends, then we are golden, too!!!!

BUY A TICKET! They are only $10 and can be purchased NOW!

 

ABOUT THE NIGHT

JOIN US MAY 6TH @ The Players club,  16 Gramercy S., NYC

SCHEDULE OF EVENTS:

6:00pm Cocktail hour with live music & photo exhibit by Yvette D’Elia

7:00pm Stage Performance: SHE, by Caridad Svich

7:15pm Feature Documentary Screening: MISS REPRESENTATION

8:45pm Post-Show Discussion with a panel of experts

  • PANELISTS:
    • Casting Director Brette Goldstein
    • 2012 OBIE Award winner for Lifetime Achievement Caridad Svich
    • New York Times featured director Jackson Gay

Door prizes and raffle drawings thoughout the night

 

For more details, information and updates go to TAPT

story:
Be a part of the Monster

Monsterpiece Theater Collective is a group of artists from multiple disciplines that are inspired by the classic in order to create something new. We look towards the things that inspire us (an author, a statue, an art form) and deconstruct, connect, and build something new and sometimes dangerous. As a collective we seek to break down walls, kick open doors, and smash through glass ceilings.

In our newest creation we look away from Shakespeare and decided to go a little wild, Oscar Wilde. This one is going to be a monster and we cannot do this without our Monster fans.

 How to help

After spending a year working with our collective of artists on script exploration and ensemble building we wanted to bring the monster fans some bubbly and bright in order to share the love we have been feeling. As we create this show as a true collective we hope to bring you the most amazing product possible, but that is not free. As you have probably guessed there is no way to produce theater for only $2,000 in NYC. As a show of dedication to you we are only asking for a small portion of our budget. The largest amount is coming from our "collective" pocket. Not a company but from the artists themselves. We believe in the work that we do so we only ask for what we need and we pay for the rest.

But we only get it if you lend a hand. Think of it as a Valentines Gift to the monster that you love. For as little as $10 you can get one of our awesome thank you gifts; blog mentions, signed scripts, and tickets to the show are only the tip of the iceberg. As we create everything about this show as a collective, for our top donation, we will work your name into a song in the show and record that song for you as a special thank you. We will insert a new name for each top level contribution and I dare you to make us work as many names into the song as possible.

The Impact

Independent theater is a breeding ground for new artists and innovation. In New York, indie theater is being forced to compromise or being forced out due to high rents, astronomical production rental costs, and exorbitant marketing prices. In order for a theater to take risks, they need support from all areas. “Crowd funding” support is how we know that you believe in innovation, creativity, and opportunity. We believe strongly in those areas as well.

 Inserting songs into classical work is not a new concept, especially into classical scripts. In this show we want to honor a connection that has been often over looked. John Gambril Nicholson was a poet and contemporary of Wilde and inspired at the very least the title of this treasured play by his work Love in Earnest (published three years before Importance). Very little is left connecting the two except the company they kept and the dual lives they led as gay men. The idea of "bunburying" was Wilde, the fondness for the name Earnest was Nicholson, but the trails of living a double life was felt by both men as well as many others that were forced to hide their love from English society. We want to connect the art of both men in this amazing play and these beautiful (and often hilarious) poems, songs and ballads. We hope that you will join us by donating.

       "If one plays good music, people don't listen and if one plays bad music people don't talk."
Oscar Wilde

Help us make the right kind of music with Oscar Wilde and John Gambril Nicholson.


Other Ways You Can Help

We love any amount of financial support that you can give and we could never do the type of work we do in this city without all the love we are shown from the Monsters. There are other ways you can help as well.

  • Tell everyone you know that we are trying to reach our goal. Share on all your social media platforms and don't forget that Indie Go Go makes it easy with its share buttons.
  • Buy a ticket to see the show. March 27-30 at the Beckmann Theater in NYC.
  • Email us to pitch a production, join our board, or be a part of the collective. mptheatercollective@gmail.com
  • Create your own Monster. Don't wait for us to kick down your walls and break through that glass ceiling. Nothing is stopping you, surround yourself with your friends and just create it!
story_txt:
Be a part of the MonsterMonsterpiece Theater Collective is a group of artists from multiple disciplines that are inspired by the classic in order to create something new. We look towards the things that inspire us (an author, a statue, an art form) and deconstruct, connect, and build something new and sometimes dangerous. As a collective we seek to break down walls, kick open doors, and smash through glass ceilings.In our newest creation we look away from Shakespeare and decided to go a little wild, Oscar Wilde. This one is going to be a monster and we cannot do this without our Monster fans. How to helpAfter spending a year working with our collective of artists on script exploration and ensemble building we wanted to bring the monster fans some bubbly and bright in order to share the love we have been feeling. As we create this show as a true collective we hope to bring you the most amazing product possible, but that is not free. As you have probably guessed there is no way to produce theater for only $2,000 in NYC. As a show of dedication to you we are only asking for a small portion of our budget. The largest amount is coming from our "collective" pocket. Not a company but from the artists themselves. We believe in the work that we do so we only ask for what we need and we pay for the rest.But we only get it if you lend a hand. Think of it as a Valentines Gift to the monster that you love. For as little as $10 you can get one of our awesome thank you gifts; blog mentions, signed scripts, and tickets to the show are only the tip of the iceberg. As we create everything about this show as a collective, for our top donation, we will work your name into a song in the show and record that song for you as a special thank you. We will insert a new name for each top level contribution and I dare you to make us work as many names into the song as possible.The ImpactIndependent theater is a breeding ground for new artists and innovation. In New York, indie theater is being forced to compromise or being forced out due to high rents, astronomical production rental costs, and exorbitant marketing prices. In order for a theater to take risks, they need support from all areas. “Crowd funding” support is how we know that you believe in innovation, creativity, and opportunity. We believe strongly in those areas as well. Inserting songs into classical work is not a new concept, especially into classical scripts. In this show we want to honor a connection that has been often over looked. John Gambril Nicholson was a poet and contemporary of Wilde and inspired at the very least the title of this treasured play by his work Love in Earnest (published three years before Importance). Very little is left connecting the two except the company they kept and the dual lives they led as gay men. The idea of "bunburying" was Wilde, the fondness for the name Earnest was Nicholson, but the trails of living a double life was felt by both men as well as many others that were forced to hide their love from English society. We want to connect the art of both men in this amazing play and these beautiful (and often hilarious) poems, songs and ballads. We hope that you will join us by donating.       "If one plays good music, people don't listen and if one plays bad music people don't talk."Oscar WildeHelp us make the right kind of music with Oscar Wilde and John Gambril Nicholson.Other Ways You Can HelpWe love any amount of financial support that you can give and we could never do the type of work we do in this city without all the love we are shown from the Monsters. There are other ways you can help as well.
Tell everyone you know that we are trying to reach our goal. Share on all your social media platforms and don't forget that Indie Go Go makes it easy with its share buttons.
Buy a ticket to see the show. March 27-30 at the Beckmann Theater in NYC.
Email us to pitch a production, join our board, or be a part of the collective. mptheatercollective@gmail.com
Create your own Monster. Don't wait for us to kick down your walls and break through that glass ceiling. Nothing is stopping you, surround yourself with your friends and just create it!

story:
“Scary Musical The Musical” has all the elements of a classic Scary Movie - with an added twist – the characters sing and dance before, during and sometimes after getting killed!


With an original pop rock score and a cutting edge script, this new age Rocky Horror Picture Show will take you on a bloody and hilarious musical adventure like never before.




Fasten your seat belts. It’s going to be a bloody night!

Please join us as we begin our fundraising campaign for our production at the NoHo Arts Center in North Hollywood, opening in September 2014

“Scary Musical The Musical” Show History

  • ASCAP/ Disney Musical Theatre Workshop presented in collaboration with   Stephen Schwartz and Michael Kerker - February 2010
  • University of Northern Colorado Workshop Production. January 2011
  •  Pittsburgh Civic Light Opera/Carnegie Mellon University School of Drama      New Works Program presented by Stephen Schwartz - May 2012
  •  Workshop Production at the York Theatre in NYC - March 2013
  •  Staged reading at the Chance Theatre in Anaheim ,CA - May 2013

Here is what some folks had to say about “Scary Musical The Musical”

“ ...could be the next Little Shop of Horrors.”
Stephen Schwartz ( Wicked, Pippin, Godspell)

“I love this show. You guys have the genuine funny bone. Hallelujah! I can’t wait to see this show. The music soars ... I love the voice this is coming from."   Jeff Marx (Tony award winning writer Avenue Q.)

“This show is so clever...it’s great”
Susan Dietz ( Producer Fela, The Little Dog That Laughed)

Creative Team

Book :
Richard Hochberg

Music and Lyrics:
Richard Hochberg and Michael Paternostro

Director/Choreographer:
James J Mellon

Casting:
Michael Donovan Casting CSA

Producers:
Kevin Bailey , Victoria Morris, Daniel Solis 

Check out our “Scary Swag” and support us in any way you can. And please help spread the word.

story:
Two Households...

    The Keeper’s Daughter’s Romeo or Juliet is a promenade production of the classic Shakespearean love story.  Choose your side and follow either Romeo or Juliet as their lives unravel into one of the greatest literary tragedies ever told.
    We at The Keeper's Daughter turn traditional stories into modern, imaginative theatre that inspires young people.  This is our first summer of development and you could help us get this event in front of as many young people as possible.

    How you can help

    We are holding many fundraising events over the next month but we also need your help in order to part fund our 10 day development period, which includes 3 days of performances. 

    To our knowledge Romeo and Juliet has never been performed quite in this way, with the Montague and Capulet story threads running simultaneously in separate areas of the venue.  It's a brilliant opportunity to open up the story in a new way.

    Not only is the dual story thread aspect of the production awesome but we will be performing in a different space every time we perform the show.  Every single performance will be completely unique.

    The main challenge with this production is the sheer scale of it.  We have a 14 strong company of professional actors - a real mixture of experience and backgrounds - all of whom also play an important role behind the scenes, covering all admin, marketing and producing bases.

    All the funding raised will go toward covering the costs that come with employing 14 professionals.  Oh, and we'll also need some new ties...


      What the audience can expect...

        Not only is this experience unique to the company of actors but we want the audience to feel just as much a part of the story.

      When our audience book they must choose an allegiance to one family or the other, in the form of a coloured tie.  A blue tie means they are now a member of the Montague family.  A red tie means they swear allegiance to the Capulets.  They must wear these ties throughout the production. 

      Audience will also be asked to bring with them a mask for the Capulet’s ball as there will be a prize for the best dressed party goer.

       


      If you can't donate to the project then please spread the word.  We all believe this is a truly unique experience and we want to get it out there.  This summer is the first step in, hopefully, a very long journey.

story:
YAYASAN PENDIDIKAN KREATIFITAS REMAJA

"Centerstage Performance Art School"

I opened this school as a result of there being a need for both expats, mixed race and locals to learn Music, Acting and Dance in Contemporary Forums and offer some Western style teaching in these areas. The school has been well received, and this was our first Musical Theatre experience. 

Bali has a wonderful culture for the Arts - but sadly, for our western kids and for the Indonesian locals that crave modern and popular music, dance and theatre - there are few vocational resources.

So, our first production was chosen - and GREASE - was the word!

It is so rewarding to watch the kids on stage, and to try and offer them a "real" theatrical experience. Sets, Props, Costumes, Hair, Photography and Marketing were all part of the overall proposition.

GREASE 

The show took more than 6 months of rehearsals, planning and organization. We auditioned more than 70 kids for the parts and ended up writing a whole new scene to include more kids in the musical. We ended up with a cast of 25 kids aged between 9 and 14 years.

We were generously given some sponsorship for a venue, some hair and make-up and advertising - that saved us just over $8000. Money came from monthly fees charged to pay for the educational development provided, with this money we could pay for the costumes, backdrops, live band, extra staging, lighting, sound plus a Professional Dramatics Arts teacher's time, direction and knowledge. Even with the sale of tickets we are still short $4000.....

I would like to start working on the next production - but I am scared with this debt looming over me personally - as I am still not drawing a wage from this business and I teach over 60 kids per week.

The Yayasan or Not for Profit employs 3 Indonesian full time staff plus pays 7 teachers every week, after rent, amenities and minor advertising there has been little left. 

If you can donate $25 or more - I will send you a video copy of our GREASE production in Bali. It was a truly amazing experience and would like to able to facilitate at least two full musicals per year in Bali for our kids.

story:
Our Indiegogo campaign goal is now a 100% complete! We are so very grateful to everyone who contributed!

The birth of "The Rose Valley" project

Our 2012 "Roots and Origins" project, funded by the Manhattan Community Arts Fund, brought together classical Bulgarian literature, ethnography, music and dance. The exhibition of household objects from Bulgarian villages represented the time when the short story "The Windmill", by classical writer Elin Pelin, was written. The workshop explained rituals, described in the short story, while the final performance brought the story to life, along with some of the exhibits as stage designs and props.

In 2012, the room for the final performance was full and we had a long wait list. That is how the idea for "The Rose Valley" project was born. It is a multi-disciplinary  project that will introduce the American public and re-introduce the Bulgarian community in Manhattan to the beauty of the traditional dances, costumes, songs and music. This project's goals are to show the vibrance and the dynamic of the Bulgarian dance, songs and music by staging performances inspired by or dedicated to the Rose Valley in Bulgaria - a place of stunning natural beauty that has inspired generations of artists and has famed Bulgaria with its fragrant oil-producing roses. The audience will enjoy performances by GORANA DANCE folk dance ensemble, by the renown Bulgarian singer Vlada Tomova with her "Yasna Voices" folk choir, by students from the biggest teen folk dance ensemble in the U.S. - "Gorana Jr" - "Hristo Botev" Bulgarian School in New York, and other guests. 

"The Rose Valley" project is our way of building upon, expanding our previous work and making the performance available to a larger audience in a professional setting. We want to open it to a larger audience interested in expanding their cross-cultural ties.

You can buy tickets for the event
Here: https://est-85248.ticketbud.com/the-rose-valley-performance-of-music-songs-and-dance

Here: Parrot Coffee Market, 31-12 Ditmars Blvd, Astoria, New York

Or here: Park West High School, 525 W 50 Str., Dance Studio, Fl. 5 on Sundays, May 11 - June 1 between 10 am and 3 pm (except May 25)

Please help us make this a reality!

We start out with a budget of $2000 - combining a donation and a grant from Lower Manhattan Cultural Council, but our expenses exceed our funds. We ask that you help us raise another $2000. Your contribution will help us:


(1) Cover part of the expenses for a professional auditorium that accommodates a  larger audience and enhances the artistic performance ($2200);

(2) Cover part of the expenses for a professional photographer and video recording ($600);

(3) Cover part of the artist fees; 

(4) Prepare advertising materials ($500);
(5) Cover the expenses for a lighting designer and stage manager ($600);

 
If you can't attend the event or make a financial contribution, you can help us by:

Spreading the word to others who may be able to support us. Indiegogo has tools that make it easy to share our campaign within your networks.

What is important to us:

Each in our own way, we hold a passion for exploring the new meanings and relevance of traditional practices in our contemporary world - here, in our new home - thousands of miles away from our homeland. On a professional level, we look for interdisciplinary links between music and literature, between rhythm and narrative; on a personal level, we see as a vital mission to share the artistic expression of our homeland with our new home; to help young Bulgarians build a connection to their parents' roots; to link closer the Bulgarian and the American community through the power of art.

About us:

Elissaveta Iordanova, the creative director of the project, is a dance artist and a choreographer with professional experience and in-depth knowledge of Bulgarian folkloric heritage. She is the artistic director of "Gorana Jr." -"Hristo Botev" Bulgarian School in New York and GORANA DANCE ensemble - uniting several generations of Bulgarian and American dancers around the captivating power of traditional folklore music and dance. 

Polya Brandoff, the project manager, is a teacher of Bulgarian language and literature, and a Ph.D. Candidate in Socio-cultural anthropology. She studies present day Bulgarian national identity among the youth, as it is refracted through the prism of traditional practices and current socio-political discourses.   

Thank you sincerely!
