story:
Short Summary

Twin Alchemy Collective is dedicated to creating bold, innovative new theatre.  We approach topics we wish to explore with a genuine spirit of curiosity.   We aren't afraid to take risks in experimenting with new forms--specifically, the best form to tell the story, whether that be something no one has ever done before, or that we've just never tried before.  We seek to create visceral performances, and to engage with our audience more immediately and intimately.  Above all, we strive to work with great precision and intentionality to craft every detail and moment with great care and specificity.  

                                               

                                    


Here's what some people had to say about our first production, Little Mother:

http://texaslifestylemag.com/best-plays-of-2013-10-6/  

^Austin Lifestyle Magazine Review by Ryan Johnson (We're referred to as "Cruel Company" here because I hadn't settled on a name yet.)

http://tinyurl.com/lz5nnbn

^ Central Texas Live Theatre Review by Michael Meigs

What We Need  


Where your money goes:
    
venues $1,650
sets $1,500
31+ costumes $1,000
Non-Profit Fees $500
Rental Euipment  $350

We're really asking for significantly less than we need.  Don't get me wrong, $5,000 will go a long, long way towards covering most of our expenses.  Even so, I will still end up spending $2,000-$3,000 of our ticket sales or my own money to pay for everything in the chart below.   If we exceed our goal, the surplus will still be paying for the essentials.  


What we'll still need :   
compensating artists  $1,000
posters and advertising  $750
Indiegogo fees $500
Props  $400
Misc. $250
 
What You Get

I wanted to create a service-based campaign, as a way to give back to the community for supporting me and the rest of Twin Alchemy. That means not offering you an "autographed" copy of something or another (I'm sure you don't want that, and its value will only depreciate), and really trying to just do something useful for you to earn your contribution.  

 As someone who graduated with a B.A. in Theatre and English, I've had to cobble together a bunch of skills (such as embroidering various breeds of dogs and writing a compelling online dating profile), but also I've gotten really good at making myself useful as a personal assistant, which I've been doing full-time for two years now while in grad school, and quite enjoy. I'd be happy to provide you current and past references, should you want to hire me for a few hours on a weekend, and if there's something you want to know if I can do, just ask first.

Another reason I wanted to do a service-oriented campaign was to get to you know you better.  By you, I mean the Austin theatre community.  I've only been in Austin for three years, and even though this is home now, I probably only know your name and know of your work.  So allow me to introduce myself: Hi, I'm Katie, I'm here, and I look forward to working with and amongst you, as well as seeing your work.  Please let me know how I can help, and engage with you and the larger community.  If you see me around town, please introduce yourself.  I'm a shy extrovert, so I probably won't initiate, but I'll be very happy if you do.

In addition to the service-oriented perks, here are a couple samples of my free-hand cross-stitching skills in the "Cross(stitch) my heart" level:

^ This was gift to my bf on Valentine's Day

Parker (pug) (RIP), Mashti (pug), Shawn, Me, and Mabel (cat)

      More dog portraits (cocker spaniel and an old lab).  

^ This was a gift to my boss for Christmas.


The Impact

Why should you consider donating even if you don't live in Austin?

If these productions are something you'd like to see, but you don't live in Austin, by all means share this campaign with a theatre company in your city whom you feel would be a good fit.  If you're a theatre director outside of Austin, and would like to read scripts, or discuss logistics, please let's get in touch! (katiegreen444@gmail.com)

I've had my plays produced in Indiana, Chicago, and New York, and would love to continue to push my work out into the rest of the world.  I'm especially interested in working with theatre persons (or non-theatre, but interested persons) in adapting the text-based adventure project for specific communities.

There are a million people blowing up my newsfeed with their crowd-funding campaigns right now

I know, I know.  But...to my knowledge, (and please, correct me if I'm wrong) the text-based, site-specific adventure game, is the only production of its kind anywhere.  I know there are a few scavenger-hunt productions, but none (to my knowledge) are strongly narrative-driven, incorporate many types of technology, including interactive text programming and video diaries, span all across a city (not just a neighborhood), and can be experienced individually over the course of a month.  I truly believe this has never been done before.  I'm also almost certain that Charles Fort and hard determinism have never been deeply explored on the stage or screen.


    Other Ways You Can Help

    If you're unable to contribute financially, we completely understand, but there are other ways to help.  We would be extremely grateful if you would consider reposting or blogging our campaign on social media sites.  That is no small favor, truly.

  and advertising 
$750 


Indiegogo
  fees
$500 


Props 
$400 


Misc.
$250
  

 What You Get

I wanted to create a service-based campaign, as a way to give back to the community for supporting me and the rest of Twin Alchemy. That means not offering you an "autographed" copy of something or another (I'm sure you don't want that, and its value will only depreciate), and really trying to just do something useful for you to earn your contribution.  
 As someone who graduated with a B.A. in Theatre and English, I've had to cobble together a bunch of skills (such as embroidering various breeds of dogs and writing a compelling online dating profile), but also I've gotten really good at making myself useful as a personal assistant, which I've been doing full-time for two years now while in grad school, and quite enjoy. I'd be happy to provide you current and past references, should you want to hire me for a few hours on a weekend, and if there's something you want to know if I can do, just ask first.
Another reason I wanted to do a service-oriented campaign was to get to you know you better.  By you, I mean the Austin theatre community.  I've only been in Austin for three years, and even though this is home now, I probably only know your name and know of your work.  So allow me to introduce myself: Hi, I'm Katie, I'm here, and I look forward to working with and amongst you, as well as seeing your work.  Please let me know how I can help, and engage with you and the larger community.  If you see me around town, please introduce yourself.  I'm a shy extrovert, so I probably won't initiate, but I'll be very happy if you do.
In addition to the service-oriented perks, here are a couple samples of my free-hand cross-stitching skills in the "Cross(stitch) my heart" level:

^ This was gift to my bf on Valentine's DayParker (pug) (RIP), Mashti (pug), Shawn, Me, and Mabel (cat)


      More dog portraits (cocker spaniel and an old lab).  
^ This was a gift to my boss for Christmas.

The Impact
 Why should you consider donating even if you don't live in Austin?
If these productions are something you'd like to see, but you don't live in Austin, by all means share this campaign with a theatre company in your city whom you feel would be a good fit.  If you're a theatre director outside of Austin, and would like to read scripts, or discuss logistics, please let's get in touch! (katiegreen444@gmail.com)
I've had my plays produced in Indiana, Chicago, and New York, and would love to continue to push my work out into the rest of the world.  I'm especially interested in working with theatre persons (or non-theatre, but interested persons) in adapting the text-based adventure project for specific communities.
There are a million people blowing up my newsfeed with their crowd-funding campaigns right now
I know, I know.  But...to my knowledge, (and please, correct me if I'm wrong) the text-based, site-specific adventure game, is the only production of its kind anywhere.  I know there are a few scavenger-hunt productions, but none (to my knowledge) are strongly narrative-driven, incorporate many types of technology, including interactive text programming and video diaries, span all across a city (not just a neighborhood), and can be experienced individually over the course of a month.  I truly believe this has never been done before.  I'm also almost certain that Charles Fort and hard determinism have never been deeply explored on the stage or screen.

  

Other Ways You Can Help

 If you're unable to contribute financially, we completely understand, but there are other ways to help.  We would be extremely grateful if you would consider reposting or blogging our campaign on social media sites.  That is no small favor, truly.

story:
New Light In Brief

In a little over a year, New Light Theater Project has produced numerous events and productions including three FREE shows and two new musicals.  We've been the recipient of fellowships and awards.  We've worked in London, we're heading to Chicago, we believe in collaboration, and that includes working with you.

Why We Need Your Help

Our upcoming season is filled with a diverse program of shows, including:

-The Darkroom Series

-SIDD (World-premiere in Chicago)

-Our world-premiere production from Resident Playwright Ross Howard, which is currently running for FREE in Manhattan.

Free?  Manhattan?  Those words don't go together very often.  But we believe in producing top-quality shows that are accessible to as many people as possible.

  • Space rental, artist fees, press and marketing, and design elements add up. 
  • With your contributions, you can join us as VIP guests to our parties with our Darkroom Series and Fall Gala.
  • FOR MORE INFORMATION, VISIT: NewLightTheaterProject.com

           

Risks & Challenges

The most difficult challenge we foresee is maintaining a long-term effort to provide
affordable theater to the community.

Fundraising is a constant and humbling experience-- But know that every penny you donate will be put to good use.  Even if you miss a show, you can see the impact of our performances and events on our website and through social media.

           

Please consider making a tax-deductible contribution to New Light Theater Project

We are fiscally sponsored by Fractured Atlas, which allows us to accept tax-deductible donations, in-kind gifts, and sponsorships.

  • If you would like to be a corporate sponsor or provide in-kind gifts, we happily accept them.  Contact Michael Aguirre at maguirre450@gmail.com for more details.

story:
The Artist's Laboratory Theatre is developing "Found Fayetteville", a show for Last Night, the New Year's Eve celebration at the square in downtown Fayetteville. The show is comprised of "found" text, and is a multi-media, reader's theatre, a "giddy and gutsy" experience- all happening in a giant sheet fort! Our venue for the evening will be Kathy P. Thompson's studio, and is just one of many performances taking places in alternative venues around the square. 



As you know, Fayetteville's comic darling, Christy Hall, has recently moved to New York to pursue a career in comedy and theatre. BUT WE WANT HER BACK.   Please help us bring her back for the New Year's shows! Not only is she performing with The Artist's Lab, she is a part of the musical comedy duo, Black and Tan, and will perform a set at The Mustacheâ€“a boutique being converted in a "comedy club" for the evening. Please help us bring back an original and beloved company member of The Artist's Laboratory Theatre. She is gut busting funny, and it only seems right to ring in the New Year with Fayetteville's sweetheart, Christy Hall. 




We need just $650 to fly Christy in from New York. This will cover the cost of that incredibly costly ticket from New York to Northwest, AR during the holiday season. It is normally a pretty expensive ticket, but this will be the highest we have paid yet! Yikes! We really can't do it without some help!

If you help us with the cost by donating, we will give you tickets to the next sheet fort show! We are sure "Found Fayetteville" will be remounted early next year. The show is going to want to have "legs". Trust me, it's a good one. 



Please share this campaign with others through facebook or email. Every little bit adds up!

story:
Hi there!!!!!

     My name is Greg Blackmon and I'm a dancer with the Eisenhower Dance Ensemble in Detroit, MI. I moved here from New York after training at The Ailey School and Dance Theatre of Harlem over the span of 2 years, while dancing with three professional companies and a student collective. I was offered a job with EDE in June, during which time I was at a point of financial instability. I took the job because I liked the repertory we learned in the audition as well as some of the things I saw when I researched the company. I also figured that I could spend the time that I had in Michigan saving up the money to get back to New York and dance with one of the many companies there that I aspire to be a part of. However, living in Michigan isn't what I thought it would be, as well as working with this company. It's a great company but I don't think it's right for me. I haven't been able to save up the money to get back because most of my money goes towards bills and incendentals like groceries and dance clothes. The little bit that I have has to be divided between paying my taxes and paying my student loans back starting in June.

     This campaign is not just a matter of me getting back to a place where the work is more suitable for me. It's also a matter of me getting home. I didn't know what a real home was until I got to New York and got to be around other artists like myself. And the energy there is easily the most vibrant, inspiring thing in the world. I was raised in a place that wasn't very inspiring, where I felt alienated most of the time because I knew I didn't belong there. I belong in New York. My home. I learned so much while I was there and I need to get back to the peace that I found there.

 

The "Hard" Part:

     In order to rent a room or sublet an apartment, pay for workshops/audition fees, and pay for transportation, I'm only trying to raise between $2500 and $3000 dollars. The rest I can take care of once I find a job. I plan on asking my old managers at Aeropostale if they can re-hire me for the summer, as well as applying to a wide array of restaurants in the city. I'm determined to get back home. 

     I know that I won't have trouble finding a job in dance or anywhere else once I get there. I'm experienced, determined, intelligent, quick and very good with people. I will do everything in my power to stay.

     In the unfortunate event that I do not reach my goal by the time I'm hoping to, I  still plan to do as many workshops and auditions as I can afford. I still plan to find at least one other job to provide myself with a significant enough income. And I definitely plan to keep writing as many people as I can to ask for help because this is one of those times when I really need it. 

     This project will be of such great impact not just to me but to those who help. You get to smile with pride saying that you helped someone's dreams come true. You would be the reason for someone being whole again and growing tremendously as a person through all the things they would learn. There's so much that New York has to offer, some of which I've experienced, but most of which I haven't yet. In such a short amount of time there, I managed to dance with three professional companies, two student companies, spend time at two of the best dance schools in the world, and network and connect with artists who are untouchable to most people. Imagine what I can do by setting my roots in the home I didn't know until I got there. Imagine the beauty that I and my colleagues could create and thrust upon this world.

Imagine.

 

 

If for any reason you can't contribute to my campaign PLEASE do help spread the word about it. I'm determined to make this work!!! I'd greatly appreciate it. And I greatly appreciate you.

 

Greg. :-)

story:
Artists Lynn Lane, Catalina Molnari and Toni Valle bring to life through movement and visual art the essence of survivors.

They ask, "Help Us Bring Regifting Lions to life."

ReGifting Lions gives a voice to people who are traumatized and have to create a new life after the trauma. Often viewed as raw and uncomfortable, survivors of cancer, addiction and other traumas learn to hide their discomfort for the benefit of others.   Addressing the issues of survivors in a unique way, Regifting Lions highlights the shame of illness and the desire to hide it, the urgency to connect with others, and the ability of survivors to recreate life after the trauma.  By addressing these issues in an artistic outlet, we hope to shed light on a problem of societal acceptance - no one wants to talk about cancer and chronic illness, or death of an overdose or suicidal depression, but they happen.  Regifting Lions explores the people left behind - these unique people's desire to live -– the willingness to unearth and heal traumatic events and the ability to reshape their lives.

From Lynn, Catalina, and Toni, “We are all well-known artists in our own right.  We are also intimately connected with the trials of trauma.   Lynn is a cancer survivor.  Toni is a 20 year sober alcoholic.  Catalina is connected to people in recovery.  We are combining our artistic voices, our histories, and our experiences in recovery and survivorship, to produce an intimate look at the healing process.  A healing process that involves life, laughter, and love.”

For more information on the choreographers, visits regiftinglions.info

Original music score composed by George Heathco.

In order to begin production of Regifting Lions, we need $7500 to pay a cast of six dancers, the composer, the lighting designer, costume designer and theatre rental.  This $7500 is two thirds of our actual budget.

No amount is too small - even $10 will help us reach or goal.  We understand not everyone can help financially, but you can help us by spreading the word.  Share this campaign, share our website, share our facebook page.  While donations are essential, having people come see the show is important too!   IF you like Regifting Lions, pass it along!

With Love,

Lynn, Catalina, and Toni

story:
Random Acts of Shakespeare by the Wilderness Wildlings

The salon:collective invites you to be part of a brave and feisty immersive theatre production and short film bringing Shakespeare’s texts to life in London this summer.

What’s happening and why?

A troupe of actors will perform short scenes, monologues and sonnets for the general public over the weekend of 17th/18th August 2013 at various locations across London.

The general public will also be invited to perform individual lines of sonnets to camera (guided by a director).  These will be edited together to create a short film of the experience and final output.

Sonnets are the 16th-century equivalent of sharing links and photos.  The urge to contain feelings and thoughts in small potent packages has endured, as much as the timeless themes of love, desire, despair and sexual attraction contained within them.

We will challenge misconceptions about a household name; engaging the local community and the general public to experience how Shakespeare is as relevant to us all now, as much as it was then; letting people know it’s not something they have to take too seriously!

We’d love you to be part of this.

So, what’s the salon:collective?

the salon:collective is a community of interdisciplinary artists  based at The Cockpit in London but we get around, to Laura Marling's Secret Music and the floating Pirate Radio Party on the Thames as well as London's oldest music hall, where we staged a family-friendly Twelfth Night last Christmas. As well as training actors, we create events, from a wake-up call for clubbers to a Midsummer Night's Dream themed picnic in Regent's Park.

Most recently, we’ve been taking our performances of the sonnets to Secret Music and a celebration for the literacy charity Beanstalk, and are shortly to perform at Wilderness Festival. 

What are we asking for?

Sponsors to contribute the modest sum of £800

…and what’s in it for you?

We’re passionate about what we do and like to have fun doing it.  We strive for this to be clear in our work. We reach out beyond the traditional theatre audience, to the immediate community and to everyone who enjoys London in the summer.

Supporting us will communicate these shared values.

Check out our perks to see how you and/or your organisation could get involved.

More details:

We’ll be producing a short documentary film about making Shakespeare more accessible to audiences through immersive performances and getting members of the public performing lines of Shakespeare to camera.

The locations will include:

  • St. Marylebone Church Market
  • Marylebone High Street
  • Church Street Market
  • Victoria Embankment Gardens

The Performance

- Performances of short scenes from Shakespeare 

- Sonnets, performed individually and in sonnet-offs between actors

- Members of the public performing (with direction) individual lines of sonnets to camera

The filming 

This documentary short film will show how Shakespeare can be rude, relevant, accessible and fun.

It will show members of the local community and general public (with help from a director) performing individual lines of sonnets to camera.

Also, our resident Shakespeare expert will be interviewed about Shakespeare saying why he is still as relevant today as 400 years ago.

story:
Upward Spiral Theatre is a brand new company, founded in January 2013, and is producing its very first project this August, as part of the Victoria 2013 Fringe Festival. This premiere project is a revival of the original work Negative Colours. The company is comprised of an inspiring and dedicated group of emerging artists, including people who are in the Theatre program at the University of Victoria, the Canadian College of Performing Arts, and are actively involved in the Victoria theatre community. We are looking for donors to help us establish our production budget. We are seeking an opportunity to workshop a play and learn from each other, and believe that we can give of this production to our audience this summer.


    We will use all of our funding to go towards costs for items such as properties, costumes, and furniture for the set, expenses for rehearsal space, and marketing and promotional costs. Based on our estimated budget, we are asking for a total of $500 to come from individual donors. With your contribution, we will thank you on our social media. Larger donations will also include complementary tickets and a thank you in our program. The $500 donation will also include a dinner for two made by our very own stage manager.

    When you make your contribution to our work, you will be a part of nurturing a new theatre company that hopes to grow and integrate in Victoria theatre. Upward Spiral Theatre’s mandate is to provide emerging artists with the opportunity to workshop and produce new plays. Your donation to us will help to make that happen.

    If you are unable to contribute financially, but still want to be of great assistance to us, you can help us out by making use of the share tool on this Indiegogo site. Tell your friends about the show, and most importantly be sure to come out and see it at the festival that runs August 22-September 1, 2013.
    

    Thank you for your support!

story:
UNITY 1918 by Kevin Kerr won the Governor General Award, Canada’s most prestigious literary award, in 2002. It has not yet enjoyed a professional production in the U.S. Project: Theater’s last production, OCCUPATION, focused on the lives of those inhabiting a refugee camp, zeroing on the choices that the women made to stay alive. This next project continues in this vein, giving space for voices that are often overlooked during and after a military conflict.

Set in Unity, a small community in rural Canada during the fall of 1918, this play focuses on a mysterious and deadly plague that swept through the world. Commonly known as the Spanish Flu, this phenomenon, in its own way, brought the terror, the panic, the horror and the sense of helplessness of the Great War home with returning soldiers.*

The central character, Beatrice, is a young girl who gets catapulted into a sea of responsibilities. From her diary entries and interactions with the town, we see Beatrice transition from a young girl to a woman discovering her capacity for survival. Boasting an eclectic array of characters, from a fifteen year old mortician to a blind soldier returning from the war, this play has the unique ability to point out the small and often forgotten horrors of life in 1918. Kerr manages to create a haunting and surprisingly funny world where fresh corpses fart and young ladies manage to fall in love knowing their lives may end within the month. Kevin Kerr offers audiences not only an epic chronicle of this forgotten chapter of Canadian history, but a chilling preview of the beginnings of our own new century.

*More people died of this epidemic than had been killed in battle throughout the armed conflict, between 50-100 million.

WHAT WE NEED

$10,700 will pay for the rental of the Gene Frankel Theatre for a 3 week run.

$17,500 will allow us to pay our actors, stage manager, and press agent.

$24,000 will cover the cost of the entire show.

THE DIRECTOR

KJ SANCHEZ 

KJ has been a fan of Project: Theater for a long time. She has been a fan of this play, Unity 1918 for a very long time, too. So she’s thrilled to bring two of her favorite things together. KJ’s a playwright and runs American Records, her own theater company and directs. She works all over the country – The Goodman in Chicago, Milwaukee Rep, Berkeley Rep, Studio Theatre in DC and Cincinnati Playhouse in the Park, to name a few. She rarely gets to work in her own back yard, here in New York City, so this is a real treat for her.

www.americanrecords.com

ABOUT PROJECT: THEATER

We believe that the sharing of creativity leads to a healthier, happier, stronger and more compassionate society. By cultivating an environment that encourages artists from all fields to challenge their skills and talents, we build a haven for innovative growth and achievement. By focusing on work that is new or forgotten we provide entertaining, exciting, and engaging productions. By composing events that explore the performer/audience relationship we constantly endeavor to build theatrical experiences which encourage the growth of social unity.

PRODUCTION HISTORY

Since 2004, Project: Theater has been noted for its innovative and dynamic productions. Ranging from forgotten classics like Archibald MacLeish’s J.B., the winner of the 1959 Pulizter Prize for drama and the Tony Award for best play, to ushering in seven world premieres, Project: Theater consistently places the performer/audience relationship at the heart of its productions.

While championing new work and forgotten classics, Project: Theater also endeavors to find plays that resonate with New York audiences. Project: Theater was honored to produce the New York premiere of Naomi Izuki’s Language of Angels, and sold out crowds raved over the company’s adaptation of My Custom Van, a book of comedic essays by Michael Ian Black. Shel’s Shorts by Shel Silverstein and The Secretaries by The Five Lesbian Brothers explored satirical comedy that ripples through many of Project: Theater shows.

In 2011, Project: Theater’s world premiere production of Ken Ferrigni’s cyber-thriller MANGELLA was ranked in the top 10 Off-Off Broadway plays by PaperMag and was called “a virtual LOL hoot” by the New York Post. Most recently, Artistic Director Joe Jung teamed up with Mr. Ferrigni to produce the new dark comedy, OCCUPATION, which ran at TBG Theatre in midtown Manhattan and was described by New York Magazine as a “powerful, insightful, cynical and timely take on survival. It gets an A!” and was ranked among the “50 Things to Do in NYC This Weekend.” For five years, Project: Theater has composed a night of site specific theater each month. With no “fourth wall,” OUR BAR is best described as a month’s worth of bar antics artfully shoved into one hour, and like any great night out on the town, each show is unique. With roughly twenty-five contributing artists for each performance, OUR BAR has provided a venue for hundreds of New York actors and writers to hone their craft.

story:
Applied Mechanics is a theater company based in Philadelphia.

We make plays that you can walk through, whole worlds for audiences to explore, with multiple intersecting storylines for them to choose how to watch.


Since 2009, Applied Mechanics has been making theater and food together.

We feed our audiences in our shows,
we feed each other at every rehearsal,
and we feed our neighbors, colleagues, and anyone who wants to come eat at our free Community Dinners.

Food has always been an integral part of our process.
And in our next show - FEED - we are making it the focus of the performance.

Where do recipes come from?
How do meals connect us to history, diaspora, and geography?
How can food connect us to people we've never met, continents or centuries away?
How does the information encoded in a seed teach us to coexist on this planet?

Donate today and help us cook up a play you can eat, as well as watch. 

Help us bring FEED to the table!

FEED
by Applied Mechanics
at the Painted Bride Art Center
September 2016
part of the Philadelphia FringeArts Festival

  • Applied Mechanics is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of Applied Mechanics must be made payable to Fractured Atlas only and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

story:
Given the current state of the world, we decided that exploring how we decide, form opinions and change or don’t change our minds is essential to understand.  So, we gave four playwrights and four scientists the task of collaborating on creating four original plays on that topic.

Each evening, following the plays  one of the scientists kick of a conversation in which the audience can respond to the issues raised in the plays.  As Cady Stanton, one of our scientists from 2013 Thought Experiments said:

"What the play gave to the conversation was realism, an emotional component....You can talk about something all you want, but people don’t understand until they also feel and experience it."

We are asking for your help to fund the Experiments.

Our $1,500 goal will be devoted entirely to paying our artists: playwrights, actors, directors and designers. 

And as our way of thanking you, please accept one of the perks listed on the right.

Thank you for helping us save the world through science and theatre!

 

Thought Experiments opens on Friday, October 13th at the Ethnic Cultural Theatre, University of Washington and plays through October 15th. 

 

Our plays this year are:

“Pay Attention” by Pamela Hobart Carter with

Geoffrey Boynton, PhD, Professor of Psychology, University of Washington

Directed by Rachel Rene

 

“Hannigan Squee, Department P” by Elizabeth Heffron with

Stacia Dreyer, PhD, Post Doctoral Scholar, School of Marine & Environmental Affairs, UW

Directed by Kathryn Stewart

 

“The Unlikely Valley” by Scotto Moore with

David Gire, PhD, Assistant Professor of Psychology, University of Washington

Directed by Jane Ryan

 

“Words for Snow” by K. Brian Neel with

Chantel Prat, PhD, Professor of Psychology, University of Washington

Directed by Jon Lutyens

story:
The what now...?

Our mission at Made it Ma! is to bring contemporary, significant plays from the global arena, to the stage in Vancouver. Our aim is to keep theatre alive and fresh for the modern generation by presenting an experience from the moment our audience members enter the building, complete with an entertaining show that breaks the rules and entices the viewer.

We have enlisted theatre veteran, Aaron Craven (Artistic Director - Mitch and Murray Productions) to helm our first project, as Director. The play, 'Bull' by award-winning playwright Mike Bartlett, is a savage, acid-tongued new work from one of the UK's most exciting and inventive young writers. Razor sharp and blackly comic, Bull is a savage and insightful play about office politics or playground bullying, depending which side you're on. Genuinely thrilling, daring and inventive, acclaimed playwright Bartlett probes the dark side of the modern workplace. He has been dubbed 'The British Mamet' for his deliberate, pointed and darkly humorous writing.'

'There is no relief, no escape. This is a riveting and really uncomfortable 55 minutes.' Susannah Clapp - The Guardian

'It is queasily entertaining... Keeps its adrenaline level high and, at the very end, raises it off the charts.' Ben Brantley - The New York Times

'...this play’s message couldn’t feel more urgent.' Alice Seville - Time Out London

With a great cast, a killer story and a favourite venue, this production promises to be vicious, hilarious and best of all, unapologetic in its playfulness and purpose. But we need your help - and Vancouver needs this show to awaken it from it's wintry January slumber. Read on friends!

Top L - R: Kate Isaac, Paul Barton. Bottom L - R : Ryan Hesp, John Prowse,         Dir. Aaron Craven

 

Something for something!

To get the show off its feet, we need to raise $2,000 - $3,000. It's not a huge mountain of funds, but a necessary injection to make the show a possibility. This amount will cover the rental of the theatre, royalties and technical fees.

Perks for donating include listings in our playbill and social media, complimentary tickets to opening night performance and reception, ad space in our playbills and much more! Business operators and those wanting to raise awareness of a specific cause can receive promotion across all of our materials, where it will be viewed by thousands of people.

Should we raise the necessary funding, we will commence production of 'Bull' and will open January 24th at Studio 1398 on Granville Island, Vancouver. And what a show it will be! Lively, dark and witty, audiences are in for a treat.

If we don't raise the full amount, we'll go ahead with 'Bull' on the funds received and see what magic we can make happen!

 

What else?

Friends, we implore you, please share this campaign around on all platforms.  The more eyes that see this campaign, the closer we will be to raising our goal amount.

Thank you for your time and generosity. We can't wait to see you in January!
The crew at Made it Ma!.

story:
In short/En bref

Bonjour!

My name is Manon Gage, and I am French-American actress, currently in my third year of training at the Juilliard School in New York City. This year, I am producing Molière's Tartuffe, one of my all-time favorite plays, as a student-initiated project. Eleven acting students and four historical performance musicians here at Juilliard have been collaborating since August 2016 with faculty members Mark Olsen (director), Michelle DiBucci (music director), and Darryl Quinton (choreographer) to bring this great classic to life in December 2016.

Molière, working under the tolerant protection of Louis XIV, wrote successful Renaissance satires with great panache. These plays are easily accessible to modern audiences due to their focus on universal human foibles which transcend the world of 17th century France. Perhaps his best work, Tartuffe is hysterically funny and gorgeously poetic, as well as being bitingly anti-establishment (it is a play that his close contemporary, Shakespeare, would have been prevented from staging in Puritan London.) Openly mocking the clergy or, more specifically the “pharisees” operating under the guise of religion to advance their own often sinister agendas, Tartuffe is as applicable today across religions, nations and communities as it was in 1664.

We are extremely thankful to have received a $500 grant from the Juilliard School, which covers honorariums to our director, stage manager and musicians. However, that still leaves us needing to pay for $1600 worth of production elements, namely set pieces, props, costumes, and lights rented from the Juilliard School's production department. We need your help! Please give whatever you can to help us put on this wonderful play. If you cannot contribute, you can still help us by getting the word out about our campaign! Please use Indiegogo's share tools or old-fashioned word of mouth.

Merci pour votre générosité!

Manon

story:
THE BEGINNING: 

I grew up in the entertainment world and at just 3 years old I knew that I wanted to be a performer. I picked up guitar at age 11 and began writing my own music by age 12. During my freshman year of high school I auditioned for the school's musical and was awarded the leading role. Ever since that moment I knew I had to be on Broadway. Musical Theatre is my passion and calling. I could not imagine doing anything else. 

I went to college for a couple years and was trained in different acting styles, as well as really honing in on my musical craft. Now, I have returned to Los Angeles to focus on pursuing my dreams of performing and my next step towards that dream is LA's Next Great Stage Star. 

THE COMPETITION:

I auditioned for the competition on December 10th and receive rave reviews by the directors, producers, and choreographers. I was accepted into the competition and I could not be more excited or blessed by this opportunity. In the competition I will be judged by a live audience and an overall nearly two dozen member panel of LA musical theatre’s most dynamic creatives forces. If I win I will be awarded representation by a talent agent as well as a cash prize. The competition will also expose me to other producers and agents (Walt Disney Parks, The Center Theatre Group, Musical Theatre West, and more). An average of 50% of contestants get signed to a talent agent through this competition. Not to mention, I will be learning and growing in a way that only a competition and exposure like this can help me. 

HOW YOU CAN HELP: 

I need $600 to participate in the competition. This will cover my vocal lessons and other amenities for the competition. It will all be worth it when I complete this competition and win or lose, I will gain a ton of experience, knowledge, and talent representation. 

THANK YOU!

Thank you so much for your consideration and I hope you find it in your heart to invest in a dream that is on it's way to becoming reality. God bless you!

story:
We are three creative individuals who have just put together our own companies, Lilian and Paul, who you can see in the attached video, are the dancers that form Dance Company Callous Affection, based in Brighton and they have both just graduated Cornwall university in a BA (hons) in Dance and Performance. Vicki, of Raxeira Productions is a freelance videographer and director, she has known Lilian since childhood and worked with both of them on multiple occasions, most notably she shot, directed and edited the 'Nym - et Moi' video seen here. Vicki is based in Scotland travels between Edinburgh and London in pursuit of creative endeavours frequently.

Our Campaign is basically just to raise funds for travel and wardrobe to give our video another edge, we believe this video will be both beautiful and entertaining and would love to share our creative expression with the world. It would mean so much to us to know that we have the support of people who wish to continue the ever diminishing funding for arts in this country. Helping us reach this very small amount will give a whole new element to this video in the way that we can really portray our Japanese influence through wardrobe and makeup and we can shoot in our ideal location, in a studio in Scotland.

Our funding breakdown is very simple, we need around £75 per person for a travel allowance, there are three of us, we need a wardrobe budget of £150 - £200, a food budget and if we have anything left over we would like to hire some new lenses.

We are a little bit weird and wonderful, Lillian and Paul have such an amazing choreography portfolio and Vicki specialises visuals, mainly natural light and dark aesthetics. We are so excited to be shooting in Scotland where we have access to rope swings and a large space to create whatever we want! 

At a time where we define ourselves as part of a mass, most of them some what evil - 'Before I move off' focusses in on the individual, and explores the intricacy of human interaction. It reminds us of why it is we should still celebrate the beauty behind the wickedness that seems to surround us at this time.

Please don't hesitate to have a look at our portfolios to which we will provide links and have a look at our previous collaboration, this video was done with no budget and we feel it is a strong representation of our style but would love to have the opportunity to push our boundaries further than before!

If you cant contribute but like the sound of our project please share us through anyway you can, facebook, instagram, even email some folks you think might like the sound of it, if you'd like to see a great example of innovative dance and full creative freedom on all sides of the board spread the word!

Lilian's Facebook- https://www.facebook.com/LilianDAvoiceandmoveme...

Vicki's Facebook- https://www.facebook.com/pg/VickiEvansPhotograp...

Please don't hesitate to have a look at our portfolios to which we will provide links and have a look at our previous collaboration, this video was done with no budget and we feel it is a strong representation of our style but would love to have the opportunity to push our boundaries further than before!
If you cant contribute but like the sound of our project please share us through anyway you can, facebook, instagram, even email some folks you think might like the sound of it, if you'd like to see a great example of innovative dance and full creative freedom on all sides of the board spread the word!
Lilian's Facebook- https://www.facebook.com/LilianDAvoiceandmoveme...
Vicki's Facebook- https://www.facebook.com/pg/VickiEvansPhotograp...

story:
A Message from the Artistic Director:

Welcome to Theater UnCorked, a journey 40 years in the making!
After many years of performing on some of the best Professional and Community stages of New England and working with so many talented individuals, I am thrilled to announce the debut of Theater UnCorked. 

As many passionate artists can attest to, having an opportunity to pursue creative projects that sing to us and work with individuals we highly respect is a dream come true. If I were to sum up Theater UnCorked’s main vision in one word it would be, “Collaboration”. Theater UnCorked will be a true collaboration from start to finish. There is no better inspiration than working with those that inspire us. From "Pop Up" one-day musical events, to work-shopping new pieces, Staged Readings, Comedies, Dramas and Theater Camps for young adults.  Our goal is to produce works that not only audiences can appreciate but that we, as artists, feel passionate about performing. 

I am truly honored and humbled to invite you on this wonderful journey as we produce our premiere production in June, "Sweeney Todd in Concert", a one night only, "Pop-Up Musical". Attend this tale if you dare and you won't regret it! Here's to 2018 and Uncorking the endless artistic possibilities! Cheers!

Shana Dirik
Producing Artistic Director
Theater UnCorked

story:
Short Summary

East Texas meets New York as UNSPEAKABLE PRODUCTIONS is proud to present TALL PINES LODGE as part of the 20th annual New York International Fringe Festival - FringeNYC. 

Texas writer JD Graves has constructed a taut psychological drama in TALL PINES LODGE, directed by Joshua Hill with a live score. First produced at the FronteraFest Long Fringe 2006 where it was called “the most disgusting thing I’ve ever seen,” TALL PINES LODGE makes its New York premiere with an all new cast.  

Set deep in the Piney Woods of East Texas, TALL PINES LODGE is a claustrophobic pulp thriller that shatters the notion of honor among thieves. The play opens with JOE ED (Conor Andrew Hall) and BOOKER (Ryan Scoble), bankrobbers awaiting their cut of the score and the arrival of the mysterious MR. VALENTINE (Brian Detlefts). When Booker’s brother, the psychopathic COTTON (Titus Tompkins), arrives they get more than they bargained for in the form of DAISY (Jehan O. Young), Cotton’s impromptu hostage. 

Tall Pines Lodge brings together long time collaborators Joshua Hill and JD Graves for the first time in over a decade to mount the New York premiere of Graves's pulp thriller.


Meet the Cast

Conor Andrew Hall (Joe Ed) was born and raised in Michigan and received a BFA from Central Michigan University. Tall Pines Lodge marks his New York stage debut.


Titus Tompkins (Cotton) Recent credits include The Waterman (Ars Nova), Phantom Pains (Under St. Mark’s Theater), Wet Glitter (IRT), R&J: Star Cross’d Deathmatch, and TV Land’s Younger. He currently writes and plays music with The Rusty Guns and the Good Morning Nags. Titus holds an MFA in Acting from American Conservatory Theatre in San Francsico. He is a proud member of Actor's Equity.


Jehan O. Young (Daisy) has performed at HERE Arts Center, Symphony Space, Soho Rep, JACK, Ars Nova and countless esteemed basements with working pipes and a black curtain. She has also performed internationally in the Setkani/Encounter Festival in the Czech Republic and appeared in the German Shakespeare Festival. Jehan holds an MFA in Acting from Columbia University School of the Arts and a BA from Spelman College.



Ryan Scoble (Booker) has performed in several Off-Broadway shows, including roles in Murder in the First (59E59), Mask of Medusa (Roots and Wings Theatricals), and Bitty Bear’s Matinee (American Girl Place Theatre). He also performs in concerts at The Town Hall with the Broadway by the Year Chorus, as well as directing, choreographing, and performing with the New York City Gay Men’s Chorus. He received his Bachelor’s in Vocal Performances from New York University (Musical Theatre) and is currently a Master’s Candidate in Educational Theatre at The City College of New York. He is a proud member of Actor’s Equity.


Brian Detlefs (Mr. Valentine) past regional credits include Bloody Bloody Andrew Jackson (Red House Arts Center) Trails (Spirit of Broadway Theater) and Into the Woods. (Blue Mountain Lake Center for the Arts.) Brian is also a singer song-writer who can be seen at various venues around New York City.



Meet the Creative Team

JD Graves (Playwright/Producer) is a published author and playwright. His writing credits include, "The Sweetheart Sour," (Near to the Knuckle; United Kingdom), Stanley and Jim (Manhattan Repertory Theatre), Concha Fina, (Hollins Playwright’s Lab, Roanoke, VA), Tall Pines Lodge (FronteraFest Austin, TX). He earned a BFA from Texas State University and for the last six years has taught History in Tyler, Texas. When he’s not teaching, he’s helping raise his family, and if he’s not doing either he can be found begging strangers to read his work.  

Joshua Hill (Director) is a playwright, a screenwriter and director. His plays have been performed in New York; San Francisco, California; Austin, Texas; Provincetown, Massachusetts; and New Orleans, Louisiana, among others. He holds a BA in Directing from The University of Texas at Austin and an MFA in Playwriting from Columbia University, where he mentored under Edward Albee. Mr. Hill currently lives in Manhattan with his two cats.



What We Need & What You Get

So where is the money going?

  • Marketing and Advertising

    It's tough to get butts in seats, and it's not cheap, either. We have 250 seats to sell and we can't rely on friends and family to take them all. Our budget accounts for both direct and online advertising and marketing, which will allow us to spread the word to the largest possible audience. 

  • Artist Compensation

    Everyone deserves to be paid for their hard work. While we are an Actor's Equity Showcase, we believe that you shouldn't have to be part of a Union to be paid for your time. Every artist working on our show will receive payment for their time and effort. No one is going to get rich from doing a Fringe show, but we can make sure they can buy groceries!

  • Props and Costumes

    Sometimes it's the little things that make a show. Dynamite comes in small packages and it ain't cheap! We have to clothe five actors and purchase or create dozens of props for the show, and the little things add up.

  • Sundries

    Expect the unexpected and you'll still be surprised half the time. Every day we get closer to opening there's another unexpected, unforeseen thing that crops up. Whether it is unexpected fees or having to replace a broken set piece, anything and everything can happen and we need to be prepared.
It doesn't seem like a lot, but we're currently producing the show ourselves on a shoestring budget. With rehearsal space paid for, every little bit helps and all of this money is going directly into the production of the play.
What do you get?
You get to help create art!
Not enough?
We believe that every perk should be personal, so we're taking the time to make sure that (almost) every perk is unique, personal and heartfelt. We want you to know how much you mean to us.

The Impact

Your contributions are going to make a significant impacts on our production. From helping create an immersive atmosphere on the stage to allowing our actors to feed themselves, your donations are going to be seen and felt by everyone involved.

By giving to our campaign you are not only supporting each and every one of us as artists -- a profession which we have all sacrificed deeply for -- but you are promoting a little bit of Texas in the Big Apple.

Risks & Challenges

Producing art is never a safe endeavor, and a FringeNYC show is no exception. Beyond the normal challenges of creating a piece of theatre, we are limited by the rules and restrictions of the festival. 

With your help we hope to overcome these challenges to present a tight, psychological drama that will leave the audience on the edge of their seats.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute, we totally understand! But we'd still love your help. Buy an advance ticket if you can come to our show (tickets available at www.fringenyc.org). 

You can also promote our show via social media: Twitter, Facebook, MySpace, Friendster (you remember Friendster, right?), every little bit of word of mouth helps. 

And if you don't want to do that? We also accept kind words and baked goods.

story:
About Me

Hi! I'm Xandra Schultz, 22 year old recent college graduate living in NYC. I have always been passionate about theater, and I'm so happy to share this play with the world. When I was in the worst parts of my struggle, I never thought I would get to this point in my life. I am pursuing an acting career in New York City with the support of my amazing friends and family. I love to not only act, sing, and dance - I am also passionate about writing, directing, and producing theater. This campaign means so much to me for so many reasons; it's not only a sort of catharsis for me, it's also a chance for me to cast some of my very talented friends in something that I created. It can be difficult as a twenty-something actor in New York to feel creatively fulfilled when you're getting more rejections than job offers. This is a chance for me to not only work with some of my best friends, but to also give them an opportunity to show the world how talented they truly are; and to work on something that really matters to us. 

What We Need & What You Get

I am putting this play up completely of my own volition and funding, so honestly anything helps! Renting an Off Off Broadway space for one performance can run anywhere from $250-$1000. I am currently looking for a venue that will work for all our needs, so the cost is still up in the air. Things like props, costumes, lights, sound, and people (actors and crew) cost money, too! Truly, anything helps; if you have $5 to donate, awesome. If you have $500 to donate, awesome. Anyone who donates will automatically receive a ticket to the show!

Other Ways You Can Help

Share this campaign! On facebook, instagram, myspace, whatever!

Conclusion

This play will be premiering in NYC on Saturday, October 8. Any amount of money helps, sharing this campaign on social media helps, even your kind words help! Thank you so, so much for taking the time to read all of this and for your help.

story:
About ACW Dances

ACW Dances was born in 2013 when Abigail Wallace and Kerry Doyle set out to create a new modern dance company. Founded on the idea that art should be accessible to all, we keep our ticket prices $10 with children 12 and under free. The very first performance of a 20-minute duet with live musical accompaniment was free of charge, performed in an art gallery in Alexandria, VA, where ACW Dances still performs at least yearly (still free of charge).

However, the dedication to affordable performance still has a cost. We receive a generous space and services grant from Arlington County which allows us to rehearse and perform in a lovely black box theater 1-2 times per year. In order to pay the dancers, buy costumes, hire light designers, get stage managers, and more, we need to reach out to you!

This year, it's simple.

We're keeping our 4th season light. We have a free fall performance this November in VA, a works in progress concert in DC in March, and a black box theater show also in VA in May. This allows us to ask for less money and still provide our artists with some compensation for their talent, dedication, and hard work.

Here's the breakdown for our year:

FALL:

Dancers: $700 for rehearsals and performance stipend
Artistic Director: $200

SPRING:

Dancers: $2400 rehearsal and performance stipends ($300 per dancer, 8 total)
Artistic Director: $200
Lighting Designer: $300
Stage Manager: $150
Tech Help: $150
Publicity & Marketing: $200
Props & Costumes: $200
Gels, other equipment: $100
Fees: $120

Total: $4720

We are subject to a 10% fee on all donations, so we really need $5,192 in order to fully afford this year's work. Amounts raised in excess of our goal, if any, will go toward producing future work. Should we not meet our goal, we will downscale productions throughout the year so that the money raised is able to cover our expenses.

Why help us?

Supporting us helps provide affordable art to people in all types of communities. We are unique in that we celebrate being an all-female dance company that continues to push the limits of what is possible in choreography both athletically and thematically. We also have a four-year history of success in running fundraising campaigns and of using those funds to produce critically acclaimed shows.

Our dancers include Abigail Wallace (founder and director), Paula Giammarco (4th season), Rachel Zappala (3rd season), Katherine LiPuma (2nd season), Samantha Sobash (1st season), as well as various adjunct artists that participate in periodic performances. Read all about them on Facebook and our website, plus follow ACW Dances on Twitter and Instagram for more!

Other ways to help:

If you are unable to donate, you can still make our season a success! Please share our campaign and steer other possible donors our way. Make noise so that people know we exist and that we are here to connect to the greater artistic community. DC/VA/MD locals: come to our events!

Thank you for taking the time to stop by and take a look at our project.  It is only with your help that we can produce our work.  We appreciate your consideration and generosity!  Please consider asking your employer if they participate in matching donations as this is a great way to make a larger contribution.  Our fiscal sponsor, Fractured Atlas, is able to meet all 501(c)(3) requirements for tax deduction purposes. 

ACW Dances' mission is to engage with and contribute to the community, with the vision that art should be accessible to all demographics.  Through performance of new modern dance work, collaborative projects with artists of all disciplines, and open discussions, the company aims to entertain and educate while furthering the artistic discipline of modern dance.

For more information on ACW Dances, please check out the company website!

ACW Dances is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-­profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of ACW Dances must be made payable to “Fractured Atlas” only. Any contribution above the value of the goods and services received by the donor is tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

story:
Every Dollar Helps!

A short list of what YOUR donations will help to fund:

  • Theater rental
  • Production insurance
  • Costumes
  • Props
  • Set pieces and building materials
  • Posters, Postcards, and Programs
  • Paying the actors (cause they deserve it)
  • Paying the design/tech crew (cause they really deserve it)

Okay Sure, But Who Are You?

My name is Jeff Newman. I hold a Bachelor of Fine Arts degree from Wright State University in Dayton, OH and have been producing theatre with consistency since earning my degree in 2009. I have brought professional successful productions clear through to closing night in Dayton, Kansas City, as well as Chicago.

I am also the Company Founder of Hot Shot Productions: The scrappy storefront theatre company that could! This upcoming world premier of The Chiraq Wall  will be the fourth production from HSP since our inception in 2009.

I'm no stranger to the rough and tumble world of the Chicago storefront theatre scene. Since moving here in 2011 I have written, directed, produced, and performed for several companies throughout the city. My work has been seen at City Lit, Stage 773, The Public House Theatre, Prop Thtr, The Alley Stage, The Berger Park Coach House, The Frontier, The Right Brain Project, Angel Island, as well as The Think Tank just to name a few.

Each experience has taught me to be a better all around theatre artist and it has become the personal mission of Hot Shot Productions to create an atmosphere in which artists feel free to contribute during the process and are genuinely proud of the product they've helped create.

YOU Can Make A Difference!

Chicago is the perfect community for the kind of challenging, low budget theatre experience that has become the hallmark of HSP. But no production simply falls out of the clear blue sky. It is only with your generosity, investment, and faith that we are able to deliver the quality theatre experience our audiences truly deserve. For more details on past productions, take a look at our slick new Hot Shot Productions Website!

But Dude, I'm Kinda Broke

You got no money? I can relate! But that doesn't mean you can't help:

  • You can share this campaign and video on all your social media
  • You can show the trailer video to friends and ask them  to share it too
  • You can check out our slick new Hot Shot Productions Website and share THAT TOO

All this without spending a dollar or getting up from your computer!

Believe me, it really does help.

Paying the actors (cause they deserve it)
Paying the design/tech crew (cause they really deserve it)


Okay Sure, But Who Are You?
My name is Jeff Newman. I hold a Bachelor of Fine Arts degree from Wright State University in Dayton, OH and have been producing theatre with consistency since earning my degree in 2009. I have brought professional successful productions clear through to closing night in Dayton, Kansas City, as well as Chicago.
I am also the Company Founder of Hot Shot Productions: The scrappy storefront theatre company that could! This upcoming world premier of The Chiraq Wall  will be the fourth production from HSP since our inception in 2009.
I'm no stranger to the rough and tumble world of the Chicago storefront theatre scene. Since moving here in 2011 I have written, directed, produced, and performed for several companies throughout the city. My work has been seen at City Lit, Stage 773, The Public House Theatre, Prop Thtr, The Alley Stage, The Berger Park Coach House, The Frontier, The Right Brain Project, Angel Island, as well as The Think Tank just to name a few.
Each experience has taught me to be a better all around theatre artist and it has become the personal mission of Hot Shot Productions to create an atmosphere in which artists feel free to contribute during the process and are genuinely proud of the product they've helped create.

YOU Can Make A Difference!
Chicago is the perfect community for the kind of challenging, low budget theatre experience that has become the hallmark of HSP. But no production simply falls out of the clear blue sky. It is only with your generosity, investment, and faith that we are able to deliver the quality theatre experience our audiences truly deserve. For more details on past productions, take a look at our slick new Hot Shot Productions Website!

But Dude, I'm Kinda Broke
You got no money? I can relate! But that doesn't mean you can't help:

You can share this campaign and video on all your social media
You can show the trailer video to friends and ask them  to share it too
You can check out our slick new Hot Shot Productions Website and share THAT TOO

All this without spending a dollar or getting up from your computer!
Believe me, it really does help.

story:
Our Story

Strife.tv and TheBboySpot.com, two legitimate names in the worldwide bboy dance community, would like to create three, $500 dollar scholarships for bboy / bgirl dancers attending university in USA and Canada during the Fall of 2011. The hip hop dance community needs more educated dancers. We need to expand our culture, have future leaders, and work in a more professional manner. To keep everything growing in the right direction, we will need to work with those who know our community because they are part of the community.


The Impact

Currently, many bboys finish high school and fail to consider higher education. Many pursue careers in entertainment and do not have a backup plan. These small scholarships will create awareness amongst the dance community for higher education beyond high school.


What We Need & What You Get

Please check out the "Perks" contribution segment on the right side of this form for donation pledge recommendations and rewards.  100% of all your donations will go towards the scholarship fund.


Other Ways You Can Help

please help us by spreading the word!  

Official Announcement (and to apply for the scholarship)
http://www.thebboyspot.com/forum/f8/bboy-bgirl-scholarship-the-bboy-spot-strife-tv-t3755.html

Scholarship Announcement Video 
http://youtu.be/E_mDGY-XYfI

story:
Hello, I’m one of those comedians you hear about, I’m headed to the Edinburgh Fringe this year with a surreal, abstract stand up show Matthew Highton’s Shadowed Vagary that critics will soon be calling “baffling”.


“Inspired, ridiculous, interconnected comedy gloriousness. Go catch this fella.” * * * * Three Weeks – Edinburgh


The video above explains all but basically primarily what I’m trying to do is to make people laugh and make my show/months run a success. Think of the laughter as the shark in Jaws, I'll find him for three, but I'll catch him, and kill him, for ten (monetary values not representative of show). Basically what I need is a bigger boat. If you’ve not seen Jaws don't worry, what I’d be able to do with your help is to put more money into the show, gaining more exposure/audience members, making more people laugh and make this a success.


This is where hopefully you come in.


Flyers still need printing and distributing, advertising still needs paying for and I need to ensure I have paid for somewhere to sleep and perform. I’d also like to eat for the month and possibly ward off scurvy. With your help I can make the final push, you’d have my eternal thanks and potentially a host of other goodies (see right). All money will go into the show, the bulk into advertising and any extra raised would continue to do so (likewise for if the goal is not met). For example a four week advert on the official EdFringe site costs £900 that's one advert in one place, the more I can get the better.


I’m working harder than ever which I said last year when I went up with my debut solo show and critics said this:


“Awesomely surreal… my favourite act so far this festival, it seems almost criminal that his show was free. Matthew Highton is definitely one to look out for in the future.” * * * * Three Weeks - Brighton


 “With material this solid and inventive and a genuine desire to take the comedy road less travelled, Highton is a star on the rise.” Fringe Guru


And so this year I’m putting more into it to ensure it’s bigger and better and not only that I'm doing it ll off my own back. I aim to bring an abstract style of comedy to audiences that is fresh, original and unlike what they’re used to. I’ve put in all the money I have in the world plus what I could squeeze/steal from relatives now I’m asking you, the people of this world to help me get that last little bit before I look at selling a kidney and or my identity.


All contributors are entitled to tickets to the show if you’re going to be in Edinburgh during August, you can claim these by emailing me. I’d also put your names on my website saying thanks which you can use to check spelling should you need to.


To arrange perks please email me on mhighton@me.com


Here are some links if you need more information on me.


Watch me perform:

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AiErDZ3NbEY

 

See my website:

www.matthewhighton.co.uk


By tickets to the show for friends and cherished loved ones:

http://www.edfringe.com/whats-on/comedy/matthew-highton-s-shadowed-vagary


Listen to twitter nonsense:

http://twitter.com/#!/MattHighton


All I can do now is hope you’ll put in what you can and say thank you.

story:
In 2004, one year into the Iraq war, US soldier Jeremy Hinzman walked into a small courtroom on Victoria Street in Toronto to make an extraordinary request: to become the first US refugee in Canada. Hinzman forces Canada to make a difficult decision about who we are as a country and whether to protect a soldier who refuses to fight. The Hearing of Jeremy Hinzman was created entirely from court transcripts, interviews, and media coverage.  

Foundry Theatre Company workshopped The Hearing of Jeremy Hinzman in 2010, culminating in a public reading in Kensington Market.  Two years later, writers Oonagh Duncan and Josh Bloch have been working with director Richard Greenblatt to continue to prepare the play for production.  

At a time when there are stories of arts censorship circulating, we are thrilled that SummerWorks has accepted us into the Festival. We need your help to raise funds for the artists and designers, and set, costume, and publicity costs. Any amount will assist, even as little as $10.  

Choose your level of support!

  • AWOL: $10-$25 (a shout out on Facebook and Twitter)
  • Conscientious objector: $25-$50 (a tax receipt, and your name in the program)
  • War Resister: $50-$100 (a tax receipt, your name in the program & our website)

The Hearing of Jeremy Hinzman opens an important dialogue that we as Canadians should have about who should be able to immigrate into our country, under which circumstances, and the definition of persecution that became the legal grounds for deportation of the Hinzman family.  Foundry Theatre Company (www.foundrytheatrecompany.com) has developed new Canadian work since 2007, and this is the second time we bring one of our playwrights to the stage.  

Help us tell this important story.

Help us in other ways!  

Tell your friends, and make some noise about this campaign!

story:
Short Summary

Summer Shakespeare brings free arts education programs to children and youth in Ghana. The program is entirely free for participants and is funded solely by donations from people like you. The heart of Summer Shakespeare is our vibrant volunteer community, without whom we could not do the work we do. 

What We Need & What You Get

It is extremely important that this program is  kept free, in order to keep it accessible for the general population of youth in Accra. Of course, this means that we need other people to help us pay for necessities like scripts, costumes, props, production costs, and all the other things that come with running a project like this. We also need help getting five of our teaching staff, Nikaury Roman, Kristen Lang, Grace Lazarz, Felicia Santiago & Daniella Novas, across the Atlantic so she can help out with the program on the ground.

The Impact

There is a lot of talent in Accra, and not nearly enough platforms. For young people who are interested in the performing arts, particularly theatre, there are very few opportunities to experience the performance process as a professional. This is a unique opportunity to be involved in every aspect of the play making process from start to finish, to take ownership of the most powerful tool we have: language. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Thanks for checking out our project!If you can't help directly with funding, you can still help by telling your friends, family and other contacts about us. We always need help
Please like our facebook page at: http://www.facebook.com/pages/Summer-Shakespear...
 
You can also use the sharing tools provided by IndieGoGo.com

story:
Project Summary

We are raising funds to produce:

four native midwesterners in …

MIGRATIONS

a full-length aerial performance.

Choreographed by Kristin Geneve Young in collaboration with performers Joshua Dean, Lisa Natoli, and Susie Williams. Costumes by Eric Gorsuch and atmospheric design by Grady Barker.

I am an aerial artist, choreographer, and teacher based in Brooklyn. I’ve performed with Cirque du Soleil's LOVE, Lisa’s Bright Ideas, ImaginAerial, Helium Aerial Dance, Suspended Cirque, Stephan Koplowitz, and Noemie Lafrance, among others. Having collaborated on those professional productions and created numerous solo aerial pieces over the last seven years, I am eager to further develop my ideas though my first evening-length, group work.

We have an incredible team of professional artists on board. With your help, we will be able to create the evening as we envision it – an immersive meditation on the ways we measure time, as explored through movement on both horizontal and vertical planes.

-Kristin Geneve Young

Work-in-progress preview: May 11, 2013

Performances: May 28 and June 1, 2013

 

What We Need & What You Get

Our fundraising goal of $3,795 represents the minimum cost to develop and present the work:

  • Performance space $1,275
  • Rehearsal space $720
  • Performer fees (artist-subsidized) $600
  • Costumes $600
  • Set $500
  • Marketing $100

If we do not meet the goal, we will have to find another way to raise funds. If we exceed our goal, additional income will go toward increasing artist fees and creating the best atmosphere to see the work.

Some perks for you (in addition to being an essential part of an indie art project):

  • at $10 level: acknowledgement on our list of supporters
  • at $25 level: VIP ticket to our work-in-progress preview
  • at $50 level: a photograph from the show, signed by the artists
  • at $100 level: private aerial class with Kristin
  • at $150 level: semi-private aerial class for you and a friend with Kristin
  • at $200 level: private aerial party for you and up to four friends with Kristin
  • at $500 level: video of the complete work
  • at $1000 level: Producer credit and dinner at Kristin’s

And, not least, undying gratitude!

 

The Impact

Vision:

Migrations is an investigation of the mechanical and organic aspects of time through aerial technique and pedestrian movement. We invite audiences to experience ordinary people existing within an extraordinary context.

Definition of MIGRATE

1: to move from one country, place, or locality to another

2: to pass usually periodically from one region or climate to another for feeding or breeding

3: to change position in an organism or substance

Medical: to move from one place to another: as a : to move from one site to another in a host organism especially as part of a life cycle b of an atom or group : to shift position within a molecule

Origin: perhaps akin to Greek ameibein to change

The project is the culmination of five years of exploration through study, experimentation, collaboration, rehearsal, and performance. This is the first opportunity to fully develop ideas by layering group choreography over the course of an evening-length performance.

Artists:

All of the collaborators are professional artists in their own right, having worked with major companies/productions and on their own creative projects. Get to know them via their websites:

Joshua Dean, performer

Lisa Natoli, perfomer          

Susie Williams, performer

Eric Gorsuch, costume designer

Grady Barker, set designer

Kristin Geneve Young, choreographer and performer

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you would like to contribute your time, special talents, or love to the project, here are some things you can do:

  • Help spread the word, in person and online.
  • Give or request one of our perks as a gift.
  • Donate goods or services for our upcoming silent auction.
  • Volunteer to help out backstage or front-of-house.
  • Come see the show!
