story:
GREAT NEWS! We are ending this Campaign early because we have raised the roof!

Thanks to the generous support of a long-standing donor, we have been able to build a roof over our stage at Phnom Penh's national museum so we can keep performing in the rain.

RAISED ONLINE: $415

RAISED VIA GRANT: $7,000

TOTAL RAISED: $7,415

However, we are still looking for support. In low season tourist numbers drop, which means it is harder for us to sell tickets and make the project sustainable. So if you believe in the power of the arts, and the value of creativity please help us to keep the show going!

For any donations we receive, we will offer complimentary tickets to Cambodian schools, or NGOs. We want as many young Cambodians as possible to see the performance, reagardless of their ability to pay for the ticket. They are the audiences and the artists of tomorrow, and we want them to feel inspired and proud of Cambodian culture.

The standard price of a Cambodian child ticket is $3. Each show costs us $700 to put on. Thanks for your support!

STAY TUNED for more information and pictures for the new roof!

WHO WE ARE

Cambodian Living Arts (CLA), is a non-profit organization based in Cambodia. Our mission is to create a sustainable environment where Cambodian arts can empower and transform individuals and communities. We do this by building the capacity of artists and the arts community, by promoting awareness of the arts, and by facilitating advocacy with cultural policymakers and major institutions. In doing so, we aim to create value and understanding of what it means to be Cambodian and to create a sense of unity and shared culture. We believe that through creativity we can each expand our potential as human beings.

 

 

 

THE PERFORMANCES

From November 2012 to late March 2013, Cambodian Living Arts organized a program of performances called Plae Pakaa (Fruitful). Six days a week, Plae Pakaa featured a rotating program of 3 Cambodian traditional arts performances  set in the splendid gardens of the National Museum, Phnom Penh:

Children of Bassac (Classical & folk dance):

Performed by a troupe filled with energy and creativity, this show includes both Apsara and folk dances from Khmer and other Cambodian ethnic minority cultures.

Mak Therng (theatre & music):

This show is a piece from the Yike repertoire, a popular folk art form. It tells a classical Cambodian tale of love and betrayal. His young wife kidnapped by a prince, Mak Therng sets out on a quest for justice, but where will this lead him? This show includes dance, drama and beautiful singing.

Passage of Live (theatre & music):

Cambodian life is rich with elaborate rituals accompanied by some of the most beautiful Khmer musical forms. This show is a voyage that begins from the greetings of birth to the farewells of death, sweetened by celebrations of love and adulthood.

 

    

 

With Plae Pakaa, Cambodian Living Arts aims to create long-ranging job opportunities in the country’s broader arts sector. Our hope is for any Cambodian artist or arts professional to achieve the dreams of their youth to one day performing on a stage before a live audience.

Plae Pakaa, which translates literally as “coming to fruition”, symbolizes the trees of traditional arts that are now bearing fruit after a long period of growth. It also symbolizes the emerging artists who are sharing the fruits of their efforts with us. From November to late March – the dry season in Cambodia – CLA was able to employ over 120 artists and other arts professionals, six nights a week,offering them a springboard toward future career opportunities in arts productions. We are proud that 65 of the 90 performers have been trained by CLA.

Music and ensemble leader in the theatre and music play Passage of Live Nhok Sinat says:

“Plae Pakaa gives us an opportunity to earn a living through art, to develop our skills, and to raise awareness about Cambodian traditions. Choosing the right music to fit the proper emotion in each scene was an interesting challenge.”

 

BY THE FIGURES

  • 25 performers from 2009 to 2012
  • 90 performers in Plae Pakaa 2012-13
  • Production of 2 new pieces of Yike Opera and theater
  • Production of 3 new dances

What we hope for the future: 

  • Continue the shows on Friday and Saturday during the rainy season;
  • Continue the show 6 days a week during the dry season
  •  Have 75 Plae Pakaa artists secure paid work opportunities;
  • Have 25 Plae Pakaa artists transition into CLA’s Performances program;
  • Have 6 troupes create 6 new pieces of work.

 

     

       

 

CAMBODIA’S BACKGROUND

Before the Khmer Rouge era, Cambodia was home to some of the most diverse and abundant arts and culture in Southeast Asia. Music, dance, theater and cinema flowed strongly through the blood of the Cambodian people. There were singers on every corner, musicians in every village and a dancer in every child. Art flourished. But in the years between 1975 and 1979, the Khmer Rouge brought a devastating end to all of that. It is estimated that during those years, 2 million Cambodians died from execution, starvation and overwork. It is also believed that among the dead were 90% percent of Cambodia’s artists who were specifically targeted for execution, a devastating blow to Cambodia’s artistic traditions. After the fall of the Khmer Rouge, this human and cultural tragedy was compounded by two subsequent decades of crippling economic hardship. Of the Master Artists that survived, few could make a living by performing or teaching.

 

CAMBODIAN LIVING ARTS’ BACKGROUND

Fifteen years ago, Cambodia was in danger of losing its artistic and identity, memory and heritage. Cambodian Living Arts was created in 1998 with a focus on recovery and preservation of Cambodia’s traditional arts, by providing classes to Cambodian youth, allowing them to acquire basic artistic skills. At its onset, the organization provided support to 16 Master Artists and 11 assistant teachers, reaching over 200 students in 8 provinces in Cambodia yearly. But context and needs of Cambodian society evolved, a new generation of artists emerged and 10 years after its creation the organization had to evolve and adapt its actions.

 

In 2009 Cambodian Living Arts welcomed Phloeun Prim as its new Director. We focused on developing talents and skills to increase national and international recognition and awareness of Cambodian arts and culture. Rather than providing support on a local level, in only a few communities, we hope in the future to enable  sustainability for the arts on a national scale, and to raise awareness globally.

 

 

 

CAMBODIAN LIVING ARTS’ MISSION AND VISION

OUR MISSION

The mission of Cambodian Living Arts is to facilitate the transformation of Cambodia through the arts. We work in collaboration with others to create an environment where Cambodian arts empower and transform individuals and communities. We do this by encouraging the growth of artists and the arts community, by promoting awareness of the arts, and by advocating for the arts with cultural policymakers and major institutions. In doing so, we hope to create value and understanding of what it means to be Cambodian and to create a sense of unity and shared culture. We believe that through creativity we can each expand our potential as human beings.

 

OUR VISION

By 2020, we envision a vibrant and dynamic cultural sector throughout Cambodia, with the arts as the country’s national and international signature. Cambodian Living Arts will be a catalyst for this development. The successful transformation of Cambodia’s cultural identity will be a model for other emerging societies.

 

COMMUNITY ARTS EDUCATION

CLA’s Community Arts program aims to provide training and encourage the practice of high-quality, traditional performing arts in communities throughout Cambodia. The program is composed of teaching activities and workshops.

Since 1998, CLA has created 28 classes of traditional performing arts in 9 provinces in Cambodia, reaching over 500 students.

 

BY THE FIGURES

  • 28 classes reaching out to 500 students
  • 40 teachers of 12 art forms
  • 9 provinces

 

CAPACITY BUILDING

At CLA, we help promising youth further their arts education by awarding them scholarships and providing them with real-world training and mentorship to support their growth as professionals. We also work to develop the existing arts sector by building the expertise of arts supervisors and managers.

CLA’s Capacity Building program aims to:

  • Help to staff the Cambodian arts sector with well trained, Cambodian arts professionals working to international standards;
  • Have CLA’s trainees become recognized in the arts sector for their skill and professionalism.

 

CREATIVE INDUSTRIES

All the arts education in the world amounts to little if, after years of training, there isn’t viable employment for Cambodia’s professional artists and arts professionals.  That’s why CLA focuses on improving job opportunities in the country’s broader arts sector as the final stage in the  growth-cycle of CLA and non-CLA graduates.

We want to foster the independent capability of emerging artists and other arts professionals, so they can form their own performance troupes and become Cambodia’s premier working performers.

Our Creative Industries program aims to:

  • Help arts professionals find consistent, well-paid work in the arts and culture sector, supported by Cambodian audiences.
  • Have 50% of CLA’s audiences in Cambodia consist of native Cambodians within 3 years.
  • Have 50% of CLA’s funding generated by our Cambodian operations within 5 years.

 

THE CLA-TEAM SAYS THANK YOU!!!

 http://www.cambodianlivingarts.org/
story_txt:
GREAT NEWS! We are ending this Campaign early because we have raised the roof!
Thanks to the generous support of a long-standing donor, we have been able to build a roof over our stage at Phnom Penh's national museum so we can keep performing in the rain.
RAISED ONLINE: $415 
RAISED VIA GRANT: $7,000
TOTAL RAISED: $7,415
However, we are still looking for support. In low season tourist numbers drop, which means it is harder for us to sell tickets and make the project sustainable. So if you believe in the power of the arts, and the value of creativity please help us to keep the show going!
For any donations we receive, we will offer complimentary tickets to Cambodian schools, or NGOs. We want as many young Cambodians as possible to see the performance, reagardless of their ability to pay for the ticket. They are the audiences and the artists of tomorrow, and we want them to feel inspired and proud of Cambodian culture.
The standard price of a Cambodian child ticket is $3. Each show costs us $700 to put on. Thanks for your support!
STAY TUNED for more information and pictures for the new roof!
WHO WE ARE
Cambodian Living Arts (CLA), is a non-profit organization based in Cambodia. Our mission is to create a sustainable environment where Cambodian arts can empower and transform individuals and communities. We do this by building the capacity of artists and the arts community, by promoting awareness of the arts, and by facilitating advocacy with cultural policymakers and major institutions. In doing so, we aim to create value and understanding of what it means to be Cambodian and to create a sense of unity and shared culture. We believe that through creativity we can each expand our potential as human beings.
 
 
 
THE PERFORMANCES
From November 2012 to late March 2013, Cambodian Living Arts organized a program of performances called Plae Pakaa (Fruitful). Six days a week, Plae Pakaa featured a rotating program of 3 Cambodian traditional arts performances  set in the splendid gardens of the National Museum, Phnom Penh:
Children of Bassac (Classical & folk dance):
Performed by a troupe filled with energy and creativity, this show includes both Apsara and folk dances from Khmer and other Cambodian ethnic minority cultures.
Mak Therng (theatre & music):
This show is a piece from the Yike repertoire, a popular folk art form. It tells a classical Cambodian tale of love and betrayal. His young wife kidnapped by a prince, Mak Therng sets out on a quest for justice, but where will this lead him? This show includes dance, drama and beautiful singing.
Passage of Live (theatre & music):
Cambodian life is rich with elaborate rituals accompanied by some of the most beautiful Khmer musical forms. This show is a voyage that begins from the greetings of birth to the farewells of death, sweetened by celebrations of love and adulthood.
 
    
 
With Plae Pakaa, Cambodian Living Arts aims to create long-ranging job opportunities in the country’s broader arts sector. Our hope is for any Cambodian artist or arts professional to achieve the dreams of their youth to one day performing on a stage before a live audience.
Plae Pakaa, which translates literally as “coming to fruition”, symbolizes the trees of traditional arts that are now bearing fruit after a long period of growth. It also symbolizes the emerging artists who are sharing the fruits of their efforts with us. From November to late March – the dry season in Cambodia – CLA was able to employ over 120 artists and other arts professionals, six nights a week,offering them a springboard toward future career opportunities in arts productions. We are proud that 65 of the 90 performers have been trained by CLA.
Music and ensemble leader in the theatre and music play Passage of Live Nhok Sinat says:
“Plae Pakaa gives us an opportunity to earn a living through art, to develop our skills, and to raise awareness about Cambodian traditions. Choosing the right music to fit the proper emotion in each scene was an interesting challenge.”
 
BY THE FIGURES

25 performers from 2009 to 2012
90 performers in Plae Pakaa 2012-13
Production of 2 new pieces of Yike Opera and theater
Production of 3 new dances
What we hope for the future: 

Continue the shows on Friday and Saturday during the rainy season;
Continue the show 6 days a week during the dry season
 Have 75 Plae Pakaa artists secure paid work opportunities;
Have 25 Plae Pakaa artists transition into CLA’s Performances program;
Have 6 troupes create 6 new pieces of work.
 
     
       
 
CAMBODIA’S BACKGROUND
Before the Khmer Rouge era, Cambodia was home to some of the most diverse and abundant arts and culture in Southeast Asia. Music, dance, theater and cinema flowed strongly through the blood of the Cambodian people. There were singers on every corner, musicians in every village and a dancer in every child. Art flourished. But in the years between 1975 and 1979, the Khmer Rouge brought a devastating end to all of that. It is estimated that during those years, 2 million Cambodians died from execution, starvation and overwork. It is also believed that among the dead were 90% percent of Cambodia’s artists who were specifically targeted for execution, a devastating blow to Cambodia’s artistic traditions. After the fall of the Khmer Rouge, this human and cultural tragedy was compounded by two subsequent decades of crippling economic hardship. Of the Master Artists that survived, few could make a living by performing or teaching.
 
CAMBODIAN LIVING ARTS’ BACKGROUND
Fifteen years ago, Cambodia was in danger of losing its artistic and identity, memory and heritage. Cambodian Living Arts was created in 1998 with a focus on recovery and preservation of Cambodia’s traditional arts, by providing classes to Cambodian youth, allowing them to acquire basic artistic skills. At its onset, the organization provided support to 16 Master Artists and 11 assistant teachers, reaching over 200 students in 8 provinces in Cambodia yearly. But context and needs of Cambodian society evolved, a new generation of artists emerged and 10 years after its creation the organization had to evolve and adapt its actions.
 
In 2009 Cambodian Living Arts welcomed Phloeun Prim as its new Director. We focused on developing talents and skills to increase national and international recognition and awareness of Cambodian arts and culture. Rather than providing support on a local level, in only a few communities, we hope in the future to enable  sustainability for the arts on a national scale, and to raise awareness globally.
 
 
 
CAMBODIAN LIVING ARTS’ MISSION AND VISION
OUR MISSION
The mission of Cambodian Living Arts is to facilitate the transformation of Cambodia through the arts. We work in collaboration with others to create an environment where Cambodian arts empower and transform individuals and communities. We do this by encouraging the growth of artists and the arts community, by promoting awareness of the arts, and by advocating for the arts with cultural policymakers and major institutions. In doing so, we hope to create value and understanding of what it means to be Cambodian and to create a sense of unity and shared culture. We believe that through creativity we can each expand our potential as human beings.
 
OUR VISION
By 2020, we envision a vibrant and dynamic cultural sector throughout Cambodia, with the arts as the country’s national and international signature. Cambodian Living Arts will be a catalyst for this development. The successful transformation of Cambodia’s cultural identity will be a model for other emerging societies.
 
COMMUNITY ARTS EDUCATION
CLA’s Community Arts program aims to provide training and encourage the practice of high-quality, traditional performing arts in communities throughout Cambodia. The program is composed of teaching activities and workshops.
Since 1998, CLA has created 28 classes of traditional performing arts in 9 provinces in Cambodia, reaching over 500 students.
 
BY THE FIGURES


28 classes reaching out to 500 students

40 teachers of 12 art forms

9 provinces
 
CAPACITY BUILDING
At CLA, we help promising youth further their arts education by awarding them scholarships and providing them with real-world training and mentorship to support their growth as professionals. We also work to develop the existing arts sector by building the expertise of arts supervisors and managers.
CLA’s Capacity Building program aims to:

Help to staff the Cambodian arts sector with well trained, Cambodian arts professionals working to international standards;
Have CLA’s trainees become recognized in the arts sector for their skill and professionalism.
 
CREATIVE INDUSTRIES
All the arts education in the world amounts to little if, after years of training, there isn’t viable employment for Cambodia’s professional artists and arts professionals.  That’s why CLA focuses on improving job opportunities in the country’s broader arts sector as the final stage in the  growth-cycle of CLA and non-CLA graduates.
We want to foster the independent capability of emerging artists and other arts professionals, so they can form their own performance troupes and become Cambodia’s premier working performers.
Our Creative Industries program aims to:

Have 50% of CLA’s audiences in Cambodia consist of native Cambodians within 3 years.
Have 50% of CLA’s funding generated by our Cambodian operations within 5 years.

story:
Short Summary

Dear Friends,

Our production “Brazil, The Land of Tears and Soul” at the Betty Oliphant Theatre from September 11-14, 2013. 15th Anniversary Season performance, was a huge success! Now after the performance we are hoping that our friends would be so kind and donate to us so we can finally pay all the expenses from the show.   This wonderful performance was all funded based on volunteer resources and community fundraisers. Although some success was made, not all of the production expenses were covered. If you resonate with what you have seen, please send any donation to cover the dancers fee, the theatre space and the choreographer, Newton Moraes. Lets thank them for the hard work and dedication it took to bring this labor of love to life.

Art is the most profound method of communication between people.  If there is no art there is no love, there is no friendship, there are only isolated, lonely individuals. Art is the deep way in which individuals can reach each other and it is the best way in which we can overcome our differences of race, class and language. I became an artist to understand people more deeply, both those whom I already thought I knew and those who came to me as strangers or as others, across a cultural divide. My own family represents this diversity. My mother is Portuguese and my father Tupi Guarani, one of the ethnic groups of Brazilian Indigenous peoples, and I grew up in Brazil. All my life I’ve found my way through some kind of artistic expression. My Toronto experience has been no different. I came to Toronto in 1991 and have again found the best way to break down the inhumanity of isolation, particularly in a complex, multicultural place such as Toronto, is through my art.

At the base of my exploration is my interest in the hybridity between the spiritual rituals and dances of the Afro-Brazilian religions like Batuque, dances from my Indigenous heritage (Tupi-Guarani) and the influences of Western dance traditions. My dance training and background is in all of these – with contemporary dance, dance-theatre, improvisation and Butoh – and my work reflects experiences of migration and cultural mixing. 

I use my unique background and experience as inspiration for what sets my work apart and makes it distinct. I am inspired not only through a complex family and cultural life, but through my long-term relationship with my late partner, a professional anthropologist.  For 23 years, we shared a life. I learned to see life through the lens of anthropology, and built a profound interest in another way of looking at culture and society, which is reflected in almost all of my work. Our, and consequently my, circle of friends grew to include many active in the field of anthropology, and through conversation and shared study, I have learned to include another perspective in my work. This self-reflexive analysis is part of my conscious creation process and what I see in my work. But once onstage, what is often returned to me through audience feedback are comments noting lyrical beauty and emotional connections. This tells me I’m achieving my goals of community and communication. 

My inspirations, though, are much broader than this base I’ve just drawn. I love soccer, every type of music, and most forms of art as well as my own dance and those of others. Friendship is a vital part of my life. I love to dance, not just in my professional work but at home or in clubs, with others. It is a vast world of communication. 

My current focus is to communicate some of Brazil’s, and humanity’s, diversity, beyond carnival and samba. My choreography draws on both Indigenous and Afro-Brazilian cultures. I am exploring the sad carnival, the suffering from the disparity between rich and poor, and the relationship between colonization and many of Brazil’s religions and rhythms. My work is an attempt to communicate the beauty of subtleties, the cultural complexity and similarities between Canadian and Brazilian culture. In blending the Brazilian understanding that dance communicates, regardless of the body who is dancing, my art puts voices, song and movements to the idea that there is no right or wrong way to dance. I am interested in Canadian contemporary dance and the discipline it offers, but am also interested performing multiple body communications through diverse bodies and languages. I draw from my history – my personal blend of Indigenous, Brazilian and Canadian – and the dance forms that inspire me, to create art that challenges expectations and stereotypes. Brazil has become known as an economic powerhouse; my contribution is to share with Torontonians my explorations of its artistic and social treasures.

What We Need & What You Get

We received some support from our community: MELLOHAWK Logistics, Rio 40 Graus Brazilian Restaurant, Cintia de Souza, Brasil Remmitance, Brazilian Star Restaurant, Dr Renato Harari.

As well as free press at Consulate General of Brazil, Brasil News, Wave Magazine, Discover Magazine, BRAFFTV Festival, aluCine Latin Film & Media Arts Festival, DOS Magazine.

Free Rehearsal space at Bavia Arts.

WE NEED to pay still.

Betty Oliphant Theatre: 5,000.00

Dancers fee: 5,000.00

Your contribution will be greatly appreciated and in exchange we would give away free tickets for our up coming performance at our studio at Bavia Arts, plus acknowledgements in our webpage, facebook, posters, fliers and twitter.

The Impact

The Newton Moraes Dance Theatre has mounted regular seasons in Toronto since its creation in 1997 and has toured extensively, to critical acclaim, in Canada and internationally. The company has performed in many of Toronto’s arts venues including the Du Maurier Theatre at Harbourfront Centre, the Betty Oliphant Theatre, Premiere Dance Theatre, Winchester Theatre, Theatre Passe Muraille, Buddies in Bad Times Theatre and the Royal Ontario Museum and has presented works at local festivals including Series 808, fFida, and the Brazilian Ball. Ongoing school presentations and workshops have provided another avenue for NMDT to foster an appreciation of Brazilian culture and inspire young people through the arts.  Nationally, NMDT has performed at Studio 303 in Montreal, Refinery Theatre in Vancouver, and Free Flow Dance in Saskatoon. Internationally, NMDT has toured extensively to Brazil, a number of cities in Germany, Bogota Colombia (Jorge Eliecer Theatre), Cuba and the U.S. The company has received support from the Toronto Arts Council, Canada Council for the Arts, The Laidlaw Foundation, the General Consulate of Brazil in Toronto, the Department of Foreign Affairs and International Trade in Ottawa, the Canadian Embassy in Berlin/Germany, the Canadian Consulate in São Paulo/Brazil, and the City of Porto Alegre/Brazil. 

Other Ways You Can Help

We all know that somehow it is very difficult or almost impossible for another artist in the field of dance to support us financially, but we appreciate if you can help to spread the word about our campaign and we would love to receive your comments and suggestions.

story:
Who we are:

We are New Orleans Queer Youth Theater (NOQYT), a group of 7 young people ages 14-21 and 3 adult co-directors committed to encouraging leadership within the queer youth community through creating original, multi-disciplinary theatre performance.

NOQYT began in June 2013 with an incubator grant from the Pride Youth Theatre Alliance, a national organization dedicated to promoting and supporting queer youth theaters nationwide. Since September 2013 we have hosted five guest teaching artists, held 28 workshops dedicated to learning and implementing devised theatre techniques and held auditions for our first full ensemble of seven youth!

We are in the midst of creating and producing our first full-length evening performance and we need your help! This piece explores the theme: "What is a Queer World? Beyond Gender & Acceptance". Our ensemble has spent 10 weeks devising, writing, and rehearsing a fantastic performance and we need help from you to make sure it happens with all the trimmings of a professional theater production.



Why is this project important?

There is a significant lack of spaces in New Orleans for youth, and queer youth in particular, to gather, build community and cultivate tools for self-expression. Our ensemble has spend the last seven months learning  about all areas of theater from devising, and story-boarding to design, costuming and direction. This performance is our first opportunity to showcase our work to the wider public and engage our allies, friends and newcomers to a better understanding of queer identities and queer experiences in New Orleans through the transformative medium of theatre.

Where the money goes:

NOQYT is both a learning and job opportunity for our youth. Your donation goes to paying youth stipends, space rental, and material fees for costuming, props and any other equipment needed to make the show a success!

The breakdown of our $2500 ask is:
  • $500 for materials
  • $500 for space rental
  • $1500 for three youth stipends 
Impact

It is imperative that we begin to hear stories of the experiences of LGBTQ youth from their own mouths. NOQYT strives to lift these voices through the creation of powerful, stimulating and educational original performance. Please join us in making art that sustains the vibrancy and visibility of the queer youth community!

story:
SmokeyScout Productions presents . . . 

a trio of one acts about dogs, bosses, and neighbors

Directed by Chris Czyz and Josh McIlvain
Written by Josh McIlvain

Starring
Thomas DeMarcus
Josh Lay
Paul McElwee
Ed Miller
Valerie O'Hara
Anna Watson

March 27-29 at 8pm
at the Gershwin Hotel
7 E. 27th Street
New York City

April 3-5 at 8pm
JUNK Performance Space
2040 Christian Street
Philadelphia

With shows in New York City and Philadelphia, we have a joint NYC-PHILLY cast and creative crew!

www.smokeyscout.com

American Wisdom showcases our three of our best and most thought provoking plays in Philadelphia and New York City. Featuring some of our favorite actors, this show allows us to expand to new audiences as we continue to produce ever more ambitious work.

Our over all budget is $5,500; our fundraising goal is $3500, the rest we plan to make up in tickets sales. Your contribution goes to travel, theater rental, cast and crew, props, marketing, lights, you name it! Our budget is designed to maximize the most out of a shoestring budget, so by passing our goal, we can increase our production values to match the quality of our art.

Like all performing arts companies, as well as museums, colleges and Super PACs, we require fundraising to support our company's ability to make great art! Your contribution goes directly to the production and has a tangible effect on the work we do--it will not get frittered away in a maze of poor administration. We may not be able to influence the next election, but we can create work that has a lasting effect on your soul.

American Wisdom includes these amazing plays . . .

THANKS FOR THE PLANT, THANKS FOR THE CONE. This world premiere of a skewed morality tale about a neighbor who's plant has just died, a neighbor who's cone is missing, and a neighbor who just wants everyone to get along.

For The Dogs.  Debt, dogs, and love demand a complicated balance in the search for a decent life in this humorous one-woman play.

Waiting For The Boss.A tense, comedic drama about the intimate revelations between day laborers who care nothing for each other.

Founded in 2008, SmokeyScout Productions (smokeyscout.com) creates work that brings the absurdity of contemporary life to the stage with brilliant acting, bold humor, inventive staging, and a respect for audience intelligence.

“Brings on the funny, tinged with an urban edge.” –Philadelphia City Paper

Wisdom includes these amazing plays . . .
THANKS FOR THE PLANT, THANKS FOR THE CONE. This world premiere of a skewed morality tale about a neighbor who's
plant has just died, a neighbor who's cone is missing, and a neighbor who just
wants everyone to get along. 

For
The Dogs.  Debt,
dogs, and love demand a complicated balance in the search for a decent life in
this humorous one-woman play. 
Waiting For The Boss.A tense, comedic drama about
the intimate revelations between day laborers who care nothing for each other. 
Founded in 2008,
SmokeyScout Productions (smokeyscout.com) creates work that brings the
absurdity of contemporary life to the stage with brilliant acting, bold humor,
inventive staging, and a respect for audience intelligence. 
“Brings on the funny, tinged with an urban edge.” –Philadelphia
City Paper

story:
We are Bunbanter's Young Theatre Company, a recently set-up group of 7 young people who meet every Saturday Ealing, London, to learn drama from a practicing theatre director.

Our performance is a modern Brechtian-styled theatre production of Caryl Churchill's short play 'This is a chair'.

Through a series of surreal sketches and using ensemble based theatre, our production takes us from the daily into the unspoken and abstract; highlighting societal issues hidden behind our everyday lives that many of us can ignore.

As a group of young people we are possibly guiltier of this willful ignorance than many, so we want to explore how we can draw attention to the connectedness of the world, the things that may not directly affect us, the ‘Big Picture’, so that we can demonstrate it to an audience like ourselves and allow them to explore too. We want our audience to leave at the end with a closed mouth but an open mind.

But because Bunbanter is a community interest company, we do not have the funds to get this performance off the ground by ourselves.

That's where you come in. Money from you will go towards our props, costumes, venue hire, even travel so that our members can make it to the show on the day.

Whatever we receive will not only help for this performance, but get the Young Theatre Company in motion so that we can continue doing what we love.


We know not all of us can donate, but any help (a like, a share, a shout from the roof about what we're doing) is still greatly appreciated.

And finally, an enormous thanks from all of us at Bunbanter!

story:
(ENGLISH FOLLOWS)

Le temps file…

Avec la danse comme langage, j’explore ici les rituels de la vie. Avec la femme comme muse, je tente ici de dépeindre cet état sacré qu’est, le sentiment d’urgence. Avec le doute comme compagnon fidèle, je travaille ici à repousser les limites de notre art. Avec le rêve comme puissant stimulant, je choisi ici d’invoquer, de provoquer.

RITUALKA, c’est…

Un spectacle de danse tribal-fusion théâtral.

Une prise de conscience du temps qui passe.

Une célébration de la vie et de ses rituels en 11 tableaux évocateurs.

22 interprètes de différents niveaux et milieux vous transporteront dans un univers ou les langages dansés et la symbolique se métissent en un tout intemporel et multiculturel.

Laissez-nous vous raconter une histoire… tout à fait inattendue!

Pour Kali Maat Co. (Josée Demers V.) c’est une première œuvre complète en tant que chorégraphe et directrice artistique.

Merci de votre soutient, merci de croire en nous.

Vos dons n’encouragent pas seulement le spectacle en tant que tel, mais assurent à ses artistes une rémunération pour leur travail.

D’autres façons de nous aider:

-Devenez membre de notre groupe facebook : https://www.facebook.com/groups/478268628942134/

-Partagez notre campagne Indigogo avec votre entourage.

-Invitez vos amis et votre famille à venir voir le spectacle.

Les dates :

Vendredi, le 5 décembre 2014 20h

Samedi le, 6 décembre 2014 20h

Dimanche le, 7 décembre 2014 15h

Salle Pierre-Buissonneau du Centre Calixa-Lavallée (Artneuf)

3819 rue Calixa-Lavallée, Montréal.

Questions? Écrire à marethada@hotmail.com

_______________________________________________


Time flies…

With dance as my language, I here try to explore the rituals of life.

With women as my muses, I here try to portray the sacred state of urgency.

With doubt as a constant companion, I here work at pushing our art beyond its boundaries.

With my dreams as a powerful propellant, I here choose to invoke, to provoke.

RITUALKA is…

A theatrical tribal-fusion dance show.

The growing awareness of time flying by.

A celebration of life and its rituals through 11 evocative pieces.

22 multi-levelled performers with different backgrounds will transport you through this journey where dance languages and symbolism fuse into a timeless and multicultural whole.

Let us tell you this, oh so unexpected story!

It is a first complete dance work for Kali Maat Co. (Josée Demers V.) as a choreographer and artistic director.

Thank you for your support, thank you for believing in us.

Your donations won’t just contribute to this show as itself, but will insure that all artists will be paid for their work.

Other ways to help us :

-Become a member of our Facebook group: https://www.facebook.com/groups/478268628942134/

-Share our Indigogo campaing with all your friends/family.

-Invite people to come and see the show.

The dates :

Friday, December 5th 2014 at 8pm

Saturday, December 6th 2014 at 8pm

Sunday, Decembrer 7th 2014 at 3pm

Salle Pierre-Buissonneau du Centre Calixa-Lavallée (Artneuf)

3819 rue Calixa-Lavallée, Montréal.

Questions? Write to : marethada@hotmail.com

story:
One man fleeing from a country torn apart by war, one man living in a world surrounded by change and one man naïve to his own ignorance.

My name is John McEwan-Whyte and i am a professional actor who also writes and directs his own short films. I have always loved the theatre and have written British about a topic that is close to my heart.

 “British” is a story that needs to be told and one that will ignite passions as well as forcing thoughts. It holds a light to the important aspects of one of the greatest crises our generation has before us, and asks the question; do we need to provide shelter to our fellow humans, or can we simply turn a blind eye?

A suitable venue hire for this play in London costs £450, the money raised will go towards that venue hire and the remaining money raised will go towards hiring someone to carry out the technical aspects of the play such as lighting and sound. Any money left over will be put into promotion of the play. 

I have written, will be directing and performing the play. Keeping costs to a minimum.

story:
Theatre N16@TheBedford 

We are Theatre N16, London's newest fringe venue dedicated to promoting a new generation of theatre makers. 

Originally in Stoke Newington, Theatre N16 moved south of the river to it's rightful home in Balham, above the famous Bedford pub. Famous for housing the longest running comedy club in the UK (Banana Cabaret) and discovering a wealth of musical talent with the likes of Newton Faulkner, Paulo Nutini and Ed Sheeran. 

So far since our formation in May this year, twenty nine different theatre companies have been given totally free space to mount a production at N16 resulting in  seventeen sell out performances and four five star shows. 

Our aim is simple. To create an environment that allows for budgets to be set aside to pay those working on productions fairly. With no hire fees, inclusive pr and technical support, N16 provides a package like no other to ensure artists don't get into financial difficulty when taking on a project.


What We Need & What You Get

Currently our technical specifications are not up to the standard of most fringe theatre's, due to the simple fact of having free standing lighting around the room, instead of a lighting rig.  Our stands don't give the best cover for shows and take up floor space which could be used to increase our capacity. So we need these things to progress..

  • A structural engineer and report
  • A load testing report 
  • Materials for the rig itself (Scaff etc)
  • Workmen to put the rig together
With every donation you will receive a Christmas treat  and many thanks as described in our perks.

The Impact

Our space will provide more advanced facilities for theatre makers therefore creating a more varied, interesting and professional standard of work for our audiences. 


Our Challenge

Theatre N16 receives no funding whatsoever, has no patrons and survives on making good quality work and getting bums on seats. A donation to our cause will act as a massive help of ensuring our work is the best to alive us to survive into the long term future. 


Other Ways You Can Help

We know it's the festive season and a time where outgoings are at a premium, so if you can't donate, a share of our campaign would mean the absolute world.


Thank you from Team N16, have a merry Christmas and a beautiful new year.

story:
Hi! I’m Thanos. I am a composer, researcher and music theatre maker. Quicklime is part of my PhD research on Music Theatre at Sussex University (UK). I have involved a group of practitioners and researchers in my project: experimenting on music theatre. So far we have managed to devise a performance that is worth to be shared with the public. We have showed different stages of this research in the UK, and now we need the funds to make this project travel, in order to share it with different audiences.

Music theatre productions are very demanding and costly, as they involve performers, musicians, set designers, equipment, material etc…
So far I have managed to maintain the budget of the production to the absolute minimum, because I was lucky enough to work with very understanding practitioners, who accepted to rehearse, research and perform in kind.
Now I am at the point where the performance is ready to travel abroad and be shared with a larger crowd.
The only thing that is holding me back is that travel expenses of all the people involved and the gear can be extremely costly… to the extent that we cannot self-fund it anymore!

Your contribution will help me pay the travel expenses of the performers and the shipment of the equipment, instruments and set. And will make our dream possible: to get Quicklime to be performed in the New Benaki Museum for OUT_TOPIAS (Athens, GR), and in Modern Body Festival (Den Haag, NL), giving visibility to the work and to the professionals involved.

I am asking for 2000EUR to cover the travel expenses of 8 performers to two festivals  and the shipment of the gear and the set to these two events.

In exchange for your generous contribution, I’ve tried to design the rewards drawing from the personal abilities of mine and of my collaborators… we are all professional practitioners of the performing arts, ready to share our knowledge in the field!
All rewards are transferable - so you could use them as a gift for someone you love!

If I do not manage to reach the entire goal, the funds I’ll manage to get will go towards covering most of the travel expenses of the performers and I will try to work out other ways to cover the shipment of equipment and set.
If I do not manage to get anything from this campaign…. the show must go on! So we will have to put this amount from our pockets, which means big sacrifices in our daily lives.

Quicklime is an independent production of an experimental performance.
Our aim is not to profit but rather to experiment with new performance experiences and offer them to the public.

If you want to help us in other ways share this funding campaign with very rich friends/ acquaintances and come see the performances in Athens and in Den Haag!

Quicklime is devised with and performed by:

M. Eugenia Demeglio (IT/UK)
Nikos Ioakeim (GR/NL)
Alexis Kotsopoulos (GR)
Nikos Karydis (GR)
Valeria Cosi (IT/ES)
Katerina Konstantourou (GR/NL)
Iakovos Pavlopoulos (GR)
Nikos Antonopoulos (GR)
Stephanie Pan (US/NL)
Goncalo Almeida (PT/NL)
Friso Van Wijk (NL)
Arthur Leadbetter (UK)
Theresa Elflein (DE/UK)

story:
Jessica Taylor/DAMAGEDANCE seeks, through dance, to explore the diversity of the human experience, increasing our awareness, understanding, and appreciation of our unique struggles, questions, and triumphs. 

On May 7-9, 2015, DAMAGEDANCE will be celebrating 5 Years of innovative and thought-provoking dance through a three performance season at the beautiful Dixon Place Mainstage Theater in New York City.  Through this important milestone, we plan to present one of our most exciting, challenging and complex works ever - a new work by Jessica Taylor entitled autopilot.

The concept behind this work is a behavioral fascination of Taylor's, playing with two senses, the ears and the eyes.  It is a collaboration with sound designer Matthew Polis and musicians Brad Meehan, David Craig, Ximena Borges, Dane Markle-Klapp, David Greiman and Kevin LeBoeuf, with the vision of each dancer in possession of a set of headphones.  The master track will be a mashup of different continuous tracks created by the above musicians, but each dancer will have only one fed into their headphones through a personal mp3 player.  Whether or not a dancer is wearing their headset will determine if their track is heard only by them or by the audience.  Each dancer will remove and replace their headset multiple times, with all sound elements in perfect synchronization.

autopilot strongly reinforces the JT/DD mission of presenting challenges and discomforts to artists, seeing their natural reactions, and helping them to overcome them as they perform both together and as individuals on the stage.  Another part of this challenge is that the tunnel vision of each dancer implied while wearing their headset is a challenge to living in the present, a reality experienced by Taylor's own research choosing to connect with people rather then close myself off during her daily commutes.

WE NEED YOUR HELP TO MAKE THIS HAPPEN!  Your contributions will help us get the necessary equipment for the work (headphones, mp3 players, music software), will pay stipends towards our artistic collaborators and dancers, and will also help to fund other production components including light design by the amazing Lauren Libretti.  

It is essential that we have this equipment not only for performance, but for creation and rehearsal, as the dancers' experiences are different then that of the audience, and for us to become as familiar as possible with the work's complexity in order to present a seamless performance and audience experience.

autopilot is just one element of many in our amazing 5 Year Anniversary Celebration plans...we look forward to keeping you posted every step of the way!  Thank you so much in advance for your time and support!!!

story:
My name is Amy Eingold and I am producing July House for this year's FringeNYC. This is my first real go for at producing and I couldn't be more excited. I was approached by the director, Nathaniel P. Claridad who then introduced me to playwright, Pat D. Robinson. Below are notes from each of them about how the play came to be and why it is an important story to be told.  

From the director, Nathaniel P. Claridad:

An ironic and scathing look at grief and privilege from the point of view of five college kids on the brink of graduation, I first encountered Pat D. Robinson's July House at the University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill.  Several workshops and readings later, July House is poised to make its New York City premiere in the NYC Fringe Festival.  Much like the post-millennial characters of Robinson's play, July House demands to be heard.  Robinson's unique voice is both brutally funny, and surprisingly (and hauntingly) self-aware.  Join us in bringing July House to life at the NYC Fringe Festival, and take part in introducing this fresh new playwright from the Carolinas to the New York stage.  

From the playwright, Pat D. Robinson:

During my sophomore year of college, I thought it would be cool to get a couple of friends together, drink red wine from the bottle and write letters to each other that we wouldn’t read until the writer died. I recall wandering around Chapel Hill, North Carolina, thinking how this would be a good ritual, a way to push us to write something real. Parallel to these thoughts, every summer my extended family would rent a beach house on Figure 8 Island, right near Wilmington, North Carolina. It is a lovely, lonely island filled with exclusive beach homes. I conjured up the idea of this rich-kid fugitive who would sneak out to his grandparents’  beach house by himself in winter.One time I took a road trip with some friends to the island in the dead of winter. I’d only been in the summer, and the stark landscape and cold winds that swept the once crowded beach were deeply inspiring to me. A summer later, I interned at New Dramatists playwriting center in New York and found myself reading some of the most current and creative American dramatists.  That summer in the city is where the current draft of July House took shape.  This summer it takes the stage!  Many thanks for your support.   

What We Need 

We have to raise all funds to get this show up. Unlike other shows that are being produced by existing companies, this is just us. We need any and all help we can get. Below is our budget:

Fringe NYC Participation Fee $650
Tip for Venue Director $150
Insurance for Cast & Crew $200
Rehearsal Space  $1,920
Audition Space $100
Equity Actors Pay ($400x5) $2,000
Production Team Stipend $2,000
Set $500
Costumes $100
Props $300
Lights $300
Incidentals & Miscellaneous $300
FringeNYC Program Ad, $300
Show Programs (400) $295
Show Postcards (5,000) $230
IndieGogo Fee (4%) $373.80
Paypal Fee (4%) $373.80


We understand that not everyone can financially afford to give, but that doesn't mean you can't help. Pass the word around to everyone you know.
story_txt:
My name is Amy Eingold and I am producing July House for this year's FringeNYC. This is my first real go for at producing and I couldn't be more excited. I was approached by the director, Nathaniel P. Claridad who then introduced me to playwright, Pat D. Robinson. Below are notes from each of them about how the play came to be and why it is an important story to be told.  
From the director, Nathaniel P. Claridad:


An ironic and scathing look at grief and privilege from the point of view of five college kids on the brink of graduation, I first encountered Pat D. Robinson's July House at the University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill.  Several workshops and readings later, July House is poised to make its New York City premiere in the NYC Fringe Festival.  Much like the post-millennial characters of Robinson's play, July House demands to be heard.  Robinson's unique voice is both brutally funny, and surprisingly (and hauntingly) self-aware.  Join us in bringing July House to life at the NYC Fringe Festival, and take part in introducing this fresh new playwright from the Carolinas to the New York stage.  
From the playwright, Pat D. Robinson:
During my sophomore year of college, I thought it would be cool to get a couple of friends together, drink red wine from the bottle and write letters to each other that we wouldn’t read until the writer died. I recall wandering around Chapel Hill, North Carolina, thinking how this would be a good ritual, a way to push us to write something real. Parallel to these thoughts, every summer my extended family would rent a beach house on Figure 8 Island, right near Wilmington, North Carolina. It is a lovely, lonely island filled with exclusive beach homes. I conjured up the idea of this rich-kid fugitive who would sneak out to his grandparents’  beach house by himself in winter.One time I took a road trip with some friends to the island in the dead of winter. I’d only been in the summer, and the stark landscape and cold winds that swept the once crowded beach were deeply inspiring to me. A summer later, I interned at New Dramatists playwriting center in New York and found myself reading some of the most current and creative American dramatists.  That summer in the city is where the current draft of July House took shape.  This summer it takes the stage!  Many thanks for your support.   
  What We Need  We have to raise all funds to get this show up. Unlike other shows that are being produced by existing companies, this is just us. We need any and all help we can get. Below is our budget:



Fringe NYC Participation Fee
$650


Tip for Venue Director 
$150


Insurance for Cast & Crew
$200


Rehearsal Space 
$1,920


Audition Space
$100


Equity Actors Pay ($400x5)
$2,000


Production Team Stipend 
$2,000


Set
$500


Costumes
$100


Props
$300


Lights 
$300


Incidentals & Miscellaneous
$300


FringeNYC Program Ad, 
$300


Show Programs (400)
$295


Show Postcards (5,000)
$230


IndieGogo Fee (4%)
$373.80


Paypal Fee (4%)
$373.80




     We understand that not everyone can financially afford to give, but that doesn't mean you can't help. Pass the word around to everyone you know.

story:
What Are We Doing?

The whirling machinations of tempests, music, and undeniable love, laughter, revelry, and reflection will be brought to life outdoors by a troupe of traveling performers in Tieline Theater's production of "Twelfth Night."

by William Shakespeare 
Directed by Drew Scott 
assisted by Ashley DiFranza

Presented on Quinnipiac University's College of Arts and Sciences' Green*
Friday, June 19 at 7:00 P.M.
Saturday, June 20 at 4:00 P.M. and 7:00 P.M.
Sunday, June 21 at 2:00 P.M.
Admission: Pay As You Will!**

*Rain location: Quinnipiac's Black Box Theater
**What is "Pay As You Will?" - Exactly what it sounds like. We wanted to try something different this year. While we'd love to offer this experience for free, the reality of the world makes that difficult sometimes. But we also don't want to put a price on art, so all we're asking is for anyone who comes to see our show to "pay what you will." What is our show worth to you? YOU decide! Any amount will do!

Cast:

  • Viola - Jessica Otterbine
  • Sebastian - Joshua Dill
  • Olivia - Julianne McGourty 
  • Orsino, Sir Toby - Michael Pray
  • Antonio, Malvolio - Sean Gardell 
  • Sir Andrew - Elise D'Avella
  • Feste - Ryan Kendall
In the meantime, please enjoy the highlight video from our previous production of "Midsummer Lovers!"

What Is Tieline Theater?

In the Quinnipiac Theater department, there's a tradition that's been upheld since its inception. After performing in their first mainstage show all newcomers receive a piece of tie line, presented to them by the veterans of the department.  This tie line is a symbol of inviting them wholeheartedly into the theater family called the "D-Lites" or "Drama Lites" (but we'll save the origin of that D-Lite-ful name for another time).

The piece of tie line has come to represent many things since the tradition started, and though its origins are somewhat blurred, the strongest image is one of unity and bonds. Much like how tie line holds together a theater set; students and alumni of the department are all held together and connected by their experience and the powerful work they've done, no matter where they are.

We have incorporated this idea of being connected into the very core of our performace. "It's like you and your scene partner are attached by a million tiny strings, so everything each of you does directly influences the other." (Timothy Cochran: Professor of Communication and Theater, Holyoke Community College) We want to connect with each other, with other students and performers from near and far, with the audience, and with the community as a whole. 

And so, our goal is to raise awareness of the area's artistic potential, not only on the Quinnipiac Campus but in the surrounding community. We aim to build a stronger alumni and guest artist relationship as well as a continuing relationship with the faculty, further reinforcing those bonds and forging new ones.

This project is being used as the cornerstone for future endeavors; including full-length summer shows and workshops. We wish to bring theater to the community and enhance the local arts culture, while at the same time promoting the talents and the assets that Quinnipiac can provide to the surrounding community.

What We Need & What You Get

Our campaign last year was able to net us $1,435! It helped us tremendously, but we were definitely down to the wire on a lot of things. We're confident we can do even better this year with your help and create an experience that'll leave an everlasting impression on our audiences to come! Here's what your donations will go toward supporting:

  • Housing and food for tech week and performances
  • Posters, flyers, and other miscellaneous publicity
  • Transportation (gas and train fare)
  • Costumes and props
  • Eventual fees for insurance, our very own official website, and becoming a full-fledged organization!
  • Future workshops and endeavors just like this!

As a result, we'll be able to provide:

  • An amazing tale full of love, music, humanity, and excitement!
  • Some very fun and unique rewards building off of what we offered last year including a private video link of the performance. a free workshop*** for anyone who is interested, and even a special song written just for you!
  • Further progress in laying a groundwork to provide this kind of experience for years to come!
***Details coming soon!

The Impact

The goal of Quinnipiac's theater department has always been "Theater for Community," and that's something we passionately believe in. But that community is both internal and external. By supporting us, you'll not only be strengthening the campus/alumni theater community and the theater community at large, but also extending the Quinnipiac/Hamden theater community beyond the confines of the school year in a location that's ripe for artistic endeavors. We genuinely feel that this project will leave a lasting impression with everyone involved and will not only challenge and bring the cast together, but strengthen the ties between the community and the art that can flourish within it. If theater hadn't been such an important part of our lives, we wouldn't be doing this. If we didn't think that doing great theater that engages the community was important and could enrich people's lives, we wouldn't be doing this. We want to give back to a school and community that's given us so much, but we need your help! And with it, we know we'll give people a unique and very entertaining experience while laying the groundwork for even greater things to come.

Other Ways You Can Help!

If you support our effort and can't contribute monetarily, never fear! Just spreading the word is an INCREDIBLE help. Tell your friends, your family, your co-workers… anyone! Even a little can go a long way, and we deeply appreciate any form of assistance you can provide.

Stay Tuned!

We'll have more exciting updates as we go along! Thanks for your support!

story:
RESUMEN

URANIA es un espectáculo sonoro y visual que se basa en descubrimientos de la ciencia para difundir a través del arte, la música, el canto, la danza y proyecciones audiovisuales, toda la sabiduría que se manifiesta en la naturaleza, tanto en el cosmos, como en las plantas, los minerales, animales,  y en las culturas ancestrales que poblaron la tierra en la antigüedad. 

Durante el espectáculo el público llegará a un estado elevado de vibración a través de dos caminos: intelectualmente, internalizando la información científica, y emocionalmente sensibilizando los sentidos a través del arte.

De esta manera se despertará el recuerdo del verdadero lugar al que pertenecemos como parte integrada a la totalidad, comprendiendo el rol que desempeñamos como especie que convive en perfecta armonía con el entorno.

Los creadores de Urania somos un grupo de artistas independientes comprometidos con el cuidado de la naturaleza:

Dirección: Mariana Tschudi, artista audiovisual graduada de Rhode Island School of Design (RISD) EEUU, 2004. En el 2007 creó “ADEMAS” organización que desarrolla proyectos artísticos relacionados a temas ecológicos y de sensibilización. En el 2012 culminó su maestría de arte digital Camberwell College of Arts, Londres. 

Dirección: Carmelo Cambareri, músico y compositor. Integrante de orquestas sinfónicas, orquestas de cámara, director de coro y director de orquestas. Actualmente se dedica a la música de investigación y experimental y está comprometido con la permacultura y la creación e instalación de eco aldeas autosustentables.

Producción General: Vanessa Demichelli, productora de eventos comprometidos con el ambiente y el arte. 

Eloísa Tréllez, física, ambientalista, contadora de cuentos, declamadora y presidenta de la Asociación Cultural Pirámide. Se dedica a la educación ambiental, la interpretación del patrimonio, la recuperación de saberes ancestrales y a la participación comunitaria.

Pamela Rodriguez: músico y cantante, en el año 2005 crea su primer disco “Perú Blue”, el cual la llevaría a su primera nominación en los premios GRAMMY® Latino 2006 como Mejor Artista Nuevo. En el 2007 lanza su segundo álbum “En la orilla”, que en su primera semana de lanzamiento, logró posicionarse entre los ocho discos más vendidos en Lima. En el 2011, Pamela presenta su último trabajo “Reconocer”, que también fue nominado a los premios GRAMMY® Latino 2012 como Mejor Álbum Pop Contemporáneo. Asimismo, fue nominada, en los premios de Independent Music Awards.

Valerie y Stephanie Koechlin, acróbatas especialistas en aparatos aéreos con estudios en el Profesional Aéreos de San Francisco Circus Center, trabajaron 3 temporadas en la Tarumba, luego viajaron al extranjero para trabajar en el Circo de Flora (Estados Unidos), en el Festival del Circo New Commershow de Alemania y Krystallpalast Varite en Alemania, actualmente se encuentran explorando danza contemporánea y contorsión.

Dirección Arte: Gisella Ramirez
Bailarines: Maria Alejandra Valera, GianCarlo Flores
Otros músicos: Sergio Sarria, Eduardo Peschiera, Mathias Tschudi.

NECESIDADES

Urania estrenará en el festival de FUSIONES del teatro Británico el 7,8, 9 y 10 de Agosto del 2015. Para crear Urania necesitamos recaudar 6,000 dólares que se usarán para:

- Alquiler de 2 proyectores de 7,000 lumenes
- Creación de vestuario
- Creación de animaciones digitales
- Creación de música original
- Maquillaje
-Iluminación
- Utilería (fabricación de pantallas, podios, y otros elementos)
- Pagos a personal técnico

IMPACTO

La naturaleza es la fuente de vida y es imprescindible despertar una nueva conciencia y así poder vivir en armonía con nuestro entorno. Queremos que Urania viaje por todo el país incentivando una nueva mirada a la naturaleza para que el Perú continúe siendo un país megadiverso y un ejemplo a nivel mundial.

RETOS

Para poder sorprender al espectador y llevarlo a un estado de plenitud es necesario sorprenderlo también con el aspecto visual y sonoro. Nuestro reto es el uso de múltiples proyecciones de videos y animaciones con efectos de mapping e interacción sincronizada entre los bailarines y las proyecciones de video.

A su vez, la música se presentará en vivo y será compuesta especialmente para el espectáculo respondiendo a la temática visual, a la danza y a la apertura sensorial como vehículo de inducción.

Se incluirán textos (poemas, citas, frases) que complementen los conceptos y sensaciones que se están plasmando en el espectáculo y se expresarán a través de textos escritos, cantados, y declamados.

OTRAS MANERAS DE APOYAR

Siempre hay maneras de contribuir, si no pueden hacerlo económicamente les pedimos que por favor compartan esta página con sus amigos para lograr este sueño!!! G R A C I A S infinitas!!!

story:
Short Summary

"An actor...is an actor...is an actor" was written and performed for the first time by Zijah Sokolovic back in 1978 and has since then been performed by him for over 30 years and in over 20 different countries. It is considered one of the most successful one man shows in Europe and it has been translated to several languages. Performed for the first time in New York in 1991 this one man show returns again for a short run in one of the greatest cities on Earth. 

The show focuses on the part of the "actor" in today's show business and the struggles one has to overcome in order to be successful. It is divided into two parts in which the actor interacts with the audience, reflects on his past and present experiences and tries to find meaning in the art of acting.

Performed and directed by Almir Kurtic the play is in it's final stages and almost ready to be shown to the public. Since it's an independent production we are in need for additional funding which would cover venue costs and marketing materials. 

 

 

The Writer

 

Zijah Sokolovic (born 1950 in Sarajevo, FPR Yugoslavia) is a Bosnian actor, writer and director who lives, acts and directs in Serbia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Croatia, Slovenia and Austria. He is a director of Theaterland in Salzburg, professor in Bruckner Konservatorium in Linz, artistic director of Dežela gledališča theatre in Ljubljana and artistic project leader for Dramatic society, Dramatično društvo, but also directs plays in Zagreb. He is most known for his one man shows "An Actor...is an Actor...is an Actor", "Cabares Cabarei" and many more. Working in stage and TV/Film for over 40 years, Zijah Sokolovic is considered one of the most acclaimed actors/writers/directors of the European region.

 

The Performer

 

Almir Kurtic is an actor from Bosnia and Herzegovina currently attending The Lee Strasberg Theatre and Film Institute in New York. He earned his Bachelor's degree in Acting in 2014 at the Academy of Performing Arts in Tuzla (Bosnia and Herzegovina) in the class of acclaimed actress Selma Alispahic. In 2016 Almir was awarded the Eleonora Duse Scholarship at The Lee Strasberg Theatre and Film Institute where he's currently finishing his two year conservatory in Method Acting. Almir's stage work expands over 7 years and ranges from classic plays ("The Odyssey", "Timon of Athens", "Don Quixote") to contemporary works ("Unity 1918", "The Motherfucker with The Hat") and many more. He can be seen in the upcoming production of "Ajax in Iraq" which will run at The Lee Strasberg Theatre and Film Institute from November 9th.

What We Need & What You Get

As mentioned above, we're trying to raise $1300 in order to cover the rehearsal space costs and the cost of the venue where the show is going to be performed. Also a lot of the funds would go into covering marketing material costs. 

The Impact

Now, the show is happening regardless of the funds raised, even if it means that it'll be performed on the street, it will happen! Your contribution would mean that the audience would have a seat to sit on and that the actor would have lights to shine on him. Last but not least, the amount of funds raised would determine the price of admission which could potentially be free. Theatre should be accessible to everyone!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't say goodbye to a dollar or thousand dollars, it's fine, simply sharing this campaign with your friend will help too. Let us reach as much people as possible! Thank you!

Almir's stage work expands over 7 years and ranges from classic plays ("The Odyssey", "Timon of Athens", "Don Quixote") to contemporary works ("Unity 1918", "The Motherfucker with The Hat") and many more. He can be seen in the upcoming production of "Ajax in Iraq" which will run at The Lee Strasberg Theatre and Film Institute from November 9th.

What We Need & What You Get
As mentioned above, we're trying to raise $1300 in order to cover the rehearsal space costs and the cost of the venue where the show is going to be performed. Also a lot of the funds would go into covering marketing material costs. 

The Impact
Now, the show is happening regardless of the funds raised, even if it means that it'll be performed on the street, it will happen! Your contribution would mean that the audience would have a seat to sit on and that the actor would have lights to shine on him. Last but not least, the amount of funds raised would determine the price of admission which could potentially be free. Theatre should be accessible to everyone!
Other Ways You Can HelpIf you can't say goodbye to a dollar or thousand dollars, it's fine, simply sharing this campaign with your friend will help too. Let us reach as much people as possible! Thank you!

story:
About SUCKERS:

Desire turns to love turns to wrath turns to apathy in this bitter comedy about friendship, fate, and the often unexpected transiency of life. SUCKERS follows the intertwining “love story” of four post-graduate, twenty-somethings, trapped in the cyclical black hole of each other. Jane, Alex, Daisy, and Holden let the fear of the unknown stop them from breaking free. Who will find their way out in this biting commentary on the danger of complacency, the giddiness of a beginning, and the beauty of finality?

 

Why are we telling this story:

SUCKERS is the premiere project of a brand new production company in New York City: Seeded Productions. Founded by Carly Speno, Leah Beth Etheredge, and Rachel Gifford, Seeded is a production company that developed out of an urge to feed the artistic hunger so many artists experience upon moving to New York City. Seeded presents opportunities for emerging voices and budding artists to do the work that fulfills them. It aims to champion the artist as a whole and serves as a channel for production, backing, support, and growth of individual projects and interests.
SUCKERS was the perfect project to launch our company, as it's author is someone near and dear to our hearts. As peers in the same Musical Theatre program at TCU, we watched Devin emerge as a gifted and important young playwright. She has grown to be a close friend and colleague and we are honored and proud to help her bring SUCKERS to life. 

 

Your Impact:

You're literally helping us put on this show. From renting the space, to props/lighting/set/costumes, to marketing and promotional costs, plus everything in between - you are truly the backbone of this endeavor. Without your contributions and support, this important story couldn't be told in New York City. 

Your impact is also felt beyond SUCKERS. If we surpass our goal, this money will go directly toward building a foundation for our production company. These donations will serve as a launching pad for Seeded Productions to fulfill it's mission of regularly producing theatre that champions the artist as a whole. 

 

What We Need & What You Get

In order to make this dream a reality, we need your help: 

We're asking for about 3200 in total for the production of SUCKERS. Our venue alone costs around half that. The rest of your donations will go toward production costs (sets, costumes, props), marketing materials, and compensation for the playwright. 

We know your giving is generous! We've come up with some "sweet" (suckers, get it?) perks to make your donation a little more worth while!

  • $5  - THANK YOU! Sending you endless amounts of love and undying gratitude
  • $25 - Social Media Shout Out: From the up-and-coming Instagram account @seeded.productions
  • $40 - Promoting in Your Honor: We will shout you out on social media + promote a nonprofit of your choosing.
  • $75 - Program Mention: We'll list your name in the program given out to audience members during the run of the show. 
  • $100 - Sneak Peak: exclusive rehearsal footage sent directly to your inbox!
  • $150+ - We're SUCKERS for You: all of the above + we'll send you a sucker and a personalized note of gratitude

Even if we do not reach our intended monetary goal, we will honor your contributions and modify our allocated budgets as necessary. Don't worry, we're determined to make this project happen no matter what - we'll just get a little creative in our journey to get there (we're artists - we think on our feet for a living!).

 

Risks & Challenges

New York is hard. And often costly. But we're persistent and dedicated to our craft! We are determined to deliver a product we're proud of and that measures up to the quality of New York City theatre standards. 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

We know that money is often tight and not everyone can support financially. Here are other HUGE ways you can help!

  • Spread the word! Follow us on Instagram @seeded.productions and share our SUCKERS Facebook page.
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools!
  • Come see the show! SUCKERS will premiere at The Bridge Theatre in Midtown this August! It will run for 1 weekend only (Aug 9-11) so don't miss out! Tickets will be released soon.
  • If you're an artist, join us! We're always searching for new artists to collaborate with. (Photographers, lighting/sound designers, and stage managers needed for SUCKERS - email us at seededproductions@gmail.com).

And that's all there is to it.

story:
Short Summary

2018 marks the 35th Anniversary of Pepatian !

And this year is a new chapter in the history of the organization with the support and shared leadership of a local community of artists including Caridad De La Luz/La Bruja, and Board President Shanika Blount. Several key artists are project leaders, including: Rokafella, Fana Fraser, Milteri Tucker, Alicia Diaz, Beatrice Capote and Maleek Washington. 

Our strength rests in our relationships, collaborations, and creativity. 

We ask for your support to help make this shared leadership model and our upcoming projects a success !

 

What We Need & What You Get

Your $ helps with:

~ production costs for 2018 Dance Your Future: Artist & Mentor Collaborative Residency project;

~ supplementing teaching artists fees for upcoming workshops in Pepatian’s Hip-Hop Academy & Empowerment Collective projects;

~ production costs for Out of La Negrura/Out of Blackness in the Bronx: A Choreographic Collaboration Across Diaspora documentary film with artists Sita Frederick, Ana "Rokafella" Garcia, & Marion Ramirez.  

Your support is invaluable, thank you!

 

What you get:

Perks include shout outs on Facebook, credit in program,  listing as benefactor on Pepatian's website, free tickets to upcoming dance shows, DVD of new documentary film, Out of La Negrura/Out of Blackness in the Bronx: A Choreographic Collaboration Across Diaspora, including bonus videos AND Pepatian t-shirt.

The Impact

Your support makes it easier to do our work to connect Afro-Caribbean-Latinx and/or Bronx-based artists with local audiences. Pepatian has successfully produced these projects for years, and your help keeps it more possible to make great things happen in the Bronx ! 

 

Feel free to support this campaign by posting and telling others about it - Indiegogo offers plenty of share tools - thank you ! ! !

story:
Any time there is talk of a revival, especially one of a musical as important to people as Spring Awakening, it's important to start with why. Why now? Why us?

Luckily, Artistic Producer and Dramaturg Ali Sousa is so beautifully able to articulate what this production means to us, so we'll let her words do the talking. 

Why Now?

Ten years ago, when I was fourteen, I came home every day after school and listened to Spring Awakening. I was a gay teenager in a Catholic school, struggling with my faith, my sexuality, and the feeling of being trapped between childhood and adulthood; old enough to have questions but too young to have them answered. Spring Awakening hit me like a bolt of lightning, and my parents wholeheartedly disapproved. Despite their protests, I fell deeply in love with the show, and that feeling never faded — and my parents came around eventually. Years later, as an adult, I took my mom to the Broadway revival, and she finally understood.

Sheik and Sater began working on Spring Awakening in 1999, in the wake of the Columbine shooting. After the Parkland shooting last February, I found myself entirely consumed by Spring Awakening as if I were fourteen again. There was something about seeing teenagers in my home state become prominent activists against gun violence that pulled me towards the show. The notion that young people were so desperate to be heard in a world of adults who brushed them off as being too young to know what they were talking about had me thinking about Wendla, Melchior, and Moritz; three teenagers, doomed by their pursuit of knowledge they were deemed too young to have.

I began thinking about ways to do Spring again. I couldn’t shake the fixation. There is something heartbreaking, infuriating, and inspiring about the tenacity young people have in the face of a repressive environment. The present moment, more than it has in a long time, is calling for a show like Spring Awakening.

The Concept

I started thinking about the role of music in Spring Awakening, and how it frees the characters and allows them a space to express themselves in the song-world. And I started thinking about what happens when you take the concept of the song-world and really give the characters full, complete control of it by making them the orchestra. Tony Award-winning original Moritz John Gallagher Jr., in talking about his similarities to his character, describes how when he was a teenager, he would hide away in his room with his acoustic guitar, and that “for [him] and countless teenagers, music is such an integral part of maturing and growing up and escaping.” I’m so intrigued by what happens when we give Moritz that guitar and the same escape.

So, you have a full ten piece band, and a cast of eleven actors. I started considering what happens when you assign an instrument to someone, and have it truly be theirs -- no switch-offs, no doubling. You have a metaphor, ready-built. The instrument becomes the character’s voice -- their singular method of self-expression, unique to them, but essential to their community.

Alongside this musical environment, this visual of actor-musicians, of young people using music as a way to express themselves, conjured up a very specific physical environment for me: a DIY house show. House shows are often done in warehouses, garages, basements -- unconventional performance spaces that have been reclaimed for the purpose of self-expression. I’m thrilled by the notion that these characters would be able to claim a space as their own in a world that truly doesn’t allow them to speak for themselves, and proceed to use it to play rebellious rock music about love, sex, anger, abuse, and anything else their parents refuse to let them discuss. It creates a world where it’s plausible and believable for these characters to have these instruments, and drops them, in their 1890s clothing, directly into our world: 2019 Brooklyn, for the briefest of moments.

Why We Need Your Help

Surprise surprise, but putting on a show is expensive! 

Your money is going directly towards things like making sure we pay each and every member of our cast and crew, having space to rehearse, that our actor's instruments stay in good shape throughout the process, props and costumes, sound equipment, and much more. 

Conclusion

We are thrilled to be bringing this show to life, but we need your help to make it happen. All of the money raised will directly benefit the artists involved, making sure that everyone on our team is paid for their work. We have a passionate team of artists, a space to perform, and a concrete vision that will make this show great. All we need now is your support! Thank you for your generosity, and we hope to see you at Spring Awakening!

story:
Short Summary

My name is Saer Black and I am theater director and the founder of Cor Cordium Theatre Productions. Some might say beginning my own theatre company at the age 15 was far too ambitious but I had a goal, one that I intended to reach. I wanted to create a safe, exciting, and rewarding place for young artists to participate in theatre productions in the Los Angeles area. With some incredible support, and the amazing opportunity to work with such talented young artists, that 15-year-old was able to start a company that has gone on to produce numerous shows. Now a high school graduate, myself and my incredible team of support are so excited for our summer show, "13: The Musical" and thank you immensely for all the love!

Note: 10% of all donations will go directly to supporting art programs in schools. Thank you, thank you, thank you!
