story:
Wait, what is it again?

'100 years' will be a riotous, heartfelt journey through the century since we were first trusted with a tiny pencil and the privacy of the polling booth.

The show will be on at the Southwark Playhouse, London, on Monday 3rd December 2018.

Why are you asking me for help then?

Because we can’t make this crazy night of theatre that celebrates women’s history without your help.  So far, we’ve maxed out our own funds developing this project and hiring a theatre space. But we still need a little bit of help.

Your money will help us hire rehearsal space, create props, hire costumes and pay a technician for the show. Every little helps, and if we don’t make our target, your donations will still be a massive help towards these costs. And if by some feat of fate we make over our target, all that money will be put into the project to pay our wonderful team.

Everyone’s making theatre these days, why is this show different?

Without bumming you out too much, it still sucks for women to try and break into the creative industries. We created this show as a way to celebrate our collective history and to give as many women as possible the chance to further their career in the Arts. I know some of you won’t believe that being a woman is still a problem, but as aspiring screen and theatre writers, you only need to take one look at the Writers’ Guild stats to realise having a womb really does seem to freak the industry out.

http://writersguild.org.uk/equalitywrites/

But I’m too skint to donate, can I still help?

Hell yeah! You can still help us out by sharing this project with your networks and encouraging them to back our project. And if you want to help out in other ways, just follow us on Twitter and DM us - we can use all the help we can get!

Wait - who the hell are you anyway?!

Megan and Stevie are the founders of ROAR. We love untold stories, unexpected topics, chaos, laughs, absurdity, the political and the personal. We write about anything and everything.

As a female-led company, we are proudly feminist in our approach. Our stories often feature women in the leading role, but our work is for everyone to enjoy. We believe in equality and work with other writers, producers and directors to bring our projects together, whatever your gender.

Megan and Stevie met back in 2014 on the MA Screenwriting course at London College of Communication, and it’s been all go since then – including filling out the long-winded forms for Companies House…

  • Megan Toogood has been shortlisted in various competitions including BBC Writer’s Room drama window, T.S Eliot Prize at the Old Vic, the Crime Writer’s Association Debut Dagger award and the Launchpad novel manuscript competition. Her full length play Frost Fever Flood is in development with the support of Theatre 503.
  • Stevie Cooke is a comedy writer, who most recently has written for Have I Got News For You and the Radio 4 show Sketchtopia. Stevie was shortlisted for the Funny Women 2017 Writing Award and was a finalist in the Funny Women 2017 Shorts Award. She was recently long-listed for the BBC Comedy Writersroom 2018.

Contact us

Email: info@roarcreativeproductions.com

Twitter: @megtoogood - @steviecooke1985

Website: https://roarcreativeproductions.com/

story:
LET'S PLAY

We believe in character-driven stories presented through live, professional theatre at affordable admission prices. No matter your budget or geography, there are many ways you can support ON AN AVERAGE DAY.

In July 2014, we raised $1,270, nearly half of our projected budget, to mount our first co-production, DYING CITY by Christopher Shinn, at The Shadowbox Theatre (later named Old Marquer Theatre) in the Marigny. Through promotional efforts and community sponsorship, we enjoyed a 4-week run with audiences consisting of local patrons and theatre artists, family, friends and New Orleans visitors alike amidst the dog days of summer:

“...the distinctive performances by these two actors [Harris and Story] -- showing the interior battles each character struggles with, as well as the unique chemistry they reflect -- give “Dying City” its lively intensity.” --Theodore Mahne, Times Picayune/NOLA.com | Read complete review

“Director Garrett Prejean keeps the tone balanced, the tension sharp and the 90-minute intermission-less work well-paced. It’s a gripping work, bordering on psychological thriller, about the haze of memory and battle and revealing difficult truths.” --Will Coviello, Gambit Weekly | Read complete review

THE BUDGET

  • $2,250 Performance Run
  • $1,280 Licensing through Dramatists Play Service, Inc. for sixteen (16) performances
  • $1,000 Publicity & Press: Advertising, Posters, Postcards, Playbills
  • $1,500 Production Team: Fees, Incidentals, Materials
  • $450 Rehearsal space rental
  • $375 Venue Deposit

CONTRIBUTE TODAY

We have fun perks to choose from but will gladly accept donations of ANY amount. Every dollar counts. We also accept checks and money orders. Contact us at averagedaynola@gmail.com for more details.

OTHER WAYS TO HELP

Contact us (averagedaynola@gmail.com) Let us know if you want to donate 1950s-1980s electronics and kitchen appliances/wares to the show, if you know of a school or community organization offering rehearsal space, or if you're interested in volunteering in some capacity.

Like us on Facebook: www.facebook.com/AverageDayNOLA

Be "The Buzz" Use #AverageDayNOLA and share this video with fellow theatre-lovers!

Spread the word! Word-of-mouth is the best publicity.

See the play in January! We are so excited to share this production with you. You can buy tickets right now at www.bit.ly/averagedaynola
story_txt:
LET'S PLAYWe believe in character-driven stories presented through live, professional theatre at affordable admission prices. No matter your budget or geography, there are many ways you can support ON AN AVERAGE DAY.In July 2014, we raised $1,270, nearly half of our projected budget, to mount our first co-production, DYING CITY by Christopher Shinn, at The Shadowbox Theatre (later named Old Marquer Theatre) in the Marigny. Through promotional efforts and community sponsorship, we enjoyed a 4-week run with audiences consisting of local patrons and theatre artists, family, friends and New Orleans visitors alike amidst the dog days of summer:“...the distinctive performances by these two actors [Harris and Story] -- showing the interior battles each character struggles with, as well as the unique chemistry they reflect -- give “Dying City” its lively intensity.” --Theodore Mahne, Times Picayune/NOLA.com | Read complete review“Director Garrett Prejean keeps the tone balanced, the tension sharp and the 90-minute intermission-less work well-paced. It’s a gripping work, bordering on psychological thriller, about the haze of memory and battle and revealing difficult truths.” --Will Coviello, Gambit Weekly | Read complete reviewTHE BUDGET
$2,250 Performance Run
$1,280 Licensing through Dramatists Play Service, Inc. for sixteen (16) performances
$1,000 Publicity & Press: Advertising, Posters, Postcards, Playbills
$1,500 Production Team: Fees, Incidentals, Materials
$450 Rehearsal space rental
$375 Venue Deposit
CONTRIBUTE TODAYWe have fun perks to choose from but will gladly accept donations of ANY amount. Every dollar counts. We also accept checks and money orders. Contact us at averagedaynola@gmail.com for more details.OTHER WAYS TO HELPContact us (averagedaynola@gmail.com) Let us know if you want to donate 1950s-1980s electronics and kitchen appliances/wares to the show, if you know of a school or community organization offering rehearsal space, or if you're interested in volunteering in some capacity.Like us on Facebook: www.facebook.com/AverageDayNOLABe "The Buzz" Use #AverageDayNOLA and share this video with fellow theatre-lovers!Spread the word! story:
Short Summary

The Worcester Repertory Company was founded in the 1960s and has provided a home to many household names over the years. Imelda Staunton, Sean Pertwee, David Wood, Celia Imrie, Bonnie Langford, John Doyle, Phyllida Lloyd, Mark Strong and many others got their professional start with the Worcester Rep. and we continue to produce top quality professional theatre for our audiences.

This is our first crowdfunding campaign and we are looking for support in bringing a new piece of writing to the stage. Funding for the arts is a constant battle and one that many organisations lose. The Worcester Rep. has managed to survive with no Arts Council funding and still produces between 5 - 10 shows per year in venues across the county. 2016 saw our first international transfer with Ben Humphrey's production of The Comedy of Errors making its way to the National Theatre of Romania for the International Shakespeare Festival.

The Rep's work is beginning to catch the attentions of a wide demographic and your help in staging this production would be incredible.

 

What We Need & What You Get

The approximate total cost of producing An Unhealthy Cure will be £3,500.

Things we need to pay for when considering a new production:

Actors - This is really important!

Marketing - Getting people to come and see the play is probably the most important thing. Otherwise, there really is no point.

Stage Management/Production - Without the backstage team nothing would get seen onstage. 

All of this is before the writers get paid and knock on costs such as Box Office, ticketing and Front of House is taken into account.

By helping us to raise £1,500 you will be ensuring that new work remains on the stage and that a unique production is available for all to see. There are of course perks to donating to our campaign. Everything from acknowledgement in the programme to VIP treatment at the premiere. There are so many ways to be a part of the production.

 

The Impact

The great Stella Adler once said:

"Theatre was created to tell people the truth about life and the social situation."

By donating to our campaign you will be helping us, as a theatre, make that a reality. Live performance can be a life-changing experience and your donations help to keep theatre live.

The Worcester Rep's. work in recent years has been diverse and well-received. We perform in venues such as cathedrals, schools, theatres, halls, outdoor gardens and everywhere and anywhere in between. Some of our recent projects have included:

Outdoor performances; A transfer to the National Theatre of Romania; Theatre in Education projects in conjunction with Worcester Bosch and Worcester Cathedral, and we will also be staging a special production of Shakespeare's King John, at the tomb of the monarch on the 800th Anniversary of his death.

This production explores a subject that everyone can relate to. Cancer. It subverts the ideas we have of finding a cure and looks to create conversation and debate surrounding one of the biggest global killers. Everybody knows somebody...and everyone will have an opinion on the play.

The play will also be adapted for radio and recorded at the Old Smithy Studios.

The Worcester Repertory Company is a non-profit organisation and run by the Worcester Live Charitable Trust. If we are lucky enough to raise more than our target figure or the production makes money it will all be re-invested in producing work, supporting youth theatre, and keeping the arts alive in Worcestershire. Not a penny will go to shareholders...we don't have any!

 

Risks & Challenges

One of the biggest risks with staging new work is convincing people to invest in the time to come and see it. With audiences increasingly looking for 'star names' or TV celebrities, companies such as the Worcester Rep. must work much harder to bring the audiences into the theatre. This campaign is as much about creating awareness of the play as it is about fundraising.

The Worcester Rep. may be a small producing house but we punch above our weight with top quality work that always engages audiences.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Contributions to the campaign will obviously help us. There's no denying that. But for those who can't or don't feel able to contribute there are lots of other ways you can help:

  • Share the campaign with family and friends.
  • Follow us on Social Media and RT/share news about the production.
  • Buy a ticket for the show. We'd love to see you.
  • Join our mailing list to find out about other work we've got going on.

story:
The Idle Playthings have been accepted into PBH's Free Fringe (as part of the Edinburgh Fringe Festival in Scotland in August). This costs a lot of money (Just over £8000 in fact!) and we need as much help as we can get in order to make this an easier feat.

We've been raising money for two years and we're almost at a place where the costs are manageable with our performers paying a contribution each but we want to reduce this as much as possible so that the opportunity to go to the Fringe is not dictated by who can afford it.

That's where you guys come in! Any donation, no matter how big or small, makes all the difference to the Playthings. We can't wait to represent our society, our Students' Union and our University at an International level again - but we need your help to do it!

story:
Distorted Realities

Artistic Director Bio: 

Brigette Dunn-Korpela is the founder and Artistic director of  B. Dunn Movement, educator, choreographer and performing artist. Her educational credentials include an MFA in choreography from the California Institute of the Arts Sharon Disney Lund School of Dance and a B.A. in dance from the University of Massachusetts Amherst. Currently, Ms. Dunn-Korpela is an Assistant Professor of Dance in the department of Kinesiology at California State University, Northridge. She is an innovative artist who explores viscerally-authentic approaches towards creative self expression. Her performance credits include the 1st National U.S. tour of The Lion King. She has performed works by choreographers, Ronald K. Brown, Nathan Trice, Donald Mckayle and Katherine Dunham, to name a few and former member of the Cleo Parker Robinson Dance Ensemble. She has appeared at the Kennedy Center, Brooklyn Academy of Music, NJPAC, Aaron Davis Hall, and the Gomhouria Theatre of the Cairo Opera House, Egypt.

Project Description: 

Distorted Realities, is a 15-20 minute dance/theatre collaboration with six performers and artistic direction by Brigette Dunn-Korpela that will premier May 4-6, 2017 at the Bootleg Theater in Los Angeles, CA. This project is facilitated by Dance Resource Center's Homegrown @ Bootleg Series. A program that supports emerging choreographers in the L.A area promote and produce their work to larger audiences. Distorted Realities seeks to investigate the hyper-normalization of human apathy and sanitized violence. This work is in direct response to the current social climate of increased human indifference, deafening silence of human compassion and political lunacy. Movement investigations are athletically charged rooted in contemporary modern dance vocabulary. Creative research is influenced by Brutalist aesthetics, American and European 1940-50’s mass media culture and German expressionism. It is the hope of this work to observe the parallels in recent history where human indifference was normalized and sanitized.

What We Need & What You Get:

Our goal minimum goal is $5,000.00 

Dancer Fees-$3,000

Creative and Production Team Fees-$4,550

  • Costume Design
  • Set Design
  •  Production Manager
  •  Sound Editing
  •  Marketing/PR
  •  Rehearsal and Performance Fee
  •  Insurance Fees

The Impact:

By supporting Distorted Realities, you are helping B. Dunn Movement provide serious dance/theatre with thoughtful content that educates, challenges and offers a viscerally unique experience and creative perspective on current events. Distorted Realities underscores the serious dangers confronting this country and abroad and suggests ways of overcoming them. We are committed to helping our communities become actively involved in fighting human apathy and encourage human compassion for all human beings. 

Your financial support for our work is one small way you can bring positive change to a very challenging moment in our global community history. We are in an age that requires active participation from all of us.

We are in this together.

B. Dunn Movement is committed to social change and justice through art in all forms.B. Dunn Movement/Dance and Theatre Company is a performance art collective based in Los Angeles, California. Our mission is to provide in-depth creative expression through diverse art forms. BDMDTC encourages individuals to create art that encompases critical thinking and an awareness of the multilayered themes within a global community. In August 2015 we successfully toured our full length interdisciplinary performance piece ECHO. With a cast and crew of 12 members we traveled  to Boston for a 2 week residency at the Multicultural Arts Center Cambridge, MA. We were well received with 4 sold out performances, community workshops and post-show Q&A. ECHO continues to perform throughout the L.A. community and beyond through lecture/demonstrations, international dance conferences, video presentations, workshops and special performances. This is our commitment to you, to create art that inspires positive change in local and global communities. 

Full Review Huffington Post http://www.huffingtonpost.com/tricia-elam-walke...

Other Ways You Can Help:

Even if you can't make a contribution, you can still have an impact on our success, by spreading the word.  Please share our fundraising campaign with your friends, family, co-workers, strange people you meet on the subway, your neighbor, mailman, your plumber, and anyone else who is feeling confused and scared and could use some thought-provoking, inspiring dance/theatre that can help them make a difference in this world. Promote us on Facebook and Twitter and Instagram. Send out the carrier pigeons. Drop flyers from a plane. Every and anyway you can support our work is a gift, for which we will be forever grateful. 

Additional means of support:

  • Attend the performance of Distorted Realities at Bootleg Theatre on May 4-6, 2017. 
  • Volunteer with us!

For information on our upcoming events and how to get involved, please visit our website www.bdunnmovement.com or Like us on Facebook.

Thank you in advance for your support. I know that together we can make positive change locally and globally!

Art for Change!!!

story:
Hi there!

This is Jason Weiss, the director of Magiko.

About a year ago, I saw my good friend Siegfried Tieber perform in his sold out solo show at the Hollywood Fringe Festival. The show was a smashing success and I was incredibly impressed with both his performance and his ability to craft such a dynamic one man show. Shortly after Siegfried's show closed, I asked him if he'd ever be interested in collaborating on a project. To my delight he was excited by the idea and said he would be thrilled to work together, and as soon as the muse stuck him, he would let me know. Fast forward several months, and I get a call from him asking me if I'd like to grab a coffee (coffee is a big part of our lives). I of course accepted and met him at my corner coffee shop, Dialog Café. Over a delicious Ethiopian dark roast, Siegfried pitched me on an idea for a new solo show, and the rest, as we say, is history!

Siegfried and I have written an incredible solo show that he is staring in and I am directing, and it's called:

UPDATE 7/12/15 with 5 hours left to go!!!!

We're on the cusp of reaching our goal! The person who get's us to 100% is going to get a very special "Thank you" from Siegfried and Jason...will it be you?


UPDATE 7/8/15:


UPDATE 7/3/15:



UPDATE 6/14/15


MAGIKO.


We are incredibly proud of Magiko, and want to share our show with the world. This is where you come in.

Siegfried and I are taking Magiko to the Edinburgh Fringe Festival, where we have been accepted into one of the most prestigious and successful venues there, Spotlites.


The Edinburgh Fringe Festival is the world's largest arts festival, with the 2014 event spanning 25 days and featuring over 3,193 shows from 51 countries in 299 venues. Established in 1947 as an alternative to the Edinburgh International Festival, it takes place annually in Scotland's capital, in the month of August. The Fringe is a showcase for the performing arts, with show categories including Cabaret, Children's shows, Comedy, Dance, Physical Theatre & Circus, Events, Exhibitions, Music, Musicals and Opera, Spoken Word and Theatre. 

The Fringe has been host to some of the top names in the entertainment industry, and this year, our names will join them.


Your support in this endeavor will enable us to take Magiko! to the highest possible levels.


Here’s what your support would do for us:


Why do we want to go to Edinburgh? 

There is no better way to gain World-Wide exposure than at the Edinburgh Fringe Festival, and the exposure we get there will enable us to accomplish our overall goal of bringing Magiko! back to one of the many amazing theatres in Los Angeles for a full run,  and eventually on to New York City. Your support combined with our hard work can make all of this a reality. Perhaps you've heard of some of the artists and plays that have graced the stages of the Fringe:

The Perks:

As a thank you to all of our supporters, every level of support comes with a great perk. We have Signed photos, Personalized videos, Tickets to our Los Angeles Previews, Props used in the production,  Private shows, Acting classes, Associate Producer credits and many many more. At the highest levels of support, we're offering exclusive corporate events and even 10% ownership of the show in perpetuity.

Other Ways You Can Help..... 

There are many ways to support Magiko!, aside from our perk program, you can always, share the link to this Indigogo page & follow us on Twitter too: @Magikolive.  Indigogo makes it easy - just use the share tools.

Here's the link to our page of the: Fringe Festival Program.

Here's the link to our venue page: Spotlites

Thanks to your generous support, what began with a toast and a handshake back in 2014 is now, a reality! 

Thank you for your support!

story:
About This Project

Myself, Charlotte Deutsch, Claire Marx, Michael Dreger, & Andrew Forbes are busy working with some amazing performers to create a reading/concert of my new, original musical/potential radio play. This is my senior thesis, so let me provide some background:

I was born in suburban Minnesota, where conservative politics squashed my queer, feminist agenda. I escaped to Perpich Center for Arts Education to study music & theatre, where I met my collaborator Charlotte Deutsch, (Director), and began writing some of the very songs in this musical. After a brief stint in New York, I found myself in Seattle studying playwriting at Cornish College of the Arts with amazing artists like Claire, Andrew, and Michael.

I created this piece intending to write a musical with parts for every under-utilized actress I’d known over the years. This mission evolved to include the frequently excluded gender-queer artists, & addresses issues ranging from sexuality, suicidality & mental illness to ableism in academia & global warming. All within a freshman dorm during a Hurricane!

Perks & Pre-requisites

Unfortunately, I don’t know any audio engineers who are currently available to work with me at a discounted rate. And I never found time to learn notation really well in 11th grade AP Music Theory. And we really want a lot of people all over to hear this thing. So:

  • We need $750:

    • $100 for button & poster design & printing

    • $200 for a live sound engineer

    • $100 for an engineer to refine the recording

    • $200 to pay my team of notators

    • $150 to pay the 15 person cast & crew a little something beyond pizza.

  • In return, you get so many perks!!! Ranging from reserved seats to your name in the script to a copy of the CD & performance, there is an option for every person, near or far.

  • If we don’t reach our goal, I will have to get a third job because these amazing professionals deserve to be paid for their service to our collective story. For real.

Why give now? What’s the impact?

Not suited for those under 12.

Some facts:

  • This musical passes the Bechtal test with nearly every scene!

  • You've heard of rock musicals right? Well, this is a folk/indie musical. All live, all acoustic. 

  • It comes after a successful 5 years performing these very songs to acclaim in Minnesota, Bronxville, LA, and Seattle. Plus 4 brand new songs!

  • This isn’t your great Aunt Tilly’s musical theatre. Real characters in real life situations- people like you, mattering to each other. 

  • Not suited for those under 12.

This is a deviation from the musical theatre classics- which are often based in patriarchal, colonialist values and service to the industry. This is all about making tight harmonies, dirty jokes, and points about the millennial condition. Take a diverse group of 8 women and 1 genderqueer person, add whisky, confined space, & a hurricane. Mix. 
This piece is for all the “Freaks” on the fringes, the “Misfits” of the mainstream. For all the women, men, and those in between, being told to fit someone else’s mold. Help me change the face of musical theatre by introducing a piece that represents voices in our community that continually go unheard!!

Risks & Challenges

I have truly spent most of my time & all my life savings to pursue my dreams to get an education in theatre & music. And I did it! And...now I’m broke as heck, with a lot of scripts. My hope is that this musical will be more than just a thesis. I want to see if this thing could go viral. I want it to be Podcasted & shared across as many platforms as possible; I’ll be submitting it to more than 8 festivals this year alone.

We are working with a highly qualified artistic team & a producer who’s already run several successful fundraising campaigns. The only risk is that we don’t acquire the funds needed to produce the show well. For that, we need your help.

This production is the beginning of a journey- one that I hope will open doors for more than just me. In the beginning of this new phase, I am supported by an incredible army of professionals whose talent and dedication to their craft astounds me every day.

Other Ways To Help!

I know circumstances mean some of my biggest fans and supporters cannot monetarily contribute. There are other ways to help!

  • Share & like posts about this project!

  • Help us find a great audio engineer!

  • Come rock out at the free show! 

  • Just be you. 

Together, we got this. Let’s make a musical.
story_txt:
About This ProjectMyself, Charlotte Deutsch, Claire Marx, Michael Dreger, & Andrew Forbes are busy working with some amazing performers to create a reading/concert of my new, original musical/potential radio play. This is my senior thesis, so let me provide some background:I was born in suburban Minnesota, where conservative politics squashed my queer, feminist agenda. I escaped to Perpich Center for Arts Education to study music & theatre, where I met my collaborator Charlotte Deutsch, (Director), and began writing some of the very songs in this musical. After a brief stint in New York, I found myself in Seattle studying playwriting at Cornish College of the Arts with amazing artists like Claire, Andrew, and Michael.I created this piece intending to write a musical with parts for every under-utilized actress I’d known over the years. This mission evolved to include the frequently excluded gender-queer artists, & addresses issues ranging from sexuality, suicidality & mental illness to ableism in academia & global warming. All within a freshman dorm during a Hurricane!Perks & Pre-requisites Unfortunately, I don’t know any audio engineers who are currently available to work with me at a discounted rate. And I never found time to learn notation really well in 11th grade AP Music Theory. And we really want a lot of people all over to hear this thing. So:
We need $750: 

$100 for button & poster design & printing
$200 for a live sound engineer
$100 for an engineer to refine the recording
$200 to pay my team of notators
$150 to pay the 15 person cast & crew a little something beyond pizza.

In return, you get so many perks!!! Ranging from reserved seats to your name in the script to a copy of the CD & performance, there is an option for every person, near or far.
If we don’t reach our goal, I will have to get a third job because these amazing professionals deserve to be paid for their service to our collective story. For real.
Why give now? What’s the impact?Not suited for those under 12. Some facts:
This musical passes the Bechtal test with nearly every scene!

story:
Better Stipends for the Cast of 'Judgement Call'

Hi, I'm Vivian Allvin, an actress in the Washington DC area (having performed at NextStop Theater, the Kennedy Center, Theater J, Venus Theater, in film/VO etc.) with a gypsy background (I was born in Brazil and raised in Italy). I'm also a mom, translator/interpreter, teacher...

I'm appealing to you to fund better stipends for the very talented cast helping me get my first full-length comedy on its feet:

  • I've written a short metaphysical comedy named "Judgement Call', which follows the story of a soul (Nick) as he embarks on his earthly journey, anxiously followed by 9 very well-meaning but very flawed 'Spirit Guides'.  I'm thrilled to get the opportunity to stage a reading of it as part of NextStop Theatre's Dark Nights Series on July 25, 2016.
  • I've been in a few staged reading and full productions as an actor. Some stipends were generous. Some barely covered gas money.
  • Let's co-create a model in which actors and other creative tribes can thrive, experiment with new possibilities, and be adequately compensated.


What We Need & What You Get

  • I'm working towards a goal of $1500. This will allow me to pay each actor on stage (and one voice over actor creating sound effects) $150.
  • In thanks, we will send you a flyer signed by the cast, rehearsal photograph and unique anecdote/blooper.
  • If I don't reach my goal, I will fund a $100 stipend personally. Whatever you wish to contribute helps!

The Impact

We all do what we have to. But I'm tired of seeing so many 'starving artists' (like myself!) working 2-3 jobs just to be able to be in a play. Let's change that!

  • Let's make playing (in a theatre as well as in a broader, human sense) sustainable!
  • Let's fill the world with thriving artists, one passion project at a time.
  • The truth is (not to throw in unhealthy rewards), a thriving artist is much more likely to buy you drinks than to whine about rejection rates at auditions. Just sayin'.

Risks & Challenges

Hurdles:

  • I don't have a huge social network. And worry about mixing personal and business matters.
  • Please, no pressure! Contribute only if you feel so inclined!

Other Ways You Can Help

Needless to say, you don't have to participate financially. It'd be great if you could help us spread the word by sharing with friends, via FB, other social media, by email etc. And if you don't feel inspired to be a part of this adventure, thank you nonetheless for reading this far! And break a leg on your personal journey and passion project! Onward and upward!

story:
Have you ever gone to the theater, spent money on parking, tickets, a plastic cup of wine, hoping to have a grand night annnd the production was awful? Yeah, this ISN't that! We gotchu. Come experience real acting, a beautiful production and a master playwright. The wine is on us. The purpose of our Theater Company is to provide Manhattan with top-notch performances, beautiful aesthetics and relevant theatre. 

This Masterpiece is performed by Marianne Goodell, Marc Lombardo, Daniele King and David Joseph Volino. Directed by Andrea Dantas (Fragmented Frida - www.fragmentedfrida.com)

story:
You helped us make our first goal.  NOW...what about next year?

Here's the story....

We lost a $7000 grant!

YOU:  Wait, what?  What grant did you lose?

SCOTT:  Each year for about a decade, New Musicals Inc. has received approximately $6,000-$7,000 from the City of Los Angeles' Department of Cultural Affairs, which we've used for two main purposes:  to offer free admission to our concert readings, and towards Elise's salary.

YOU:  That sounds good.  What went wrong?

SCOTT:  Nothing went wrong, per se...but the City told us that their grants aren't meant for ongoing permanent support of salaries...they want to fund performances for large amounts of people who can't afford expensive tickets.  They have urged us to apply again when we have a project which has a LOT of tickets which we can give away, rather than supporting our Artistic Director's salary.

YOU:  Oh, no!  Does that mean poor Elise isn't going to get paid?

SCOTT:  Poor Elise indeed (says Scott, pulling out the Sympathy Card); yes, the grant money was allocated for her.  To be honest, but Elise and I would both take cuts in pay if we're not successful in raising $7000 from somewhere...but You feel much more sympathy and love towards Elise than towards me, so we're focusing the campaign on her.

YOU:  Smart move.

SCOTT:  (wipes a silent tear).

YOU:  But wait.  Are you saying Elise makes only $7000?

SCOTT:  Elise's salary is more than that; there is money in our budget to pay her for about half-time salary; the rest of the money we scramble every year to find; and now we have to scramble for the usual money plus the $7000 we were counting on from the grant.

YOU:  Oh, you guys!  You're always raising money, it seems.

SCOTT:  It's actually a little worse than we're making it sound...because we didn't get the City grant this year, and we've been discouraged from applying for the next funding cycle...so we're actually down two years' worth of funding...$14,000.

YOU:  Got it.  So what if I can't give $14,000?  Can I give less?

SCOTT:  Absolutely.  We're suggesting a minimum contribution of $50...but it would be tremendous if you're able to start higher than that.

YOU:  Is my donation tax-deductible?

SCOTT:  It is. 

YOU:  All right; I want to help Elise.  How do I contribute?

SCOTT:  Just click one of the "perks" which corresponds to the level of your contribution.  Spoiler alert:  they're not really perks...no tickets, or books, or restaurant coupons -- we're saving those for our annual Holiday Auction next month.  These "perks" are intangible ones, like "Elise will pick a day on the calendar and think about YOU all day long...or a half-day for the lower amounts."

YOU:  Got it.  Glad to help.

SCOTT:  Thanks.

If you'd like to donate in an amount different from those in the Perks, just hit the red "BACK IT" button, and you can type in whatever amount you'd like.

 

A sly aside from Elise:

(Shh...don't tell Scott that we all know you guys helped make our first goal because you pitied ME!  He's a little jealous.  So let's dedicate the second stretch goal to Scott.  (He doesn't need to know you're giving still because of ME...)

story:
Our Story

VERSIPELLIS is the premiere production of two contemporary fusion dancers, Bevin Victoria and Danielle Elizabeth. Bevin Victoria has been a fusion BellyDancer for 4 years. Prior to that she was a nationally ranked sparring champion in Tae Kwon Do, and competitive gymnast for 10 years. She currently holds certifications as a Personal Fitness Trainer, Competitive Gymnastics coach and has many years of training in classical ballet and acro dance among other styles. Danielle Elizabeth holds a degree in fine arts and contemporary dance and has bellydanced for twelve years, with many serious side ventures into the worlds of Butoh Dance Theater and Traditional Balkan Dance, amongst a few other forms. 

Originally, this project had been the brainchild of Bevin Victoria for a number of years, and was best described as a series of choreographed pieces loosely based around the idea of primitive human needs/desires, their effects on our relationships with the world around us and how they cause us to shape-shift in order to be fulfilled. The idea of the 'shape-shifter' became a theme in many of her pieces and the exploration of this became more and more urgent until finally, it had to manifest in the show she had imagined for so long. After asking her highly esteemed fellow dancer (and yes, good friend) Danielle to co-produce, the production has come to life with a whole new flavor and some completely unexpected twists. Danielle has created a second aspect of VERSIPELLIS based on her personal main focus over the past few years as a dancer: the connection between live music and dance. She collected an ensemble of musicians that have agreed to compose completely original pieces for the show and she will compliment each choreography by directing structured improvisations based around the common themes. Together Bevin and Danielle have built a show based on their dual loves of contemporary dance and belly dance, with their strong desire to take it to the stage in an intimate theater setting where subtlety and nuance can become utterly heartbreaking and the larger picture will enrapture entirely.


The Impact

Our greatest hope for this production is to enlighten multiple genres to each other's presence and create a piece art of that sets a standard and precedent for future belly dance performances. 
We want to elevate everyone in the community specifically highlighting the artistry and dynamism that exists between dance and music and celebrates that connection while producing a show that helps the viewer to understand these themes that inspire us on the stage and in life. We want to celebrate art and life through dance and also inspire other performing artists to push themselves and each other so that quality pieces are the mainstay and we all feel good about the projects being made in the belly dance community.
Dance and theater are temporal art forms, but we feel they are just as valuable and precious as the beloved painting that adorns your living room wall, or the intricately carved bronze statue that graces your coffee table or the series of moving pictures sitting on your shelf in the form of DVD's.   

Portland, Oregon is turning into a mecca for belly dance fusion in this country. An over-saturation of sorts tends to happen when a community has more artists than patrons, which in turn, can also mean that new and ground-breaking projects, like VERSIPELLIS, sometimes don't get funded. We strongly believe that there is enough support in this community to encourage the growing number of incredible artists, specifically in this genre however, we want to do one better: we want to create a template for future shows as an example of how professional artists can be sustained by their art. Think about your profession... most people had to go to school, get certified, practice, apprentice or invest a significant amount of time to do what they do. Dancers and musicians are no different. We simply want to support not only the dancers in this show but also, on a larger scale, support the concept that good, dedicated artists can be sustained by their community. We want to keep creating interesting, thought-provoking, engaging pieces of art to simply, put more beauty in the world. Besides, when has more beautiful things to look at ever been a bad thing...? 

To put it simply, if our project doesn't receive the funding we hope for, "the show must go on". Coming out of our pockets for the production, however, will greatly decrease and/or diminish our ability to set the standard we want to set for this type of work. It will also make it impossible for us to reproduce this show anytime in the near future. We need help to compensate our artists and to represent them in the context of this show in a way that will elevate and appreciate their wonderful talents!



What We Need & What You Get


For VERSIPELLIS to come to life the way we envision it we need at least $800

This project is really a huge undertaking for us and in order for it manifest our breakdown looks a little something like this:

$400= the cost of dancer/musician rehearsal salaries. Did we mention that there are original LIVE compositions, intricately choreographed pieces AND dancer/musician improvised pieces? We want nothing more than for VERSIPELLIS to be an example of how artists can be sustained by pouring their blood, sweat and tears into their creations!

It takes some hardcore studio time to orchestrate this folks... trust us!

$250= opening night theatre rental

$150= second night theatre rental


Now, as you may notice, this doesn't account for the myriad other expenses associated with a production of this caliber. Some of these things are:

Marketing materials like postcards, newspaper ads, flyers, posters and the photo shoots that have to produce the photos to go on said materials 

Costuming 

Studio rental space for rehearsals

Lighting and Sound Technicians

Travel Expenses for the cast and crew


Most of these expenses will be covered in part by our ticket sales, although many of our wonderful and talented fellow community members have donated their time and services to the project. If we exceed this funding goal we can reimburse them! YAY! Also, it will allow us to get more creative with our costuming, hair, make-up, lighting and spend more on mastering the soundtrack for higher quality recordings of the genius work of our composers! All to provide an even more awesome experience for the audience.



Other Ways You Can Help

During the performance we would like to have a few vendors in the lobby vending related goods (dance wear, art based on the theme of the show, etc). If you are a vendor interested in vending for a minimal fee please contact us about how to apply


Even if you cant make it out to our show, please invite five of your friends (via our facebook page).

story:
In early 2009, Rich, a shop teacher in the Chicago Public School system sent a group of high school students to FreeGeek Chicago, including a curious and funny 15 year-old named Axel. Over the past two and a half years, Axel has torn down countless PCs, helped us with all manner of Spanish translation, seen our toughest growing pains, and become our most valuable volunteer in the laptop room.


This September, Axel is heading off to the University of Illinois at Chicago to pursue a degree in engineering or computer science. His family wants him to have paid work for the summer, so he’s applied for a job at CVS.

For $3,000, we can save Axel from CVS and give him an awesome job. Axel should be FreeGeek Chicago’s summer laptop intern. A laptop intern will increase FreeGeek’s capacity to sustain ourselves through sales of our modestly priced ($50-$100!) laptops and help stabilize our growth. An internship at FreeGeek will give Axel a nice line on what promises to be a long, exciting resume.

FreeGeek is a labor of love, and there are few people we love more than Axel. But love isn’t always enough to pay the bills or provide an internship. We’re proud we have yet to accept any grant or foundation funding. Our sustainability is rooted in the incredible efforts of our volunteers, who deserve the best we can give them. With your financial support, we can remain independent, improve and enrich our volunteer programs, and expand to meet the demand for practical technology hardware, access, and skills.


Axel's internship benefits FreeGeek by:

  • Expanding our laptop sales: Our biggest pain point, our most important revenue source, and a lynchpin of our future as the world goes mobile.
  • Keeping the laptop room organized: Between Axel's contributions and the help of volunteers, the laptop room will finally run smoothly.
  • Getting our sole employee some help: When there's a looming recycling run, a donation to receive, or errands to run, Axel's presence will be invaluable.


Axel starts June 21st. We'd like to raise $1,000 in the next week to know that the investment in Axel’s wages, tools and equipment, and administrative overhead will work. We’ll need $2,000 more in the next month to cover the full 10 week internship ($10/hour, 20 hours/week; $1,000 in equipment and overhead). All donations that exceed the final published internship budget will go towards recycling fees.


Your support will have have tangible benefits. Because of some generously donated high-def video equipment and an equally dedicated volunteer, an internship for Axel means we can begin developing a bilingual online video series about laptop repair. We’d love to thank you in the credits. Having Axel around also means we can track our work more effectively: This fall, we’ll release a report on the internship’s impact on FreeGeek’s financial sustainability, and provide laptop room reports at community council meetings. Axel has offered to personally thank any public contributor to the campaign.


If you’d like to make an anonymous cash donation, just come visit and ask any on-duty staff person to make a donation. We’ll pass around a hat at the end of every OpenBuild day, too. As much as we need your money, we hope that you come in, meet Janet, and fix some laptops, organize some shelves, make a video, or drink a cup of coffee and soak it in.
story_txt:
In early 2009, Rich, a shop teacher in the Chicago Public School system sent a group of high school students to FreeGeek Chicago, including a curious and funny 15 year-old named Axel. Over the past two and a half years, Axel has torn down countless PCs, helped us with all manner of Spanish translation, seen our toughest growing pains, and become our most valuable volunteer in the laptop room.This September, Axel is heading off to the University of Illinois at Chicago to pursue a degree in engineering or computer science. His family wants him to have paid work for the summer, so he’s applied for a job at CVS.


For $3,000, we can save Axel from CVS and give him an awesome job. Axel should be FreeGeek Chicago’s summer laptop intern. A laptop intern will increase FreeGeek’s capacity to sustain ourselves through sales of our modestly priced ($50-$100!) laptops and help stabilize our growth. story:
THE SHOW:

Kubrilesque: or a Musical Parody with a Tease, combines burlesque with many styles of dance and talents. The beauty and talent of the performers makes Kubrilesque a cohesive piece of art and the ultimate showgirl experience. The story is a chronological parody of the 12 fims of Stanley Kubrick, while telling a story about a man making his final film.

WHAT WE'RE DOING:

The cast and crew of Kubrilesque have put in a lot of work, making Kubrilesque a joy to watch or to be a part of. We haven't been on tour in two years, but we've taken the time to work on a killer score and the video featured on this page. We are planning on touring the show again, with some new music starting in the Summer of 2013. We need some assistance getting the cast's travel expenses paid. That is what this fundraiser is for. All the money from this fundraiser will go directly towards planefare, gas, and travel expenses for the cast. We'll need much more than $500, but its our goal for indiegogo, just to get us started.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

  • get the word out about our campaign.
  • tell any press that might interested in covering our show next year
  • If you have any new or used costumes, lighting or sound equipment, a recording studio, a bus or van (in any condition), hotel vouchers, food gift cards, or gas cards, we'll gladly take any donation that can help us reach our goal of touring Kubrilesque

THANK YOU!

story:
WHO WE ARE

BreakLA

BreakLA was founded two summers ago by a small group of friends who wanted to do something big - to create a major breakdance competition at UCLA. Coinciding with Hip Hop Appreciation week, we were able to expose an audience that was familiar with choreographed dance, but not necessarily b-boying. The event strives to not only expose people to this often stereotyped genre, but also showcase the immense athleticism and dedication of these dancers.

It was a great success, composed of some of the most talented b-boys on the West Coast, but we really want to expand the event. This year will be a big step forward for us where we will be expanding in all directions: increasing the size of the venue, the expected attendance, and most importantly, the quality of performances. The event will feature a slew of internationally recognized hip hop artists, including world champions and runners-up in breakdancing, hip hop choreography, and beatboxing. Please view and read about our performers on our website.

Having some amazing guests also means a lot of airfare and hotels to pay for! While we’ve been fundraising all year, there are only so many bobas and sandwiches that we can sell. This is where we need your help!

 

Battle Royale

Battle Royale is one of the biggest events hosted by any student organization on the UCLA campus hosted annually by the gentlemen of Omega Sigma Tau. It showcases the campus' four main dance teams -- ACA Hip Hop, NSU Modern, Samahang Modern, and VSU Modern -- and brings people from all over Southern California to see the competition for the Battle Royale Belt and the title of UCLA's best dance crew. In the past, the event has attracted over 1,400 attendees with celebrity judges such as Yuri Tag of Kaba Modern and Taeko Carroll of Fysh N Chicks.

This year, Battle Royale and BreakLA have combined to expand to a larger venue and audience.

 

What We Need & What You Get

This event is completely organized by student volunteers and we’ve been working hard to get this event together! Unfortunately, we've just been left in the lurch by two organizations that had promised to help us sell tickets -- to the tune of $7000. We've redoubled our efforts, but without your help, we really aren't sure how we're going to make this dream a reality. 

 

$3,000 for Venue Staff: While we’d love to manage the event ourselves free of charge, we aren’t qualified to work as the security, technicians, or stage builders who will make this event safe and run smoothly! We need to make sure we have the funds to pay for their hard work. Without these funds, our event will not happen!

$2,000 for Transportation & Housing:

-Airfare for b-boys from Korea and around the United States

-Gas for shuttling talent between the airport, hotel, and UCLA

-Hotels for housing our performers

-Parking for dance crews and other talent

 

Of course, your help will be rewarded with some fantastic perks:

 

$50+ Swag it Up!

A ticket to the event + BreakLA Tank Top

 

$100+ The Inside Scoop!

All of the above + a BreakLA Tank with signatures from all our staff

 

$250+ Starstruck!

All of the above + a BreakLA Tank with signatures from artists of your choosing

 

$500+ Behind the Scenes!

All of the above + an exclusive invitation to the tech rehearsal of the show and a chance to meet some of the dancers and artists

 

If we somehow exceed our goal, we’d be, first of all, ecstatic(!), and secondly, promise that every bit of the money we receive from this will go to the event. Some examples are: better stage set-up (we went with the bare minimum to save on costs), gas for our volunteers to shuttle our performers from the airport, to hotels, to the event, and any other surprises/unforeseen costs (they seem to pop up every so often!)

 

The Impact

Our goal is to spread Hip Hop awareness on the UCLA campus and teach people the stylistic qualities of various aspects of Hip Hop that make it so prevalent today. Instead of reinforcing the negative stereotypes that plague the Hip Hop genre, we want to show the audience our performers’ commitment to their craft and their individuality. In addition, we wish to present Hip Hop as a viable form of expressing oneself through our various performances.

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that you might not be in a position to contribute financially at this time. But there are many other ways you can help us make BreakLA a success:

  • Spread the word to your social network on Facebook, Twitter, your school, work, neighborhood, etc.

  • Post flyers around your school campus, neighborhoods, dance schools, and other venues

  • Give some support in the comments or through social media below

  • Come to the show April 26, 2013

We're on Facebook, Twitter and Youtube, if you want to stay up to date on this show:

  • Join our Facebook Event Page

  • Like our Facebook Page

  • Send us a tweet @BreakLA

  • Subscribe to our YouTube Channel

Thank you for your support!

story:
UPDATE JUNE 21: Hi friends!  We have just one week left in our campaign!  Thank you to everyone who donated- we really appreciate your support.  Please share this page with everyone you know- we still have a ways to our goal!  The show is selling very well, so if you have any questions about purchasing tickets, please contact Sarah Benvenuti at sarah@thecivilians.org as soon as possible. 

Thank you again for all of your support!

 

What is Be the Death of Me?

The Civilians, the center for investigative theater, takes its singular brand of creative investigation in a bold new direction with Be the Death of Me, an installation performance piece that offers the audience intimate encounters with matters of life and death in New York City. The audience will navigate their experience inside the atmospheric Irondale Center, housed in a historic church in Fort Greene, Brooklyn. Through a dynamic variety of settings and formats, the audience encounters real stories gathered from a wide cross-section of New Yorkers - everyone from ER nurses to priests, funeral directors to vampires, shamans to crime-scene cleaners. Through this myriad of perspectives, Be the Death of Me uncovers hidden worlds inside New York - places inhabited by those that witness the demise of our bodies, as well as those that imagine what may or may not happen to our souls on the other side of life. Be the Death of Me draws on months of interviews conducted by a team of Civilians' artistic volunteers.

Who is this artistic team?

The Death team is the largest ever to work on a Civilians’ production.  Over 70 writers, dramaturgs, designers, actors, and other artists have come together to create unique, two-night performance where the audience is an integral part of the work. 

“But Civilians,” you ask, “did all these amazing artists just donate their time to you?!”

Indeed, they did!  This veritable army of artistic volunteers has contributed countless hours to interviews, transcription, creative inquiry, and other integral parts of the investigative process. Be the Death of Me truly would not exist without each and every one of these artists’ input - which is why we need your help! 

Support these fantastic artists!

With a show of this magnitude, each artists’ input was invaluable.  Therefore, your gift will help us to show the artists how much we value their collaboration by enabling us to pay them even a symbolic stipend for their work.  By giving to this campaign, you will be giving directly to the over 70 individuals involved with creating Death and help us show our appreciation for their time, dedication, and creativity.

Already given? Please help us spread the word! You can share this link with family, friends, Facebook friends, and even strangers if you prefer.  Every dollar earned is another dollar going into the hands of a hard-working artist.

Want a sneak peek?

At the June 28 and 29 performances, audiences will each have a unique experience as they wander through the Irondale Center and experience the many distinctive personalities that our artists met with over the past six months. Here’s just a peek at some of the stories they uncovered:

"I liken death to a hot air balloon that there are many ropes that tether the balloon once it's full of hot air it wants to rise and leave the ground, leave the earth. But those very thick ropes leave it tethered to the ground, and sometimes those ropes are fear, sometimes they're a very strong relationship, and we think about all the threads that connect you to your mother or your sister, or your brother. You kind of have to let some of those threads go, and you actually need to receive permission from your loved ones." - Anonymous, Cancer Nurse

"Death gives everything such beautiful meaning. To live forever, you just wouldn't do anything. People already know they're going to die and they just sit around and watch television - that's death as much as anything else... I think maybe people should, periodically, have guns put to their heads."
- Brandon, Former Embalmer

"If you want to be buried in New York City, you need a lot of money, or a family member who already has a plot, or you just get lucky with immediate internment, otherwise you're probably going to be buried in New Jersey."
- Allison, Cemetery Tour Guide/Historian

To learn more about the show and to see the curent list of participating artists, visit www.thecivilians.org/current/death_of_me.html.

*DISCLAIMER:  The Civilians cannot guarantee the validity of our deals with devils, gods, goddesses, reapers, angels, demons, and other cosmic deities concerning lifespans, reincarnation, immortality, and/or steins of beer to follow in the afterlife.  Please note that taking advantage of the onsite bar could invalidate such said agreements.

The Civilians

The Civilians is the center for investigative theater, supporting the development and production of new theater from creative inquiries into the most vital questions of the present. The Civilians expands the scope of American theater and champions innovation by tackling complex and under-explored subjects, enabling artists to enrich their processes through in-depth interaction with their topics, diversifying artistic voices and audiences, and integrating theater with new media. Development often involves community residencies, travel, face-to-face conversations, and extensive research. This high degree of engagement with the public continues into production, inviting the audience to be active participants through ongoing channels of dialogue. The company provides a home for a multi-disciplinary group of artists and partners with regional theater and arts presenters in New York, nationally, and internationally. 

Want to learn more about The Civilians? Visit www.thecivilians.org or contact us at 718-230-3330.

The above video was created by Max Kaplun: www.maxkaplun.com.

The above video was created by Max Kaplun: www.maxkaplun.com.

story:
About the project

Hi! We are PE|Mo, a collaboration between HATLO (theater) and Rosa Vissers (dance). Since 2011 we create experimental performance works that incorporate unpredictable social arrangements, physical risk, and alternative narratives.

For the past year we’ve been working on our biggest creative baby to date: Anatomy of an Accident. Presupposing accident as organism – we have been studying local and national accidents using the lens of anatomical research to expose their complex, layered nature. Now we are asking for your support to bring this piece to audiences November 6-8 and 13-15, 2015.

We hope you’ll pitch in! And of course come see the shows :)

Photo by Tim Summers

The difference you make (aka you're our hero)

With a group of 12 performers and 3 designers, Anatomy of an Accident blurs the lines between docudrama, pedestrian movement, physicality, and text in a meta-theatrical attempt to change the outcome of a shared traumatic event.

Your support will: 

  1. Help us pay our amazing design team and performers;
  2. Cover part of our rehearsal and performance equipment rental costs;
  3. Keep ticket prices by suggested donation. That way, anyone who wants to see the performance, can be there.
Give a little, give a lot. Any gift makes a difference.


Art & Social Justice

Anatomy of an Accident is about bringing together our lives as artists and our community work. 

Rosa is the Executive Director of Yoga Behind Bars and Hatlo is a Support Coordinator for homeless young adults at Teen Feed. Our creative work is very much informed by our day jobs and we want to bring our artist lens to community healing work. 

It is important to us to learn and meditate on communities coming together and how we as artists can contribute to solutions in the aftermath of a traumatic event. 

As part of our creative research, we have been conducting interviews with  community organizers involved in community organizing. Performances will be followed by a moderated conversation. We look forward to receive feedback from the audience on bringing a social justice lens to our creative work.

Other Ways You Can Help

Can’t contribute but love our work? Please share this campaign with your people and networks. It’s easy: just use the tools provided by Indiegogo.  

Our Team

co-director/narrative + text: HATLO
co-director/choreography: Rosa Vissers
costume designer: Clare Strasser
lighting designer: Jessica Trundy
composer: Paurl Walsh
core ensemble: Jessica Chung,  Corina Dalzell, Jordi Montes, Hannah Simmons, Kince de Vera, Jenna Vershen, Ryan Vinson, Maggie Wegener
second ensemble: Amanda Kurtz, Ryan Mather, Kathryn Padberg and Kai Hoshino Sandy

Thank you!

The difference you make (aka you're our hero)

Your support will: 


Help us pay our amazing design team and performers;
Cover part of our rehearsal and performance equipment rental costs;
Keep ticket prices by suggested donation. That way, anyone who wants to see the performance, can be there.

Give a little, give a lot. Any gift makes a difference.





Art & Social Justice 

Anatomy of an Accident is
about bringing together our lives as artists and our community work. 
Rosa is
the Executive Director of Yoga Behind Bars and Hatlo is a Support Coordinator
for homeless young adults at Teen Feed. Our creative work is very much informed
by our day jobs and we want to bring our artist lens to community healing work. 
It is important to us to learn and meditate on communities
coming together and how we as artists can contribute to solutions in the
aftermath of a traumatic event. 
As part of our creative research, we have been conducting
interviews with  community organizers involved
in community organizing. Performances will be followed by a moderated
conversation. We look forward to receive feedback from the audience on
bringing a social justice lens to our creative work.



Other Ways You Can Help Can’t contribute but love our work? Please share this campaign with your
people and networks. It’s easy: just use the tools provided by Indiegogo.  

Our Team
co-director/narrative + text: HATLOco-director/choreography: Rosa Visserscostume designer: Clare Strasserlighting designer: Jessica Trundycomposer: Paurl Walshcore ensemble: Jessica Chung,  Corina Dalzell, Jordi Montes, Hannah Simmons, Kince de Vera, Jenna Vershen, Ryan Vinson, Maggie Wegenersecond ensemble: Amanda Kurtz, Ryan Mather, Kathryn Padberg and Kai Hoshino Sandy
Thank you!

story:
What? You missed the Indiegogo campaign? You can STILL help send us to Dublin with a tax-deductible contribution to CTEK Arts!
http://ctekarts.org/donate.html

This campaign is raising funds on behalf of Provincetown Community Compact Inc, a verified nonprofit. The campaign does not necessarily reflect the views of the nonprofit or have any formal association with it. All contributions are considered unrestricted gifts and can't be specified for any particular purpose.

“TWO FROM PROVINCETOWN” GOES TO DUBLIN!

CTEK Arts is taking “Two From Provincetown” to the international stage! “Two From Provincetown: A Shining Attribute and What To Throw Out” has been invited to participate in the International Dublin Gay Theater Festival 2014 (www.gaytheatre.ie). The plays will run for seven performances, May 12 – 18, 2014 and we need your support to make this happen. The playwrights, cast and director will represent Provincetown, Massachusetts, New York City, and Austin, Texas.

“Two From Provincetown” will be a brilliant evening of one-act plays. “A Shining Attribute” by Candyce Rusk, directed by Dana McCoy, and starring Sarah MacDonnell in her one-woman tour-de-force as Bijou, a burlesque queen with a thorny past in Boston and Provincetown. Kathleen Warnock’s “What To Throw Out”, directed by Margaret Van Sant, will feature Sarah MacDonnell and Dana McCoy in a two-hander about stripping things to their essence, and finding what lies beneath.

Both shows have deep roots in Provincetown, the birthplace of modern American theater. "A Shining Attribute” debuted in the first Women’s International Theater Festival (WITF) in 2010, returning to acclaim during the 2013 WITF Festival. “What To Throw Out” premiered in the 2013 Fall Provincetown Playwrights Festival. Kathleen Warnock’s plays are a hit in Dublin and this is her fifth invited presentation at the Festival.

HELP “TWO FROM PROVINCETOWN” GET TO IRELAND

Your contribution (of any amount) will help fund the following:

  • Roundtrip airfare from NYC and Boston to Dublin for the company
  • The cost of a furnished flat (with kitchen and laundry!) in Dublin for them to stay. And presumably cook and do laundry.
  • Postcards, posters and playbills
  • A per diem so the actors don't have to go out busking in the street! (Though they can if they want to).
  • Basic groceries to save money on dinner out.

Other Ways

Many of you are artists trying to get their own work up and running... sometimes you're just not able to contribute in cash. But we still need (and love!) you!

Please share, re-post, tweet, busk and otherwise spread the word about our “Two From Provincetown” campaign. And:

  • Send your Irish friends to the International Gay Dublin Theatre Festival and “Two From Provincetown”!
  • Come and see us in Dublin…we’ll play great pub games after the show.
  • Send us a kind word, and come to our invited dress rehearsal here at the Provincetown Theater in late April (date TBA shortly).

story:
What's the Buzz

My name is Aaron Michael Krueger.  I am a performer and writer/composer living in NYC.  I began writing New Dawn as a 10 minute musical for a class my freshman year of college, and the show has grown into a full length musical since then.  My senior year of college, I was able to do a production of the show in fulfillment of my requirements for my Directing II class.  Now, after three years of rewrites and tweaks, the show is ready for another production, and has been chosen to be a part of the Midtown International Theatre Festival with direction and choreography by Lexie Fennell Frare.

What We Need and What You Get For Helping

Here's what the money raised will go towards:

  • Festival Fees (including the Participation Fee and the Theatre Usage Fee)
  • Rehearsal Space
  • Simple Sets and Costumes
  • Paying the Actors, Designers, and Staff
Here's what you can get for helping us fund the project:

  • Downloads of Demos recorded of the music
  • Personalized Facebook Video Thank Yous
  • A Special Thank You printed in the program
  • Poster Signed By The Cast and Creative Team
  • Two Tickets to a performance of New Dawn (travel to NYC not included)
  • Special Access to the final rehearsal of New Dawn (travel to NYC not included)

The Impact

Besides helping me achieve one of my dreams, putting this show up is important because the show focuses on topics that are still relevant to high school students and families.  Many of the events of the musical are inspired by things I went through and felt when I was in high school.  The show raises awareness about topics that teens deal still deal with in high school.

Other Ways You Can Help

Just because you can’t contribute, it doesn’t mean you can’t help:

  • Share this page on your Facebook to let your friends and families know about it
  • Post a Tweet about this page 
  • Film a vlog and post it to Youtube sharing the information about this page
  • Like the show on Facebook at www.facebook.com/NewDawnTheMusical 

Thank you for all of your help!

story:
THE PROJECT

After a sold-out & critically acclaimed workshop production last May, also recently named as one of the Ten Best Theatre Productions for 2010, Prodigals returns for its official World Premiere. Set in a small bar in Sault Ste. Marie, Ontario, six young underachievers await the results of a murder trial that’s hit close to home. Their world of drinking, sarcasm and missed opportunities is flipped upside down when a former friend returns from Toronto to testify in the trial, reopening old wounds and creating some new ones as well. Directed by Peter Boychuk, Prodigals will appear on stage in Studio T at Goldorp Centre for the Arts, SFU Woodward's, from May 3rd - May 14th, 2011


Reviews from the workshop production:


“Minogue… is too savvy to simply dismiss his roots. There’s an ache that runs through this play, and it’s about the difficulty of negotiating the terrain between adventure and compromise…[He] does an excellent job of fleshing out his characters’ individual points of view…Minogue is a promising young writer. Those don’t show up every day. If you run into him, buy him a beer” --Colin Thomas, Georgia Straight


“Great writing, fabulous acting and a good omen for things to come in Canadian theatre”--Ed Farolan, ReviewVancouver.org


“There are usually two ways I know when a piece of theatre thoroughly sucks me in: a total immersion into the story that blocks out the usual annoyances from my fellow theatre-goers, or, as was the case with the Twenty Something Theatre production of Prodigals last night, when I find myself so connected with some of the characters that I want to scream out and provide them with what I consider sage advice.”--Mark Robins, GayVancouver.net


“Peter Boychuck’s direction was fantastic, in my opinion. The actors’ performances were seamless. All actors are so incredibly believable, so totally human, so flawed and imperfect yet so caring and loving. I was so incredibly taken by the play that in one of the climaxing scenes, I actually shouted “oh sh!t”…That, to me, was the perfect demonstration that I was completely immersed in the play.”--Raul Pacheco, Hummingbird604.com


THE COMPANY & OUR IMPACT:


“Twenty-Something Theatre performs an important function in Vancouver’s cultural ecology: it offers edgier scripts, including original works such as Sean Minogue’s Prodigals, and even in its name attempts to appeal to a younger demographic.” --Colin Thomas, Georgia Straight

Twenty-Something Theatre “is reaching out to--and getting--younger audiences” --Jo Ledingham, Vancouver Courier


Twenty-Something Theatre is a Vancouver based independent theatre company dedicated to producing contemporary theatre that is provocative, edgy and relevant to our generation. We are committed to providing Vancouver’s next generation of theatre artists with opportunities to pursue their craft and we strive to enhance Vancouver’s theatre community with productions that entertain and evoke the lives of today’s young people.


Heading into our 6th year we have featured some of the city’s best up-and-coming artists in such highly acclaimed works as This Is Our Youth by Kenneth Lonergan, The Shape of Things by Neil Labute, The Fever by Wallace Shawn, Suburbia by Eric Bogosian, Unidentified Human Remains and the True Nature of Love by Brad Fraser and Blue Surge by Rebecca Gilman; however, since its founding, Twenty-Something Theatre has only ever produced established plays. 


Prodigals is the first original work we have undertaken, and is therefore an important step in making our company a vital part of the theatre community that is dedicated to producing and fostering original new work. We want to be a company that not only provides opportunities for young actors, designer, directors, stage managers and technicians but who also provides those same opportunities to young playwrights by allowing them to gain exposure and experience that they might not get otherwise.


HOW CAN YOU HELP?:

In order to mount the World Premiere of Prodigals – our biggest venture yet as a young company – we need to fundraise approximately $2,000 through individual donations from people like you. 


All of your donations will go entirely towards covering the cost of creating this production including:


-venue costs such as technical and front of house labour

-design and construction of the set, costumes, lighting and sound

-marketing and publicity for the production that helps us get bums in seats


With your help Twenty-Something Theatre can further establish itself as, not only a vital component of the Vancouver theatre community, but also as a company where young emerging playwrights are given the opportunity to have their work seen on a professional level.


More than anything you can also help us spread the word!! Tell all your friends, family, co-workers, strangers that you meet on the street, about this exciting project. You can follow along with our progress on the company blog, An Unidentified Production, or on Facebook or Twitter. Or if you have other questions or just want to chat over email you can contact us via email at info[at]twentysomethingtheatre[dot]com.


On behalf of everyone here at Twenty-Something Theatre as well as the incredible cast and production team of Prodigals I would like to extend a very big thank you for all your support.



~Sabrina Evertt


Artistic Producer,

Twenty-Something Theatre


PS...Twenty-Something Theatre Society is a Canadian not-for-profit Registered Charity so if you would rather receive a tax-deductible receipt for your donation than the offered "perk" please contact us at the email provided with your name, address and donation amount.

story:
• Short Summary

This production is so important to me. The characters are based on people I have met throughout high school. 'Kids These Days' focuses on the issues teenagers deal with today and how the problems we have are constantly negated by society, when in fact, they impact who we grow up to become.

The idea for this play found me, almost like fate. I heard about the Strawberry One Act Play Festival and wanted to participate, but I had nothing I wanted to write about. The next day, inspiration hit me right in the face. I was sitting in class having the worst day. I couldn't eat or sleep, my problems were consuming me, yet I was stuck in this classroom, like being in a prison cell. My teacher asked for my assignment and I looked at him and said I didn't have it. He shook his head and gave me the death stare as he walked away commenting on how I can’t graduate without doing my homework.  I realized that for the past 11 years of my life, school has been the most pressing issue above all others.  Even though my life seemed to be crumbling down around me, the most important and pressing issue was passing class, or handing in an algebra assignment. It seemed that for the majority of my life I was learning how to read and write but I never learned how to be happy or how to deal with my issues. So this sparked the question, what will happen once I graduate, and once those issues that were hidden behind textbooks and calculators soon become real?

Hence, the birth of 'Kids These Days'.

Let me start off by telling you a bit about me! My name is Rachel Wagner; I am going into my senior year of high school and will hopefully be attending a BFA program for acting the following year. I have been acting my entire life and decided to try my hand at writing. This is the first play I have ever written and it has been accepted into the Strawberry One-Act Festival.

Being a part of the festival is so important to me. I want to represent teenagers in this competition. I'll be competing with more experienced adults who probably have more money and training than I do. This is where is where YOU the donor comes in! 

What We Need & What You Get

The most important thing is covering the expenses that comes with putting on the production. Money is needed for rehearsal space, audition space, sets, props, and transportation. It would love to give a stipend to the actors, director and crew who will work hard for very little. It is important that the production looks polished and professional.  Plus, if you donate you get like 1,000 good karma points, so who would want to pass that up?

The Impact

This production means so much to me, and the people who have helped inspire me to write the characters. This opportunity is unbelievable and I want to make the most out of it.

Other Ways You Can Help

No worries, I understand that I'm not finding a cure for cancer or saving kittens so if you think your money is best suited elsewhere don't sweat it! There are plenty of other ways you can help.

  • Spread the word! Get people interested in the production!
  • Donate props! Anything "teen" whether it's a stereo, a football, a pair of shoes anything that can be used in the production is greatly appreciated! For prop donations you can reach me at KidsTheseDays2012@gmail.com
  • Show support for The Strawberry One-Act Festival and the Riant Theater! They are the reason my production is possible so feel free to help them out!
