story:
"Not everything that is faced can be changed but nothing 
can be changed  until it is faced." James Baldwin

Five Days Left - Let's Knock It Out Of The Park! Here's How we'll handle overfunding when we exceed the $6,000 goal:

We're In The Final Countdown! Check out the update video!

Here's The Previous Update - Look How Far We've Come!

Breaking the silence surrounding the sexual abuse of children is key to stopping this vicious cycle that continues to be passed from one generation to the next. Help us to help children who are survivors of sexual assault to do just that.

I'm Donna Jenson and I founded Time To Tell with the mission of sparking stories from lives affected by incest and sexual abuse to be told and heard. 

It took me seven years to write my play, What She Knows: One Woman's Way Through Incest, based on my experience of surviving incest and what I did to make my life worth living. Every scene written, every word recited, has been medicine for me. And what a delicious circle - first I heal from making art, this play, out of my trauma, then I share it with others, this trauma transformed into a performance, and audience members get some healing and courage to talk about their experience. See excerpts of the play here.

Luckily, I'm not alone. John Sheldon, master guitarist, accompanies me with his remarkable score and two original songs: "A Way Through" and "It Wasn't Your Fault," key messages of the play. He's former lead guitarist for Van Morrison and a James Taylor songwriter. Also, Jackie Humphreys, Clinical Consultant to the project, is at the performances. She's a licensed social worker with two decades of experience in this issue, offering support to audience members wishing to talk to someone.

I started out thinking my audience would be other adult survivors, women like me. Surprise! Surprise! They are but there's more. I didn't anticipate how my play could reach boys and girls. The boys being juvenile sex offenders ages 8 to 20 at the Stetson School in Barre, MA. See what their clinicians say about the impact Iï¿½ve had on the them here. The girls are serving sentences in a highly secure incarceration and treatment facility, the Rotenberg School, in Westboro, MA. Ages 13 to 20, 75% have suffered sexual assault.

The Impact

Reaching young people, in particular, who have been abused as well as those who have abused others offers a great opportunity to help in stopping this cycle of violence perpetuated through families and communities. Here's what the girls were saying in their thank you notes after our performance at Rotenberg:

"I really liked your story, very sad but I liked it more cuz you got the courage to tell us."

"Thank you for sharing your story with us. It inspired us to stand up for ourselves."

"You encouraged me to love myself more and to want more in life. Thanks."

And NOW!

We're collaborating with The Chicago Alliance Against Sexual Exploitation, CAASE, an advocacy organization, that is working to bring the performance to venues and groups that can benefit from the show's powerful message of survival and hope.  These organizations include formerly incarcerated women and prostituted youth.  CAASE will also help promote the show to groups throughout the city so that they can benefit from being able to attend the performance. Read more about this fabulous organization at www.caase.org.

What We Need & What You Get

We need $6,000 for travel expenses from western Massachusetts to Chicago, Illinois to spend a week giving performances and follow-up workshops to all these groups free of charge. That's what all the funds from this campaign will be used for.

If the sexual abuse of children is of concern to you - supporting our work gives you a meaningful way to participate in breaking the silence that surrounds and perpetuates it. 

In addition, see the tangible rewards awaiting your involvement on the right side of this page.

Other Ways You Can Help

You can also help *big time* by sending this link to all the people you know telling them what you think of it. 

You might say, like some have already said, "it's one of the most innovative ways I've seen for touching hearts and minds about this issue" or that "this project gives me real hope that there can be a change" or, "after hearing Donna's story and John's music, I feel cleansed." 

You can find out more about us and our project on our web site at www.TimeToTell.org.

Video created by TVGeis Productions www.tvgeis.com 
Edited by Tye Whipple
story_txt:
"Not everything that is faced can be changed but nothing 





can be changed 



until it is faced." James Baldwin



Five Days Left - Let's Knock It Out Of The Park! 

Here's How we'll handle overfunding when we exceed the $6,000 goal:



We're In The Final Countdown! 

Check out the update video!



Here's The Previous Update - 
Look How Far We've Come!



Breaking the silence surrounding the sexual abuse of children is key to stopping this vicious cycle that continues to be passed from one generation to the next. Help us to help children who are survivors of sexual assault to do just that.

I'm Donna Jenson and I founded Time To Tell with the mission of sparking stories from lives affected by incest and sexual abuse to be told and heard. 

It took me seven years to write my play, What She Knows: One Woman's Way Through Incest, based on my experience of surviving incest and what I did to make my life worth living. Every scene written, every word recited, has been medicine for me. And what a delicious circle - first I heal from making art, this play, out of my trauma, then I share it with others, this trauma transformed into a performance, and audience members get some healing and courage to talk about their experience. See excerpts of the play here.

Luckily, I'm not alone. John Sheldon, master guitarist, accompanies me with his remarkable score and two original songs: "A Way Through" and "It Wasn't Your Fault," key messages of the play. He's former lead guitarist for Van
Morrison and a James Taylor songwriter. Also, Jackie Humphreys, Clinical
Consultant to the project, is at the performances. She's a licensed
social worker with two decades of experience in this issue, offering support to
audience members wishing to talk to someone.

I started out thinking my audience would be other adult survivors, women like me. Surprise! Surprise! They are but there's more. I didn't anticipate how my play could reach boys and girls. The boys being juvenile sex offenders ages 8 to 20 at the Stetson School in Barre, MA. See what their clinicians say about the impact Iï¿½ve had on the them here. The girls are serving sentences in a highly secure incarceration and treatment facility, the Rotenberg School, in Westboro, MA. Ages 13 to 20, 75% have suffered sexual assault.
The Impact
Reaching young people, in particular, who have been abused as well as those who have abused others offers a great opportunity to help in stopping this cycle of violence perpetuated through families and communities. Here's what the girls were saying in their thank you notes after our performance at Rotenberg:

"I really liked your story, very sad but I liked it more cuz you got the courage to tell us."

"Thank you for sharing your story with us. It inspired us to stand up for ourselves."

"You encouraged me to love myself more and to want more in life. Thanks."
And NOW!

We're collaborating with The Chicago Alliance Against Sexual Exploitation, CAASE, an advocacy organization, that is working to bring the performance to venues and
groups that can benefit from the show's powerful message of survival and hope. 
These organizations include formerly incarcerated women and prostituted
youth.  CAASE will also help promote the show to groups throughout the
city so that they can benefit from being able to attend the performance. Read more about this fabulous organization at www.caase.org.

What We Need & What You Get
We need $6,000 for travel expenses from western Massachusetts to Chicago, Illinois to spend a week giving performances and follow-up workshops to all these groups free of charge. That's what all the funds from this campaign will be used for.

If the sexual abuse of children is of concern to you - supporting our work gives you a meaningful way to participate in breaking the silence that surrounds and perpetuates it. 

In addition, see the tangible rewards awaiting your involvement on the right side of this page.
Other Ways You Can Help
You can also help *big time* by sending this link to all the people you know telling them what you think of it. 

You might say, like some have already said, "it's one of the most innovative ways I've seen for touching hearts and minds about this issue" or that "this project gives me real hope that there can be a change" or, "after hearing Donna's story and John's music, I feel cleansed." 

You can find out more about us and our project on our web site at www.TimeToTell.org.

story:
Click Here for info about the performance on May 3, Festival Accés Asie.

Futuristic, electric, & evocative.

IREDEA is a dance rock opera inspired by the writer Philip K. Dick's visions of the future. In the story, the planet is destroyed by an apocalypse. The few remaining faces of humanity are at war with each other to define a new morality. Mysterious characters are at the centre of this struggle. One is an artist in a paralyzed body. Another is brilliant, cold, and manipulative. The third is wise but destitute and desperate.  

Depicted through exquisite choreography emphasized with original music and new forms of multimedia, this newly concocted theatrical universe follows a gifted sculptor who is sent on a quest to apotheosize the man who destroyed the world.  Locked inside the recesses of her mind, she travels through the ruined landscape that she has woken up to. The artist is pushed to ridiculous limits through confrontation with both internal and external forces.  She battles through her own vulnerabilities to come to terms with her new reality and a final decision that has consequences far beyond her own life. 

IREDEA is booked for a total of 14 performances at these festivals in 2014:

* Montreal Festival Acces Asie, May 3 & 4 Click Here (Tickets 17.50$ – Box office: (514) 861-4036. Espace Aline-Letendre, Église du Gesù, 1202 rue Bleury.)

* Montreal Fringe Festival, June 12-22

* Ottawa Fringe Festival, June 20 - 30


HOW YOUR SUPPORT WILL IMPACT OUR PROJECT

We have been developing the work for this sci-fi dance rock since 2011. 

The total cost of creating and producing this show up to the end of our 2014 Summer tour is approximately $20,000.  Much of Iredea has been created from our own pockets.  Before launching for public audiences in less than 2 months, we are in need of financial support in this final stretch. 

We are trying to raise $4000 from our Indigogo supportors and another $4000 from corporate sponsors. The balance of the budget is being invested by us the artists.

These funds will be used primarily to pay our team of artists who are working tirelessly on the show. Other expenses also include: press & promotion costs, festival fees, touring costs, and additional materials and props. 

Your contribution will help us get through the final and most challenging stage of the show creation before it is brought to audiences for the first time.  This initial series of performances in 2014 will greatly serve as a launching pad for Iredea to be seen and picked up by producers throughout the world. Our vision is too continue to develop this work to its full artistic potential over the next 5 years. It is our goal to perform and tour this work in all parts of the world and inspire audiences from all walks of life.  

Woo Me Myth is a dance rock opera company based in Montreal, Quebec created by musician Ted Strauss & contemporary dancer Jenn Doan in 2009.  We started the company in 2009 out of a shared passion to deliver a new performance language that is both evocative and awe-inspiring for all audiences. Together we create the sonic and physical landscape for every live performance, merging together mythology, striking contemporary dance, and the eclectic sounds of electronic and rock music. 

Our first full production in 2010, The Duck Wife,  toured across Canada with a 4 member rock band, an ensemble of 5 dancers and actors, and a production manager. An incredibly ambitious undertaking for us two young artists with a big vision. The show received much audience acclaim and won several awards along the way. The Montreal Gazette reviewed, "The Duck Wife is a revelation."

This incredible Duck Wife experience affirmed to us that we were on to something. This is what we love to do... to create, to collaborate, and to perform. 

The development of Iredea began in the fall of 2011 when we set out to find the inspiration for our next creation. Woo Me Myth’s vision has always been rooted in mythology. Science fiction, a mythology for the modern world, became the centre of our fascination.

For 2 years, we experimented and delved into research of cinema, history, art, and movement in the dance studio. These were the seeds that would become Iredea.  After performing in the 2013 Festival Vue Sur La Releve in Montreal, we were awarded an artist’s residency at Le Gesu arts centre, and an offer to present in the 2014 Festival Acces Asie. Starting in September 2013, we began to assemble a team of incredibly talented collaborators from all artistic disciplines to finally take this vision to the next level. 

Please help us bring this sci-fi dance rock to life!   


THE IREDEA TEAM

Ted Strauss, artistic director, composer

Jenn Doan, choreographic director, dancer


Dancers

Melina Stinson

Mark Medrano

Maxine Segalowitz

Karston Kroll


Creative team

Sandra Chirico, costume designer

Clement Yeh, prop designer 

Tristan Brand, photographer 

Scott Combes, visual artist 

Marigold Santos, visual artist 

Josee Gagnon, performance mentor

Kaie Kellough, writer and sound poet

Maria Simone, rehearsal director


Production team

Mohamed Hamad, web and social media

Christine Kinsella, booking agent 

Khosro Berahmandi, Festival Director of Access Asie 

Le Gesu


Our job description looks something like this: 

dreaming, researching, discussing, rehearsing 4-6x per week, directing, reading, physical training, writing, planning, composing original music, writing narration, producing, arguing, organizing, scheduling, more thinking, more planning, making errors, making corrections, meeting with collaborators, more dreaming, learning, stressing, contacting press, more meetings, a little more arguing, a lot more stressing, more rehearsing, fundraising, photo shooting, video shooting, editing videos, editing pictures, social media posting, hustling, thinking, planning, losing sleep, promoting, performing, more promoting, and then more and more and more performing!!!

story:
Every semester at NYU Tisch School of the Arts, students have the opportunity to propose a show to produce. When approved, the team gets the opportunity to put on a completely student-run show. 

As part of the Spring 2014 GAP season at the NYU Tisch School of the Arts, we are presenting Bonnie & Clyde.


“You’ve read the story of Jesse James
Of how he lived and died;
If you’re still in need
Of something to read,
Here’s the story of Bonnie and Clyde…”

Bonnie & Clyde is America's darkest love story, chronicling the twists and turns in the lives of this country's most notorious outlaws and, for many, folk heroes.  Our team is drawn to this story at a crossroad in our lives: a time at which we are each trying to establish ourselves as young artists up against a seemingly impossible industry.  Such is also the case for the title hero and heroine, grappling with massive dreams and an even greater obstacle: the Great Depression.  Bonnie Parker wrote a poem during her time on the road with Clyde that was found after their death.  In it, she chronicled the lives of two misunderstood kids who, in pursuit of notoriety, got carried away.  That is the story we want to tell.

We are transforming our performance space into a 1930’s Texas saloon and transporting audiences back to a time when rebel obsession was born, Americans were wiggling free socially from the heavy restrictions of Prohibition, and the Great Depression was the backdrop for the poorest of times this country has ever seen.  Saloon culture included dancing, gambling, drinking, mingling, and, in many cases, theatrical skits.  The musical is the theatrical skit of the evening, brought to life by the saloon patrons, played by our actors.  Audiences may have heard this story before, but never like this.  Our company represents everything that the NYU GAP experience stands for: students taking charge and crafting our own theatrical experience.  Together, we look forward to sharing our take on the story of Bonnie and Clyde with you.

“Some day they’ll go down together;
And they’ll bury them side by side;
To few it’ll be grief
To the law a relief
But it’s death for Bonnie and Clyde.”
-Bonnie Parker


The Company

Book by Ivan Menchell
Lyrics by Don Black
Music by Frank Wildhorn

Directed by Matthew Gregory
Choreography by Gabriella Pérez
Music Direction by Ben Chavez
Produced by Brídín Clements

Preacher/Judge/Hamer - Sommer Carbuccia
Cumie Barrow/Stella - Caroline Casey
Ted - James Cella
Sheriff Schmid - Carver Duncan
Bonnie - Adrienne Eller
Young Bonnie - Megan Ermilio
Blanche - Tara Halpern
Henry Barrow/John/Joe/Ed Crowded/Teller - Alec Mathieson
Young Clyde/Bud/Archie - Donovan Mendelovitz
Buck - Max Meyers
Emma Parker/Trish - Lillie Ricciardi
Eleanor/Governor Ferguson/Shopkeeper - Tess Richie
Clyde - Tim Sampson

Dramaturg/Assistant Director - Tessa Lee
Assistant Choreographer - Jelani Alladin
Dialect Coach - Lauren Roth
Production Stage Manager - Brianne Stewart
Scenic Designer - Matilda Sabal
Costume Designer - A.C. Gottlieb
Lighting Designer - Kelley Shih
Sound Designer - Nikolai Mishler
Technical Director - Evan Kutcher
Assistant Stage Managers - Eli Carpenter, Meg Whitehurst
Assistant Scenic Designer - Hahnji Jang
Assistant Costume Designer - James Nguyen
Assistant Technical Director - Cherrish Curry
Hair & Makeup Stylist - Alex Rivera
Wardrobe Supervisor - Martín Lara

Our Goal

In order to bring this storytelling to life, the Bonnie & Clyde team needs to raise $6000. We have to pay for production rights, lighting, projection and sound equipment, publicity fees, costume pieces and scenic materials. If you can't contribute money but would like to donate (i.e. free printing or building supplies) we would love to hear from you too! Contact us at bonnieandclydegap@gmail.com 

How You Can Help

You can contribute money online or email us at bonnieandclydegap@gmail.com for other ways to donate.

Your contributions help cover materials to build the set and props, lighting and sound equipment, costumes, publicity fees, and rights to produce the play. By supporting this project, you are giving a group of students the opportunity to establish ourselves as the next generation of theatremakers. 

Can't contribute money? That's okay! Help us out by spreading word about the show! 

Visit our website: www.bonnieandclydegap.com

story:
Wee Man Productions is a new company based in the New York City area interested in developing high quality, new work, by emerging artists that aims to engage and involve multiple communities in the artistic process.  Our goal is to give artists; actors, writers, filmmakers, and dancers, a home and a professional environment where they can feel safe while experimenting without repercussions. We are committed to pay all the artists on our team. We are comprised of Nicole Beerman, Mark Cirnigliaro, and Josh Beerman. Wee Man Productions is currently producing the Equity Showcase of the World Premier of Hounds of War, a play by Bill Holland, Directed by Mark Cirnigliaro, opening at the Dorothy Strelsin Theatre March 21st and running through April 5th. 

While Wee Man Productions is a new company in NYC, our members are not. You will see in our individual bios we have all been working professionally for well over 10 years, both in New York and across the country. With our individual experience, in theatre, film, and dance, Wee Man Productions has the chance to be something really special.

Our current show Hounds of War is the beginning for Wee Man Productions and if our second show, Josh Beerman's play Craftsman is accepted to FringeNYC, we have the opportunity then to increase our community and engage with other artists doing a variety of work.  In addition to these plays we are beginning development on a web series and a dance piece. We are very interested in different kinds of individuals that we might co-produce with in the future, artists that may provide us with fresh ideas, and new directions.

Right now, we would love to partner with you. You would not be taking a chance with us, but cementing a commitment to new work of all kinds.

story:
Our Story

Peggy Shaw is our grand-butch-elder, and we want to support her.  Shaw has devoted her entire life to making art that transforms our lives as queers, artists, audiences, scholars, students, and fellow travelers.  As a working artist in the United States, Shaw's lifetime of labor leaves her without a pension.  As her family, friends, and fans, we are her safety net.  Give back.


The Impact

The Peggy Shaw Pension Fund enables an aging, butch lesbian grandmother to continue making art in the face of illness, adversity, and the current economic crisis.


What We Need & What You Get

Keep on giving! First, we are raising $15,000 to get Peggy back on her feet after a difficult year.  Every dollar after that that will go towards her much needed Pension Fund to support her in the coming years.  All funds raised will go to Peggy Shaw.  


In this year, Peggy Shaw's physical archive--which includes production flyers, posters, photographs and other ephemera--have been digitized.  As a supporter of the Peggy Shaw Pension Fund, you will receive selected digital and/or original items from her collection (see Perks).


Other Ways You Can Help

Keep supporting her shows, tell your friends about the Peggy Shaw Pension Fund, invite Peggy to your college or community, organize a local fundraiser, buy Shaw's new book, A Menopausal Gentleman: The Solo Performances of Peggy Shaw (ed. Jill Dolan, University of Michigan Press), check out the archive http://www.splitbritches.org.

In this year, Peggy Shaw's physical archive--which includes production flyers, posters, photographs and other ephemera--have been digitized.  As a supporter of the Peggy Shaw Pension Fund, you will receive selected digital and/or original items from her collection (see Perks).


Other Ways You Can Help
Keep supporting her shows, tell your friends about the Peggy Shaw Pension Fund, invite Peggy to your college or community, organize a local fundraiser, buy Shaw's new book, A Menopausal Gentleman: The Solo Performances of Peggy Shaw (ed. Jill Dolan, University of Michigan Press), check out the archive http://www.splitbritches.org.

story:
The Project:

you & i Theatre is a collaborative creation based company headed by Co-Artistic Directors Kevin Kraussler and Ming Hudson.  Our mandate is to create works of physical theatre that promote social change.

The Elephant and The Goldfish is a new Theatre for Young Audiences play in development with initial dramaturgy by Jan Derbyshire.  This is a physical theatre piece that requires highly stylized and acrobatic movement.  To further develop the physical components of this creation, we will be conducting our second development workshop in October of 2013.

With this work we, at you & i Theatre, are interested in exploring the narrative of an actor who needs to play the part of an individual who has schizophrenia, and so seeks out the first hand experience of a young woman who has been institutionalized.  This begins an adventure through friendship and delusion that takes the viewer on an expressionistic journey through the mind of the protagonist.  Our primary goal is to ask: What is “normal” and who decides what “normal” is?  

One of our company members was raised in a household with a Schizophrenic parent, which was the impetus for this project.  There is currently a stigma around issues concerning mental wellness in Canada even though roughly 1 in every 4 people will be diagnosed with some form of mental health issue within their lifetime.  Approximately 1 in every 100 people are Schizophrenic.  For this community it is important to tell the stories of those whose lives have been touched by Schizophrenia in order to open up a dialogue about the condition, and to reduce the stigma that interferes with integration and acceptance of those with this illness.  We are specifically targeting this play to junior high/ high school age young audiences. 

The person we have chosen to be our dramaturg and director as we move forward with this project is renowned Canadian Director/Actor/Dramturg Jack Paterson.  Paterson is the perfect fit for our project because of his long standing history of artistic achievement, as well as his extensive experience with Theatre for Young Audiences.  However, Paterson is currently pursuing his MFA at the prestigious East 15 Acting School at the University of Essex.  In addition, Hudson is also currently living in the UK, attending the London International School of the Performing Arts obtaining a diploma in physical theatre and creation.  

To meet our staged production goal of 2016, we feel that it is crucial to have a development workshop this year.  With two thirds of our creative team currently located in London, it is most cost effective to have the workshop in London and transport one individual there than to pay for two individuals to fly back to Canada.  We realize that this is a large expense, but we wouldn’t undertake this international workshop if we didn’t feel that the specific individuals involved were not essential to creating the best possible play we could create at this point in time. While this workshop will take place in England, we are committed to using Canadian artists to create a uniquely Canadian play.   

Any contribution you can make will help us get to London and continue this important work! 


What We Need:

We are hoping to raise $2500.  This would cover:

  • Travel costs for Kevin to get to London
  • Payment for the Artists

If we exceed our fundraising goal, the extra money would go towards the creation of a company website to promote the show and attract further funding. 


Who We Are:

KEVIN KRAUSSLER

 He is a graduate of the University of British Columbia BFA Acting Program and an Alumnus of the Douglas College Acting Program.  He has performed professionally with Companies such as Bard on the Beach Shakespeare Festival, Theatre Conspiracy, and Screaming Weenie Theatre co.  In addition, he has co-created new works for the Vancouver and Victoria International Fringe Festivals.  He has also trained with the Vancouver Circus School.    

MING HUDSON

Ming Hudson is a Canadian theatre artist who can currently be found training at the London International School of Performing Arts, a world-renowned Lecoq-based physical theatre and creation program located in the UK.  A graduate of the Department of Theatre at the University of Victoria, Ming earned her BFA with distinction in a specialization in acting in 2007.  In Vancouver, her most recent credits include Fall Away Home (Boca del Lupo), PostSecret: Unheard Voices (Brand to Stage Productions), and The Penelopiad (Arts Club Theatre).  Ming also trains regularly in the circus arts, with a focus on aerial silks, main à main balancing, acrobatics, and doubles static trapeze.


JACK PATERSON

Jack is a Canadian director, dramaturg, actor, and theatre creator who works across the country.  Favorite credits include directing the instillation of The List (BoucheWHACKED!), the site specific The Women of Troy  (Canadian Stage) and F. Garcia Lorca’s The Love of Don Perlimplin for Belisa (Shaw Festival); production dramaturgy on the English language premiere of H. Muller’s Mabeth: nach Shakespeare (Theatre Conspiracy); and playing Hitler and Walt Disney in The Blue Light (Firehall Arts Centre) and Scheffler in The Ugly One (Plan B Collective).

He is the founder of multi-award winning Mad Duck Theatre Collective for whom he adapted and directed Coriolanus, Julius Caesar, Vancouver’s first female Prospero in The Tempest and the Vancouver premieres of Shakespeare’s R&J and Titus Andronicus.  Other directing credits include the award winning The Hobbit and The Odyssey (Carousel Theatre) and Banana Boys (Firehall Arts Centre). A graduate of Circle in the Square (NYC), he has performed with The Arts Club, Chemainus Theatre and as a regular performer in Savage God’s The Shakespeare Projects.

Jack recently completed a series of Artistic Director Residencies with the mandate of Three Provinces, Three Companies and Three Mandates with Playwrights’ Workshop Montreal (Quebec), Theatre Conspiracy (British Columbia) and The Magnetic North Theatre Festival (Ontario/ Alberta).  He is the Co-Artistic Producer of BoucheWHACKED! Theatre Collective in Vancouver, the West Coast Ambassador for Playwrights Workshop Montreal, and an Associate Artist with Theatre Conspiracy.  His work has been nominated for over twenty Jessie Richardson Awards including four for Outstanding Direction and two for Outstanding Production.  He is the recipient of The Ray Michal Outstanding Body of Work by an Emerging Director Award.  Jack is currently acquiring a MFA in Theatre Directing from the prestigious East 15 Acting School at the University of Essex in London. 


(Special thanks to Cameron Anderson for producing our video.)

story:
We're raising money to get our new show "Digger" off the ground.

Hi friends! Mike, Alissa, Brian and Joemca from Inkfish here. Great news: we've been invited to travel to Minnesota for a few weeks to work on our new show Digger. The wonderful people at Lanesboro Arts Center http://www.lanesboroarts.org/ have invited us to their facilities this spring for an artist's residency and we can't wait to get started.

About the show: 

Digger is about holes, and man’s descent into chaos. It ponders literal holes – black holes, holes dug through the earth, bullet holes, holes in bodies, wormholes, and spillways –in combination with Dante’s Inferno –the ultimate descent into a hole. The production concept was initially inspired by the media surrounding the Chilean mine collapse in 2010. When watching the coverage of the collapse, We were struck by similarities between the San Esteban mine and historical interpretations of Dante’s Inferno: the miners were trapped in an extended state of limbo (first circle of hell), and the structure of the San Esteban mine is uncannily similar to early artists’ interpretations that map Dante’s hell. Our narrative will draw on the miner’s experiences, Dante’s Inferno, and personal experiences to tell a story of the human struggles with lust, gluttony, greed, anger, heresy, violence and treachery.

What We Need  What You Get

We need to raise $3,900 to pay for travel and expenses to and from Lanesboro, MN for 3 people.

Expenses:

Artist fees: 2 x 2 weeks x 450 per week = 1800
               1 x 1 week   x 450 per week =  450

Travel: 2 by car including hotel expenses each way: 600
          1 by air: 600
 
Per diems: 2 x 18 days x 50 per day = 1800
               1 x 8 days   x 50 per day =  400
 
Administration: 250

TOTAL EXPENSES: $5900

Income:

Lanesboro Arts Center:$2000
 
Total amount we need to raise:  $3900
 

What You Get

For a $10 contibution you receive a thank you on our web site and some good karma.  

For a $25 contibution you receive the aforementioned, plus a groovy limited edition Inkfish button.

For a $50 contibution you receive all of the above plus an awesome limited edition signed poster.

For a $100 contibution you receive all of the above plus a snazzy Inkfish tee-shirt.

For a $500 contibution you receive all of the above plus  a framed, signed original concept storyboard.

For a $1000 contibution you receive all of the above, plus an original maquette (working model) of a leading character from Digger.

If you can’t contribute you can still help:

  • Put this link on your Facebook timeline.
  • Link to us on your blog.
  • Share this on Twitter.
  • Check out all the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
Our Story

WHO:

FrenetiCore is a non-profit organization that offers creative community experiences to the public through the presentation and promotion of original theater, dance, film, and music in Houston, Texas. FrenetiCore was incorporated as a non-profit organization in 2003 by Rebecca French and Robert Thoth with the goal of creating cutting-edge multi-media dance theater productions unlike any others found in the Houston area.  FrenetiCore has performed at least 1 full length work and several smaller productions per season since 2003.  Under the artistic direction of French and Thoth, FrenetiCore maintains a dance company comprised of regular members and guest performers.

WHAT:

Tenderina is the surreal story of a stripper ballerina and her journey to self-revelation, premiering December 2-17 at Frenetic Theater. A multi-media collaboration based on a script by poet/playwright Loueva Smith and directed by Cliff Mabry, with original film and music by Robert Thoth and dance choreography by Rebecca French, “Tenderina” is a thought-provoking and humorous show that you can’t bring the kids to!

Featuring Allison Gregory Jones as Tenderina, a.k.a. ‘The Girl Matador’; Allen Bauman as the psychedelic angel and voodoo musician, Kirk; Benito Vasquez as Tim, the accuser at a surreal trial where Tenderina is defended by the one-eyed storyteller Lee, played by Loueva Smith. Tenderina pivots into a journey of self-discovery and faces many unresolved questions as she learns what it means to be a dancer.

Dance by FrenetiCore artists:  Kira Boerkircher, Taylor Coon, Rebecca French, Erica Halligan, Kristen Hanks, Mollie Miller, Stacey Ramsower

Lighting Design by Kevin Holden
Set Design by Dana Harrell
Costumes by Gin Martini


The Impact

Houston Texas is the strip club capital of the world. Struggling performers are often tempted by the 'easy' money lure of strip clubs, when they would rather be making art. We need your help to keep our artists off the pole!

Your donation will help offset FrenetiCore's production costs to pay Tenderina's actors, dancers, designers and technicians. FrenetiCore believes in paying performers for their artistry and you can help! In addition to performer fees, other expenses include of purchasing a cyclorama and new video projectors to serve as the stage backdrop and display the original film created for Tenderina.


What We Need & What You Get

A donation of any size helps! To meet our goal of $7,500 we need donations of all sizes. FrenetiCore needs your help to cover the following:

$5,000 Performer fees

$500 Costuming

$500 Set building

$1,000 Cyclorama

$6,000 Video projectors

$1,500 Publicity

Donations can be made in the following amounts: $10, $25, $50, $100, $250, $500 and $1,000.

Donations are tax-deductible. FrenetiCore is a 501(c)(3) and will supply a donation letter for all contributions.


Other Ways You Can Help

Please consider donating to our campaign and sharing it with your friends and family. Every donation makes a difference and helps us reach our goal. Besides your monetary support we ask that you share our event on Facebook, Twitter, your own website and anywhere else you can!

story:
Our Story

Feeling creatively charged but without an outlet, Claire Needham and Rebecca Dealy decided to take control and produce one of their favorite plays, Twelfth Night or What You Will. Under the direction of emerging artist, Lily Whitsitt, Needham and Dealy have assembled some of the most dynamic and creative actors, musicians and designers to fully realize this magical play. The show will run July 29th, 30th and 31st. To purchase tickets for this inspiring event, please visit http://www.brownpapertickets.com/event/187086


What We Need & What You Get

From the very beginning, we have wanted this production to be set on a rooftop. We want our audience to feel like they are at a great summer party that happens to feature Shakespeare and music. After scouring the city for potential roofs, we found our ideal space in the roof of Brooklyn's OfficeOps. A large part of our budget will go towards the rental fee. Every single person involved in this project is working for free and our incomparable designers are working tirelessly to put this show together on a dime. We ask for your generosity with the hope that seeing our show will, as it has for all of us creating it, re-enthuse your beliefs in New York's theatrical community. To show our immense appreciation to all of you, we have partnered with The Private Theatre, a non-profit theatre company led by John Gould Rubin, so that we can make all of your donations tax deductible. In addition, we'd like to offer the following perks:


$25 donation: Signed copy of the program and a free drink at the performance

$40 donation: Signed copy of the program, free drink and 1 free ticket

$50 donation: Signed copy of the program, 2 free drinks and 1 free ticket

$75 donation: Signed program, 2 free tickets, 2 free drinks and a CD from LISN (featuring company member and music arranger Chris-Gerard Heyward)

$100 donation: Name in program, Signed program, 2 free tickets, 2 free drinks, LISN CD and OUR UNDYING LOVE


Remember, any funds you donate are tax-deductible, so don't be shy; unleash your generosity! When you donate, please include your street address in the section called "Tell the campaign where to send your Perk," so that we know where to send your tax receipt.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you have any time or skill you'd like to volunteer in lieu of a monetary donation, don't be shy! We can absolutely use your help and artistry! Please contact rebeccadealy@gmail.com

story:
(ENGLISH, CASTELLANO, CATALÀ)

Please help me get to the WPIC Conference in Stockholm, Sweden, this summer

Hi, I am Angelina Llongueras, a theater artist from Barcelona,  Catalonia, Spain, relocated to San Francisco, CA. I am an actress, a playwright, a stage director and a theatre arts researcher and professor.

After a long selection process, my one woman show "Phoolan is Everyone" has been invited to be part of WPIC (Women Playwright's International Conference) to be celebrated in Sweden this summer.

Being able to attend this conference is a great opportunity for this play and for me as a playwright, as it will  open doors and give me the necessary back up to help my plays be produced. Being a woman playwright with no "big contacts" and a penchant for social justice theatrical themes, this is the best opportunity I may have to advance my playwrighting career.

For more than 25 years, I have created many independent shows dealing with silenced individuals and cultures, with my own resources exclusively, and have brought them to many stages in the world, so as to preserve the kind of stories that tend to be "erased" from collective memory, or distorted. In 2004 I created in Barcelona, and premiered in Ecuador my "Phoolan is Everyone", thinking that Phoolan Devi, the strong Indian woman whose life and legacy it explains, would be a good role model for young Ecuadorian girls to learn from. I have brought it to many alternative theatres and cultural centers in Europe, the Americas and the US. In November 2010 it was invited for participation in the  prestigious Bogotá and Cali Women Theatre Festivals in Colombia.

Due to the "cuts" in the arts and education, in spite of my ongoing dedication to theatre in all its forms, these last years I have had to survive by getting my income from an array of non-artistic jobs. I barely cover my expenses and have no extra money to allow me to go on a trip like the one I have been invited to. I tried to obtain travel grants for artists from "normal" venues, and discovered that most of them have also been "cut" and there are practically no funds for supporting people like me.

I need $ 3,000 to cover the plane ticket and the costs of my stay there . I am trying to get cheap plane tickets with one stop on the way, and if I get the money in June,  there will be some time left to find this kind of tickets.

Aside from the perks I am offering, I will make sure to send a weekly THANK YOU  email with the updated list of donors to all of you.

THANKS!!!

(SPANISH)

Por favor, ayúdeme a asistir a la Conferencia Internacional de Mujeres Dramaturgas (WPIC por sus siglas en inglés) en Estocolmo, Suecia, este verano

Hola, soy Angelina Llongueras, una teatrera de Barcelona, Cataluña, España, que actualmente vive en San Francisco, CA. Soy actriz, dramaturga, directora escénica y profesora e investigadora teatral.

Después de un largo proceso de selección, mi monólogo "Phoolan somos todas" ha sido invitado a formar parte de la WPIC (Conferencia Internacional de Mujeres Dramaturgas) que se celebrará en Suecia este verano.

Poder asistir a esta conferencia es una gran oportunidad para esta obra y para mí como dramaturga, ya que abrirá puertas y me dará el apoyo necesario para promover que se produzcan mis obras de teatro. Al ser una mujer dramaturga sin "grandes contactos" y con inclinación  a abordar temas de justicia social en el teatro, ésta es la mejor oportunidad que se me presenta para hacer avanzar mi carrera dramatúrgica.

Durante más de 25 años he creado muchos espectáculos independientes que tratan de individuos y culturas silenciadas, con mis propios recursos exclusivamente, y las he llevado a muchos escenarios del mundo, para preservar la clase de historias que tienden a "borrarse" de la memoria colectiva, o a distorsionarse. En 2004 creé en Barcelona y estrené en Ecuador mi "Phoolan somos todas" porque pensé que Phoolan Devi, la mujer india fuerte cuya vida y legado cuenta esta obra, sería un buen modelo del que las jóvenes muchachas ecuatorianas podían aprender. La he llevado a muchos teatros alternativos y centros culturales de Europa, América y los EEUU. En Noviembre de 2010 fuí invitada a participar en los prestigiosos Festivales de Teatro de Mujeres de Bogotá y Cali de Colombia.

Debido a los "recortes" en las artes y la educación, a pesar de mi contínua dedicación al teatro en todas sus variantes, estos últimos años he tenido que sobrevivir obteniendo mis ingresos de un serie de empleos no artísticos. Apenas me alcanza para cubrir mis gastos y no me sobra dinero para permitirme hacer un viaje como éste al que se me ha invitado. He tratado de obtener becas de viaje para artistas por medio de las fuentes "normales" y he descubierto que la mayoría de ellas también se han "recortado" y que prácticamente no hay fondos para dar apoyo a las personas como yo.

Me hacen falta $ 3.000 para cubrir el boleto de avión y los gastos de mi estancia allí. Estoy tratando de conseguir boletos de avión baratos, con una parada en medio, y si obtengo el dinero en junio, auún quedará tiempo para esta clase de boletos.

Aparte de los premios que ofrezco,  me aseguraré de enviar semanalmente un email de GRATITUD con la lista de donantes puesta al día a todos Vdes.

¡GRACIAS!!!!

(CATALÀ)

Sis plau, ajudeu-me a estar present a la Conferència Internacional de Dones Dramaturgues (WPIC per les seves sigles en anglès) a Estocolm, Suècia, aquest estiu

Hola, sóc l'Angelina Llongueras, una teatrera de Barcelona, Catalunya, España, que ara viu a San Francisco, CA. Sóc actriu, dramaturga, directora escènica i professora i investigadora teatral.

Després d'un llarg procès de selecció, el meu monòleg "Phoolan som totes" ha estat convidat a formar part de la Conferència Internacional de Dones Dramaturgues (WPIC) que es celebrarà a Suècia aquest estiu.

Poder estar present a aquesta conferència es una gran oportunitat per aquesta obra y per mi com a dramaturga, doncs obrirà portes i em donarà el suport necessari per poder produïr les meves obres. Donat que sóc una dramaturga sense "grans conexions" i amb una inclinació cap el tema de la justíca social en la meva feina teatral, aquésta és la millor oportunitat que se'm presenta per poder fer anar endavant la meva carrera dramatúrgica.

Durant més de 25 anys, he creat molts espectacles independents sobre individus o cultures silenciades, amb els meus propis mitjans, i les he portades a molts escenaris del món, per preservar lea classe d¡històries que tenen tendència a "esborrar-se" de la memòria col.lectiva, o a distorsionar-se. L'any 2004 vaig escriure a Barcelona i vaig estrenar a l'Ecuador, la meva "Phoolan som totes", pensant que la Phoolan Devi, la dona índia forta en la vida i en el llegat de la qual es basa l'obra, podia ser un bonmodel del qual les noietes joves de l'Ecuador en podien aprendre. L'he portada a molts teatres alternatius i centres culturals d'Europa, Amèrica i els EEUU. El novembre de 2010 va ser convidadaa participar en els prestigiosos Festivals de Teatre de Dones de Bogotà i Cali a Colòmbia.

Degut a les "retallades" a les arts i l'educació, malgrat la meva dedicació contínua al teatre en totes les seves varietats, aquests darrers anys he hagut de sobreviure aconseguint els meus ingressos d'una sèrie de feines no artístiques. A penes m'arriba per cobrir les meves despeses i no tinc diners de sobra per poder fer un viatge com aquest al qual se m'ha convidat. He provat d'aconseguir beques de viatge per artistes de les fonts "normals" i he descobert que la majoria també han estat "retallades" i que pràcticament no hi ha fons per donar suport a les persones com jo.

Em calen $ 3.000 per cobrir el bitllet d'avió i les despeses de la meva estància allà. estic provant d'aconseguir bitllets d'avió barats, amb una parada enmig, i si tinc els diners el mes de juny.encara hi haurà temps per aquest tipus de bitllets.

Apart dels premis que ofereixo, m'asseguraré de enviar un email setmanal d'AGRAÏMENT amb la llista posada al dia dels i les donants a tots vostès.

GRÀCIES!!!
story_txt:
(ENGLISH, CASTELLANO, CATALÀ)
Please help me get to the WPIC Conference in Stockholm, Sweden, this summer
Hi, I am Angelina Llongueras, a theater artist from Barcelona,  Catalonia, Spain, relocated to San Francisco, CA. I am an actress, a playwright, a stage director and a theatre arts researcher and professor.
After a long selection process, my one woman show "Phoolan is Everyone" has been invited to be part of WPIC (Women Playwright's International Conference) to be celebrated in Sweden this summer.
Being able to attend this conference is a great opportunity for this play and for me as a playwright, as it will  open doors and give me the necessary back up to help my plays be produced. Being a woman playwright with no "big contacts" and a penchant for social justice theatrical themes, this is the best opportunity I may have to advance my playwrighting career.
For more than 25 years, I have created many independent shows dealing with silenced individuals and cultures, with my own resources exclusively, and have brought them to many stages in the world, so as to preserve the kind of stories that tend to be "erased" from collective memory, or distorted. In 2004 I created in Barcelona, and premiered in Ecuador my "Phoolan is Everyone", thinking that Phoolan Devi, the strong Indian woman whose life and legacy it explains, would be a good role model for young Ecuadorian girls to learn from. I have brought it to many alternative theatres and cultural centers in Europe, the Americas and the US. In November 2010 it was invited for participation in the  prestigious Bogotá and Cali Women Theatre Festivals in Colombia.
Due to the "cuts" in the arts and education, in spite of my ongoing dedication to theatre in all its forms, these last years I have had to survive by getting my income from an array of non-artistic jobs. I barely cover my expenses and have no extra money to allow me to go on a trip like the one I have been invited to. I tried to obtain travel grants for artists from "normal" venues, and discovered that most of them have also been "cut" and there are practically no funds for supporting people like me.
I need $ 3,000 to cover the plane ticket and the costs of my stay there . I am trying to get cheap plane tickets with one stop on the way, and if I get the money in June,  there will be some time left to find this kind of tickets.
Aside from the perks I am offering, I will make sure to send a weekly THANK YOU  email with the updated list of donors to all of you.
THANKS!!!
(SPANISH)

story:
Message Me If... is hitting the road! 

Kelly Anderson Dance Theatre is bringing  Message Me If... to Milwaukee and we couldn't be more excited!  I will soon be sharing one of my favorite works in one of my favorite places, my hometown.  I hope that, with your help, I can make this homecoming a true success.  

About the show 

Inspired by several years of unsuccessful relationships and the accumulation of horrible online dating disasters, I decided to take matters into my own hands.  Contemporary dating sucked.  So, I decided to make a dance about it. 

Message Me If... is an evening-length dance theater production about a single girl living in the contemporary dating world.  Boozy first date disasters, cat lady meltdowns, online catastrophes, a reality television tragedy and the infamous “ladies night” all make their way into the imaginary world she creates based on her unsuccessful quest for companionship. 

Why we need your help!

Truthfully, I am tired of having to ask family and friends for donations. Unfortunately, due to the current state of the arts, crowdfunding seems to be one of the only solutions to pull this off independently.  I could opt to raise ticket prices as a solution.  However, I want people to see the show.  I want everyone to see the show, not just those who can afford it.

With a full house, I should be able to reimburse some  of the production costs.  With your help, I will be able to pay the dancers too.  They have worked incredibly hard to make this dream a reality and this show couldn't exist without their dedication and talent.  Help me reward them for being awesome!!!!! 

Where your money is going

$3200 performer compensation
$250 promotional material (posters/flyers)
$1350 lighting design and remaining theater rental
$400 remaining performance costs (video, costume, props)
$400 Lodging 

Most importantly!

I really hope you can make the show. That is the greatest contribution you can make.  We do this because we love it and we love sharing it with you.
P.S. Chicago and Madison folks...Milwaukee isn't that far away and I promise it will be worth the trek. 

Don't miss Message Me If... in Milwaukee!
Danceworks, 1661 N. Water St.
March 12th, 6pm and 8pm 
March 13th, 3pm
For tickets visit: http://danceworksmke.org/performances/guestconcerts/
For more information visit:
https://www.facebook.com/KellyAndersonDance/?fref=ts
or 
http://www.kellyandersondancetheatre.com
Any contribution will help us pull this off, even if minimal.  Every dollar adds up! Skip that cocktail and contribute to a dancer instead.

story:
I am a choreographer, video artist and singer/songwriter, living in Oakland, CA. I recently moved from Brooklyn, New York to expand my individual experience.  I majored in Dance and Literature at The New School University.  

Recently, I have been working on a film and dance piece, titled 'Subject to Change'. This is a film with a live dance component, exploring perception. Prying into the subconscious and conscious mind, I ask: 'Why do we see what we see?' The music explores sound and senses. I collaborated with the very talented Electronic DJ, Jason Snell, who worked like Magic to thread together sensory music.

 It is a part of The ODC Pilot 62 Program in San Francisco, shown alongside five talented choreographers and film artists in the Bay Area. We are all working together to premier a nights work, titled 'Kinetoscope...This Time With Pictures' on March 22 & 23.

 This process has been mentored by renowned Los Angeles based filmmaker, video artist and choreographer, Cari Ann Shim Sham*. This program is designed for emerging choreographers.  The theme is Dance for Camera. Pilot is known for it's slogan 'pulling it together by your own bootstraps', working as a collective. The artists simultaneously make work, while dividing roles (PR, Social Media, Box Office, Programs, Reception etc.) to put up an evening of new work. That being said, this is why I need your help.

During this process, I have found an exciting creative voice combining these two elements of dance and video. However, as I open into my process and new work, I am in need of financial support. Production for this piece has taken more time and money than expected. So far, I've spent more than 300 dollars on rehearsal, travel, computer programs and equipment. Now, I really need help to pay for rehearsal space and production (costume and set). I would love for that to even be a possibility! I would love to  pay the very talented performer Ashley Trottier for her dedication and hard work to this piece. 

Help me make this piece all it can be and more. Contribute anything you can, even one dollar counts. If you cannot give at this time, help spread the word to friends and family that may be able to.

I believe in the power of art. Expression is a courageous act that can transform the individual and community, even on a subtle level. We must keep art and performance alive. Support this work, help it breath.

story:
UPDATES!

To see Uma & the rest of the Movery contemporary dance company in their inaugural performance go here: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6MYDPy15N9A

See Important Links at the bottom of the page 

About Me:

My name is Uma Shannon and I am a dancer from Amherst, MA. I began dancing at East Street Dance Center in Amherst, MA in the fall of 2009 at the age of 13. Although some would say I started dance late, I know I am in good company since dancers such as Martha Graham, Rudolf Nureyev, and José Limón also started in their teens as well.

I study and enjoy ballet, character, modern, contemporary, and flamenco. I have had the good fortune to train with Irina Vakhromeeva, Andre Reyes, Claire Maurey, Tai Jimenez, Tekla Kostek, Onalie Arts and Ines Arrubla among others.

The Goal:

In February, I auditioned and was accepted to the Gelsey Kirkland Academy of Classical Ballet’s 2013 Summer Intensive which I will be attending for three weeks. Attending this program is a dream come true.

My goal is to raise $5,000 through this campaign to cover the costs of tuition, room and partial board in New York City, plus other related costs such as travel, lunches, and program activities that are not covered by tuition. I am one of five children and while my parents do their utmost to support all of us in our numerous endeavors, money is very tight.

My Past Experiences:

My performance experience includes such classics as Don Quixote, The Nutcracker, Maurice Maeterlinck’s “The Bluebird of Happiness”, and Paquita. Along with my ballet experience I have danced in a number of original contemporary works. Recently I joined dancer/choreographer Claire Maurey’s contemporary dance company, The Movery, located in the Pioneer Valley of Western Massachusetts.

I support my dance training with work study at my ballet school, and working as an assistant instructor in the pre-ballet classes.

How You Can Help:

In exchange for your help, my sisters and I are offering various perks which you can see on the right hand side of the page.

If you can't help out financially then please take a moment to support this campaign and share this page with your friends.

I really appreciate any support you can provide and thank you for taking an interest in my hopes and dreams to take this next important step forward in my dance career. I look forward to expanding my knowledge and experience as a dancer this summer at Gelsey Kirkland’s Academy of Classical Ballet.

 

Links

Tatiana Shannon's DeviantArt site - http://tarasgreen.deviantart.com/gallery/ (examples of the perks offered by Tatiana Shannon are in the top left hand folder titled Samples for Indiegogo Campaign)

Olympia Shannon's photography: http://cargocollective.com/olympiashannon.

Gelsey Kirkland Academy of Classical Ballet - http://www.gelseykirklandballet.org/ (where Uma will go this summer!)

East Street Dance Center - http://www.eaststreetballet.com/ (Uma's dance school.)

The Movery - http://www.themovery.com (Uma is a member of The Movery, a locally based contemporary dance company.)

I am one of five children and while my parents do their utmost to support all of us in our numerous endeavors, money is very tight.
My Past Experiences:
My performance experience includes such classics as Don Quixote, The Nutcracker, Maurice Maeterlinck’s “The Bluebird of Happiness”, and Paquita. Along with my ballet experience I have danced in a number of original contemporary works. Recently I joined dancer/choreographer Claire Maurey’s contemporary dance company, The Movery, located in the Pioneer Valley of Western Massachusetts.
I support my dance training with work study at my ballet school, and working as an assistant instructor in the pre-ballet classes.
How You Can Help:
In exchange for your help, my sisters and I are offering various perks which you can see on the right hand side of the page.
If you can't help out financially then please take a moment to support this campaign and share this page with your friends.
I really appreciate any support you can provide and thank you for taking an interest in my hopes and dreams to take this next important step forward in my dance career. I look forward to expanding my knowledge and experience as a dancer this summer at Gelsey Kirkland’s Academy of Classical Ballet.
 
Links
Tatiana Shannon's DeviantArt site - http://tarasgreen.deviantart.com/gallery/ (examples of the perks offered by Tatiana Shannon are in the top left hand folder titled Samples for Indiegogo Campaign)
Olympia Shannon's photography: http://cargocollective.com/olympiashannon.
Gelsey Kirkland Academy of Classical Ballet - http://www.gelseykirklandballet.org/ (where Uma will go this summer!)
East Street Dance Center - http://www.eaststreetballet.com/ (Uma's dance school.)
The Movery - http://www.themovery.com (Uma is a member of The Movery, a locally based contemporary dance company.)

story:
WHO WE ARE

Berlin International Youth Theatre (BIYT) is a MAGICAL MIXTURE of young people ages 12-17, from different countries, cultures, ages, and schools coming together to develop acting skills, BUILD SELF ESTEEM, work together as an ensemble, and MAKE NEW FRIENDS. All of this hard work is channeled into the creation of a yearly LIVE PERFORMANCE in a professional theatre in the heart of Berlin.

What makes BIYT so unique is that classes are taught and performances are supported by PROFESSIONAL THEATRE ARTISTS, often volunteering their time to bring the highest quality theatrical experience to international youth in Berlin. At the same time, through our DIVERSE PARTICIPANTS, we provide a platform for social exchange between different cultures, promoting communication and understanding in the global language of English.

You see, our goal at BIYT is not only to provide OUTSTANDING THEATRE EDUCATION but also to present high quality original performances for families that are both entertaining and thought provoking. Our work is a COLLABORATION between the imagination and energy of the youth we serve, the professional theatre artists who support them, and the international heritage of the city where we reside.

Like all collaborations, BIYT needs the help of others to bring magic to the stage—YOU CAN MAKE AN IMMEDIATE AND SIGNIFICANT IMPACT with your support today!

OUR PROJECT

After months of training, devising, writing, and—let’s face it—having a ton of fun, our yearly original production is beginning to come to life! The students of BIYT are once again tackling difficult issues through theatre with the world premiere of MODELMONSTERMODEL- The Curse of Narcissus!

“Bombarded by the media with images of retouched and impossible beauty, these images begin to shape our understandings of reality and the world, including the identities of its people and places.” –Priscilla Bergey, Director

Through in-depth group DISCUSSION, individual RESEARCH, and community INTERVIEWS, the participants of BIYT have created theme for an original theatrical experience that explores issues of BODY IMAGE and is inspired by the ancient Greek myth of Narcissus. MODELMONSTERMODEL- The Curse of Narcissus is a play that encourages an appreciation of our own beauty, which so often has been wounded and undervalued by the images we see in the media. This ENSEMBLE CREATED WORK will be devised and performed by the young participants of BIYT.

We must raise 3000€ before opening night to bring ModelMonsterModel: The Curse of Narcissus to life and WE NEED YOUR HELP to reach our goal!

WHAT YOUR GIFT WILL FUND

BIYT families pay a small monthly fee to participate in our weekly workshops where they train in and create performance, lead by professional theatre artists. Workshops begin in the fall and culminate with our original production in late spring. In order to keep this monthly cost low, we utilize the generosity of the Berlin theatrical community who donates our rehearsal and performance space. In addition, many of our professional teaching artists and support staff volunteer their time and talents without pay. Even with this outpouring of practical support, the money we earn does not begin to cover the cost of bringing our yearly vision to the stage for the young people of BIYT.

With your help, the money we raise before opening night will go to fund production essentials such as lighting and sound designers and operators, costumes and sets for our performers, a choreographer, and a stage manager, to mention only a few budget items. While so many of the BIYT staff volunteer their time without pay, those few professionals we hire to support our productions work well below industry standards for to hep us bring to the stage what our participants have created.

It doesn’t have to cost a king’s ransom to fund a quality production, but it does need funding. For instance, a donation of 25€ will fund the creation of 1-2 costumes for a performer and for our production of ModelMonsterModel: The Curse of Narcissus and in this production, we need to build 40 costumes! Of course, A DONATION OF ANY SIZE helps us get that much closer to our goal, but for your generosity at the following amounts, we have some special gifts to say “THANK YOU!”:

For your donation* of 25€, you will receive one ticket to any performance of ModelMonsterModel: The Curse of Narcissus! 

For your donation* of 50€, you will receive our popular and stylish BIYT Logo Canvas Shopping Tote! 

For your donation* of 100€, you will receive a DVD of our spring production, ModelMonsterModel: The Curse of Narcissus! 

*Berlin International Youth Theatre is in the process of seeking non-profit status as an organization. We're not there yet! Unfortunately this means that your gift this year is NOT tax-deductible, but the good karma it will bring you is priceless!

WHY YOUR GIFT MATTERS

Since 2010, Berlin International Youth Theatre has brought QUALITY THEATRE EDUCATION to English speaking youth in Berlin. With your gift this year, you will be supporting our fourth original World Premiere production, written and created by the young people of BIYT. Many of our families have grown up participating in Berlin International Youth Theatre and we are constantly looking for new ways to engage the community in a MEANINGFUL AND LASTING way. Your gift towards this year’s production will enable us to continue our LEGACY of providing a unique and transformative theatrical experience to the international families of Berlin.

story:
OUR PLAY:
It's 1980 and Reagan has just been elected. August had fled the country six years prior to be with his beautiful young Greek bride on a secluded Mediterranean island, where he planted a modest vineyard. Now, his young wife is pregnant, his crop is robust, and he is about to have his first tasting... When a strange woman in a large-brimmed hat arrives at the couple's guesthouse. (www.sheilacallaghan.com)

OUR COMPANY:
We are impassioned by theater that is visceral, poetic and honest, theater that is both full of fireworks and tempered by the subtle beauties of daily life, theater that connects us to the most fundamental parts of ourselves: The joy, the anger, the fear, the desire, the thrill, the animal. Our work is to embody these parts fully and unashamedly, and to facilitate our audience’s contact with those parts of themselves. We want to make a home in your heart for two hours or so. We want to take your breath away. We’ll give it back. Maybe...
________________________________________________________________________________________

Hello! We are LES VIGNES, a New York City based theater company and Sheila Callaghan's LASCIVIOUS SOMETHING is our inaugural production, playing September 14th through 18th at the beautiful 6B Community Garden in the East Village. But we can't do it without you. Your kind donations are the pieces that will put our puzzle together. Here is where they will go:

Lighting and sound are not only integral to the theatre, they are art forms unto themselves. We are blessed to be performing outdoors and need to meet the demands of that atmosphere so you can see and hear our play clearly and beautifully.

Props and costumes will help us create the Greek island home where the play takes place in 1980, and bring you there with us.

Postcards, flyers & programs to establish contact with the community.

Each artist on our team joined us out of an excitement about the project and devotion to their craft. We'd be privileged to have your support in paying each member of our cast and crew a stipend for their time and energy.
_________________________________________________________________________________________

LASCIVIOUS SOMETHING
a play by Sheila Callaghan
produced by LES VIGNES
directed by Shannon Fillion
starring Ezekiel Briscoe, Leemore Malka, Julia Piaton, Kate Schroeder
lighting & sound by Ben Demarest // stage managed by Edward Herman
assistant directed by Kaitlin Schuster // dramaturgy by Jess Applebaum
September 14th-18th // 6B Community Garden // 6th Street & Avenue B // NEW YORK
free admission // reservation details to follow 
FOR ALL THE LATEST NEWS: http://www.facebook.com/pages/LASCIVIOUS-SOMETH...
please email leemoreleemore@gmail.com with any questions!
